=== [[Wikipedia talk:Refactoring talk pages#rfc_BEEEAE6|Wikipedia talk:Refactoring talk pages]] expired 2020-01-02 14:01 ===
* Id: BEEEAE6
* Date: 2020-01-02 00:43:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|933604808|UNSORTED 933604808}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|933688640|UNSORTED 933688640}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Hello! [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wikipedia%3ARefactoring_talk_pages&type=revision&diff=929450979&oldid=929449926 In this change], I had added text to this page which listed fixing [[WP:Link rot|dead links]] in other peoples comments ([https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=User%3ATheAwesomeHwyh&type=revision&diff=933602368&oldid=933602179 see example]). However, the change was based only on what was [[Help:Archiving a talk page#Choosing_a_bot._Table_comparing_the_2_main_bots|implied in a table on a mostly unrelated page]].  That is why I ask whether it is appropriate to change other people's talkpage comments so to fix dead links. Please vote '''yes''' or '''no''' below. [[User:TheAwesomeHwyh|<span style="font-family:Courier;color:#FFA352;background-color: #000000;">TheAwesome</span>]][[User_Talk:TheAwesomeHwyh|<span style="font-family:Courier;color:#12ECFF;background-color:#000000;">Hwyh</span>]] 00:43, 2 January 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Bruce Pascoe#rfc_8DF25AC|Talk:Bruce Pascoe]] expired 2020-01-04 03:01 ===
* Id: 8DF25AC
* User: Bacondrum
* Date: 2019-12-15 21:39:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|930925850|BIO 930925850}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|930925851|HIST 930925851}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|930925854|POL 930925854}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|935812304|BIO 935812304}}

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|935812310|POL 935812310}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Historian [[Bruce Pascoe]] has recently had his Aboriginality questioned by [[Andrew Bolt]]. The claim is highly controversial and similar claims by Bolt have landed him in court: [https://www.smh.com.au/national/bolt-found-guilty-of-race-discrimination-20110928-1wqhd.html Bolt found guilty of race discrimination], the "scandal" is based on a self published [https://www.dark-emu-exposed.org/ blog] and is being run by "culture warriors" [[The Australian]] and the [[Herald Sun]] (both owned by the [[News Corp (2013‚Äìpresent)|News Corp]]). No other mainstream outlets have run the story and the claims made are potentially [[WP:LIBEL]]. Are Andrew Bolt and other "culture warriors" reliable sources for Aboriginal identity claims? [[User:Bacondrum|Bacondrum]] ([[User talk:Bacondrum|talk]]) 21:39, 15 December 2019 (UTC)}}


=== [[Talk:Bruce Pascoe#rfc_2179716|Talk:Bruce Pascoe]] expired 2020-01-04 03:01 ===
* Id: 2179716
* User: Laterthanyouthink
* Date: 2019-12-05 02:09:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|929329143|BIO 929329143}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|933988769|BIO 933988769}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This discussion, as you can see from above, does not appear to be going anywhere, and I think we need some more voices in here. Copied from above (as yet no other options offered, but please add if you have one). As far as I can see, our options here are:
# Mention his self-reported ancestry in the lead as well as in the body.
# Leave out the ancestry in the lead but mention it in the body.
# Don't mention ancestry at all.
And/or
# Don't mention the (as yet unsubstantiated) allegations, coming from two avowedly right-wing sources, at all. Wait and watch for future press or other coverage.
# Mention the allegations, making clear the names of the accusers, in a brief note with the best possible sources, in the body of the text following mention of his self-reported ancestry.
[[User:Laterthanyouthink|Laterthanyouthink]] ([[User talk:Laterthanyouthink|talk]]) 02:09, 5 December 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Template talk:Infobox television#rfc_5041AD4|Template talk:Infobox television]] expired 2020-01-05 20:01 ===
* Id: 5041AD4
* User: Cyphoidbomb
* Date: 2019-12-23 17:58:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|932134295|MEDIA 932134295}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|932134297|TECH 932134297}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|934297050|MEDIA 934297050}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|934297052|TECH 934297052}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Indian films and television shows often have three credits for writing: Story, screenplay and dialogue. For background, please see [https://www.hindustantimes.com/brunch/dialogues-and-screenplay-separated-at-birth-abbas-tyrewala/story-EfS1ol8YDFZ6dTv6XnyqGJ.html this article]. The essence, is that someone might conceive of a story, someone will write the stage direction, and someone will write the dialogue, the latter being a specialised skill that a screenwriter doesn't always perform. This convention is not limited to a handful of series, it is widespread and obviously different from how western television shows are produced.

Currently, when editors add this content, they might lump all three into the {{para|writer}} parameter and format them using pseudoheadings like at [[Naagin (2015 TV series)]]:
:{{ubl|'''Story'''|Mrinal Jha|'''Screenplay'''|R M Joshi|'''Dialogues'''|Deepti Rawal}}

Should a {{para|dialogue}} parameter be added to the template? [[User:Cyphoidbomb|Cyphoidbomb]] ([[User talk:Cyphoidbomb|talk]]) 17:58, 23 December 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:2020 United States House of Representatives elections#rfc_3DB6A3D|Talk:2020 United States House of Representatives elections]] expired 2020-01-06 22:01 ===
* Id: 3DB6A3D
* User: Orser67
* Date: 2019-12-07 21:05:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|929736260|POL 929736260}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|934501047|POL 934501047}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There has been an ongoing discussion about the inclusion of each House race and associated details at [[2020 United States House of Representatives elections]], as well as other articles. Some editors have raised concerns regarding the size of the article, but others have argued that cutting down the information in the article is not justified. Here are some of the options that have been discussed:

* Option A: status quo, essentially. Keep all races and information currently in place in the article.
* Option B: do not list each individual race on this page, instead only having the races listed on state pages (e.g. [[2020 United States House of Representatives elections in Massachusetts]]).
* Option C: Do not list each individual race on this page, but instead have them listed (in essentially their current form) at a separate list article. 
* Option D: List all the races, but cut down on the details listed, shifting the more detailed information to other articles ([[2016 United States House of Representatives elections]] being one potential example)
* Option E: Something else 
-[[User:Orser67|Orser67]] ([[User talk:Orser67|talk]]) 21:05, 7 December 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Impeachment of Donald Trump#rfc_B9DA603|Talk:Impeachment of Donald Trump]] expired 2020-01-07 07:01 ===
* Id: B9DA603
* User: Hodgdon&#39;s secret garden
* Date: 2019-12-27 19:36:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|932714735|POL 932714735}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|934568735|POL 934568735}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The article currently reflects a common understanding that inasmuch as the Congressional articles read "is impeached," after passage this is so; that said, [https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2019-12-22/trump-impeachment-why-can-t-the-senate-start-a-trial-now the handful of times various states' highest courts issued decisions] regarding the matter, their conclusions have been it occurs at the bar, even if figuratively, of the trying body. Inasmuch as legal precedents consistently inform the latter and but common presumptions do the former, WP ought give more weight to both interpretations than currently.--[[User:Hodgdon&#39;s secret garden|Hodgdon&#39;s secret garden]] ([[User talk:Hodgdon&#39;s secret garden|talk]]) 19:36, 27 December 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Nevillean theory of Shakespeare authorship#rfc_6A71806|Talk:Nevillean theory of Shakespeare authorship]] expired 2020-01-07 19:01 ===
* Id: 6A71806
* User: Kfein
* Date: 2020-01-07 16:54:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|934637658|BIO 934637658}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|939465685|BIO 939465685}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should these aspects of the Neville authorship theory be included in the article: 

James and Rubinstein also suggest that Shakespeare's plays portray many of Neville's ancestors, who played major roles in British history, in a particularly favourable light. REF: Keys 2005. REF:Alberge 2005.

James and Rubinstein write that since Neville was a director of the Virginia Company, he would have been able to read the confidential letter by William Strachey that describes the Bermuda Shipwreck of 1609, that is considered a source for The Tempest. REF: BBC News 2005. REF:Alberge 2005.

[[User:Kfein|Kfein]] ([[User talk:Kfein|talk]]) 16:54, 7 January 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Knights of Columbus#rfc_4D6E430|Talk:Knights of Columbus]] expired 2020-01-08 03:01 ===
* Id: 4D6E430
* User: Elizium23
* Date: 2019-12-09 02:32:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|930000056|RELI 930000056}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|934725207|RELI 934725207}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the article mention that the Knights' lobbying for the phrase "Under God" to be inserted in the Pledge of Allegiance was successful, or not? [[User:Elizium23|Elizium23]] ([[User talk:Elizium23|talk]]) 02:32, 9 December 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Aphex Twin#rfc_12A6379|Talk:Aphex Twin]] expired 2020-01-08 05:01 ===
* Id: 12A6379
* User: Cambial Yellowing
* Date: 2019-12-09 04:20:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|929933738|BIO 929933738}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|929933742|MEDIA 929933742}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|934738974|BIO 934738974}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|934738975|MEDIA 934738975}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This RfC is about the inclusion of the phrase "local independent record label", releasing Aphex Twin's first record, in the lead. It follows a sentence about the artist starting to perform as a DJ in the area in which they grew up. As most featured/good articles about musicians or bands include in the lead salient summary details of how an artist went from unknown to becoming a notable musician (e.g. [[The_Beatles|1]], [[Nina Simone|2]], [[Elvis Presley|3]]), this aspect of ''how'' the artist achieved that is relevant, but other editor feels it is important not to include it in the lead for space reasons.

In the lead section, per [[WP:MOSLEAD]], part of the aim is to "cultivate interest in reading on", and expanding this section slightly from merely a list of the records and various aliases that the artist has used serves that end. More detail about the launching of the artist's career is given in the body. A [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Aphex_Twin&oldid=929840230 version] was arrived at after editing by [[user:Acousmana|Acousmana]], with the word "local" added to give narrative continuity from the preceding sentence [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Aphex_Twin&diff=next&oldid=929840230 here], but editor GentleCollapse6 feels it is important that a reference to his widening DJ career, and specifically any reference to the label which began his career and its place in the local techno community, be removed completely. This RfC seeks comments on ways to resolve these conflicting views. <span style="white-space:nowrap;text-shadow:#4682B4 0.1em 0.1em 1.5em,#4682B4 -0.1em -0.1em 1.5em;color:#000000">[[User:Cambial Yellowing|<i style="color:#999900">Cambial Yellowing</i>]][[User talk:Cambial Yellowing|<b style="color:#218000">‚ùß</b>]]</span> 04:20, 9 December 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Black Sabbath (album)#rfc_294D822|Talk:Black Sabbath (album)]] expired 2020-01-08 05:01 ===
* Id: 294D822
* User: Isento
* Date: 2019-12-09 04:07:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|929933742|MEDIA 929933742}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|934738975|MEDIA 934738975}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Black_Sabbath_%28album%29&type=revision&diff=929902569&oldid=929784157 This content was removed] by {{u|SolarFlash}} on the grounds that the source verifying the content is "in dispute" (although the only evidence of dispute is SolarFlash's undoing of the addition), and that [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Black_Sabbath_%28album%29&type=revision&diff=929894827&oldid=929784157 one should "obtain consensus before adding any additional genres"], even though SolarFlash had [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Black_Sabbath_%28album%29&type=revision&diff=929543107&oldid=929473894 removed a genre themselves without obtaining consensus]. So, as I am left to interpret their remarks as expressing a desire or demand for consensus if changes are to be made against their preferred revision of the genre content, I have listed this RfC. Given the fact that there are reliable third-party sources in both the lead and [[Black Sabbath (album)#Genre|in the body of the article]] verifying journalists who've claimed this album is of those two certain genres, should this content be removed, as SolarFlash attempted in their edit? [[User:Isento|isento]] ([[User talk:Isento|talk]]) 04:07, 9 December 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Timoth√©e Chalamet#rfc_F5C1430|Talk:Timoth√©e Chalamet]] expired 2020-01-09 02:01 ===
* Id: F5C1430
* User: KyleJoan
* Date: 2019-12-10 01:51:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|930075502|BIO 930075502}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|930075504|MEDIA 930075504}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|934883894|BIO 934883894}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|934883896|MEDIA 934883896}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Which of the two versions of a paragraph in the lead section is more suitable for the article?

'''A.''' Chalamet's breakthrough came for his lead role as Elio Perlman in Luca Guadagnino's romantic drama ''Call Me by Your Name'' (2017). It earned him a nomination for the Academy Award for Best Actor, making him the third-youngest nominee in the category. He portrayed a drug-addicted teenager in the drama ''Beautiful Boy'' (2018), earning a nomination for the BAFTA Award for Best Actor in a Supporting Role, King Henry V in the period drama ''The King'' (2019), and collaborated with Greta Gerwig in the coming-of-age films ''Lady Bird'' (2017) and ''Little Women'' (2019).

'''B.''' In 2017, Chalamet gained wider recognition for his portrayal of Elio Perlman in Luca Guadagnino's romantic drama ''Call Me by Your Name'', after which he appeared in the coming-of-age films ''Hot Summer Nights'' and ''Lady Bird'' as well as the western ''Hostiles''. His performance in ''Call Me by Your Name'' earned him an Academy Award nomination for Best Actor, making him the third-youngest nominee in the category. He then portrayed a drug-addicted teenager in the drama ''Beautiful Boy'' (2018), for which he was nominated for the BAFTA Award for Best Actor in a Supporting Role. In 2019, Chalamet starred as King Henry V and Theodore "Laurie" Laurence in the period dramas ''The King'' and ''Little Women'', respectively.

Please enter your votes under '''Survey''' and conduct any discussions under '''Comments'''. Thank you! [[User:KyleJoan|<span style="font-family:Consolas; color:#CD8C95">'''K'''yle'''J'''oan</span>]]<sup>[[User talk:KyleJoan|<span style="font-family:Consolas; color:#8B6969">talk</span>]]</sup>  01:51, 10 December 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Alcohol intoxication#rfc_DD68749|Talk:Alcohol intoxication]] expired 2020-01-09 06:01 ===
* Id: DD68749
* User: Rowsdower45
* Date: 2019-12-10 05:12:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|930097025|HIST 930097025}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|932346457|SCI 932346457}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|934907856|HIST 934907856}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|934907857|SCI 934907857}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I have been involved in an edit war with {{Reply to|Doc James}} over the question of whether [[alcoholism]] should be included as a complication of alcohol intoxication. My position is that our own article on Alcoholism provides sufficient language to justify the notion that alcohol intoxication leads to alcoholism: subsection [[Alcoholism#Warning_signs]] states that "warning signs of alcoholism include... frequent intoxication," and subsection [[Alcoholism#Definition]] states that "the drinking will increase as more intoxication is required." The other editor insists that listing alcoholism as a risk factor is sufficient, despite the fact that language published by Wikipedia makes clear that additional alcohol intoxication is just as much of a complication‚Äîin other words, my position is that alcohol intoxication is BOTH a risk factor for, AND complication of, alcoholism. I'm saying that we should, at the least, classify it as both. [[User:Rowsdower45|Rowsdower45]] ([[User talk:Rowsdower45|talk]]) 05:12, 10 December 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Requests for comment/Partial blocks#rfc_981318E|Wikipedia:Requests for comment/Partial blocks]] expired 2020-01-11 06:01 ===
* Id: 981318E
* Date: 2019-12-12 05:45:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|930399886|POLICY 930399886}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|930399888|PROP 930399888}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|935212403|POLICY 935212403}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|935212406|PROP 935212406}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
[[File:MediaWiki's Special-Block interface, taken February 21, 2019.png|thumb|Screenshot of the new [[Special:Block]] interface with partial blocks enabled]]
Currently, administrators are only technically able to prevent users from editing the entire site via a [[WP:BLOCK|block]]. In 2018 and early 2019, the Wikimedia Foundation's [[Wikipedia:Community health initiative on English Wikipedia|Anti-Harassment Tools team]] worked on implementing '''partial blocks'''. Rather than the entire site, this functionality would allow [[WP:ADMIN|administrators]] to prevent a user from:
# Editing one or more specific page(s)
# Editing all pages within one or more namespace(s)
# Emailing other users
As of December 2019, this functionality [[phab:T218626|has been deployed]] on most large- and medium-size wikis‚Äîspecifically the Arabic, Bengali, Chinese, Dutch, Finnish, French, German, Hebrew, Hungarian, Italian, Japanese, Korean, Persian, Polish, Portuguese, Russian, Serbian, Spanish, and Telugu Wikipedias, as well as on Meta Wiki, MediaWiki, and all Wiktionary, Wikivoyage, and Wikisource wikis. There are plans to deploy the functionality to more projects in the future as well. More information on partial blocks can be read at [[Wikipedia:Community health initiative on English Wikipedia/Partial blocks]]. An example of a partial blocks policy modeled off of other wikis can be found at [[:Meta:Partial block model policy]].

The purpose of this [[WP:RFC|request for comment]] is to determine whether partial blocks should be enabled on the English Wikipedia. 05:45, 12 December 2019 (UTC)}}

*Question 2. Should the sections of this article be ordered in "family" order (Protestantism second) or "denomination" order (Eastern Orthodox Church second)? [[User:Elizium23|Elizium23]] ([[User talk:Elizium23|talk]]) 17:36, 12 December 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Lou Dobbs#rfc_78760F2|Talk:Lou Dobbs]] expired 2020-01-11 22:01 ===
* Id: 78760F2
* User: Jdcomix
* Date: 2019-12-28 01:01:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|932761859|POL 932761859}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|935312562|POL 935312562}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I was lurking through various ARBCOM cases in 2019, and happened across one that covered this article. I clicked it, interested in the subject, only to find that the article is teeming with NPOV violations. Take the section under "Political views and controversies" called "Birtherism": the entire section is just attacking the subject of the page. I'm not a defender of Fox News or their obvious bias, but this seems completely contrary to Wikipedia's purpose as an aggregate of what reliable sources say to produce an encyclopedia. What's the point of mentioning an AP article that says that he was supposedly a "publicity nightmare"? The only reason this is here is to attack the subject of the article, which is not only a NPOV violation, but is also a BLP violation. Hell, the entire political views and controversies section is just attacks (typically, controversies sections are not something that should take up half of the article). Also, the claim in the lede that he is a "Trump confidante" is not supported by the sources that the claim cites. As a result of all of this, I'm asking for input on '''what we should do to neutrally reword the controversies section, to the best of our ability, as supported by reliable sources'''. I understand that this topic has been discussed ad nauseam on the talk page, but nothing has been done to solve the problem. Do any of the editors of this page have some ideas as to how we could rework the controversies section? Thanks, and happy holidays! [[User:Jdcomix|Jdcomix]] ([[User talk:Jdcomix|talk]]) 01:01, 28 December 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:White Croatia#rfc_DE6F291|Talk:White Croatia]] expired 2020-01-12 05:01 ===
* Id: DE6F291
* User: Rosguill
* Date: 2019-12-13 04:20:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|930539422|HIST 930539422}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|935374144|HIST 935374144}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 This is a two-part RfC convened as the result of [[Wikipedia:Dispute_resolution_noticeboard#White_Croatia|this discussion at the dispute resolution noticeboard]]. The RfC concerns the addition of claims regarding various source's views on the location of White Croatia. The first issue concerns the addition of claims attributed to 19th century sources, and the second issue concerns the interpretation of the source ≈Ωivkovic (2012). A third dispute identified at DRN is contingent on the outcome of the ≈Ωivkovic dispute, and thus there may be a need for a further RfC once this one is closed. <sub>signed, </sub>[[User:Rosguill|'''''Rosguill''''']] <sup>[[User talk:Rosguill|''talk'']]</sup> 04:20, 13 December 2019 (UTC)}}

* '''B''':  By 1968, the Beatles had achieved commercial and critical success. The group's mid-1967 release, ''Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band'', was number one in the UK for 27 weeks, through to the start of February 1968, having sold 250,000 copies in the first week after release.

Tables for each series of the programme, covering the results of Live Rounds - Semi-finals and Finals - features two columns of fields, the first denoting the act of a participant in that stage, and the second for buzzes and votes of judges (except finals). * '''A''' - Delete the first field
* '''B''' - Delete the second field
* '''C''' - Delete both fields

=== [[Talk:List of Falcon 9 and Falcon Heavy launches#rfc_5DDF440|Talk:List of Falcon 9 and Falcon Heavy launches]] expired 2020-01-17 13:01 ===
* Id: 5DDF440
* User: Tercer
* Date: 2020-01-07 15:14:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|934628439|SCI 934628439}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|936220747|SCI 936220747}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the [[List_of_Falcon_9_and_Falcon_Heavy_launches#Booster_landings|booster landings]] graph be simplified? More specifically, is the graph difficult to understand due to having too much detail? A closely related issue is that most editors agree that the captions "Ocean failure", "Parachutes failure", and "Ocean touchdown" should be improved, but we cannot come to a consensus as to how. Simplifying the graph would solve this.

The options for simplification are:

*'''Option 1:''' Do nothing.
*'''Option 2:''' Merge the categories "Ocean failure", "Parachutes failure", and "Ocean touchdown" together into "Test (no recovery)".
*'''Option 3:''' Merge the categories "Ocean failure", "Parachutes failure", "Ocean touchdown", and "No attempt" together into "No attempt".
*'''Option 4:''' Same as option 2, and also merge both kinds of success into "Success" and both kinds of failure into "Failure". 
[[User:Tercer|Tercer]] ([[User talk:Tercer|talk]]) 15:14, 7 January 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:ERC Starting Grant#rfc_2FAC2BE|Talk:ERC Starting Grant]] expired 2020-01-18 01:01 ===
* Id: 2FAC2BE
* User: Jerodlycett
* Date: 2020-01-17 18:30:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|936266455|UNSORTED 936266455}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|936315124|UNSORTED 936315124}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
If these two pages, and the third grant, can be expanded into one article on [[European Research Council Grants]] then they should be. Notable grantees could help. However if they cannot be expanded into their own article then just redirect these and the third potential article to [[European Research Council#Grants offered]]. Just don't feel this quite meets an AfD yet. [[User:Jerodlycett|Jerod Lycett]] ([[User talk:Jerodlycett|talk]]) 18:30, 17 January 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style#rfc_1C4F78A|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style]] expired 2020-01-18 02:01 ===
* Id: 1C4F78A
* User: Jack Upland
* Date: 2019-12-19 01:19:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|931467519|POL 931467519}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|931467524|STYLE 931467524}}

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should legal abbreviations for judicial offices, such as "Smith J" for "Justice Smith", be used in the text of articles? Examples can be seen in [[Court of Disputed Returns (Australia)]] and [[Butler Machine Tool Co Ltd v Ex-Cell-O Corp (England) Ltd]].--[[User:Jack Upland|Jack Upland]] ([[User talk:Jack Upland|talk]]) 01:19, 19 December 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style#rfc_2F94817|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style]] expired 2020-01-18 02:01 ===
* Id: 2F94817
* User: DESiegel
* Date: 2019-12-29 00:01:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|932927856|STYLE 932927856}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|933021296|POLICY 933021296}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|933021300|TECH 933021300}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|937912539|STYLE 937912539}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|937912542|POLICY 937912542}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|937912547|TECH 937912547}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The Cquote template is used in many articles to set off quotes with large quote marks. The MOS says not to use it in articles and the template also contains that instruction.

Thus, rule and practice are not in good alignment. How should we fix this (if we should)? Should the quote marks be removed from those articles that use it by modifying {{tl|Cquote}}? Or should the MOS be changed? 

-- [[User:DESiegel|DES]] [[User talk:DESiegel|<sup>(talk)</sup>]][[Special:Contributions/DESiegel|<sub>DESiegel Contribs</sub>]] 00:01, 29 December 2019 (UTC)}}


=== [[Talk:Chairperson#rfc_55D424A|Talk:Chairperson]] expired 2020-01-18 02:01 ===
* Id: 55D424A
* Date: 2019-12-19 01:35:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|931467524|STYLE 931467524}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|936321305|STYLE 936321305}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I was the nom of the RM that resulted in moving this article from Chairman to Chairperson ([[Talk:Chairperson/Archive_4]]). I'm also aware that prior to that, an attempt to move this article from '''Chairman''' to '''Chair (person)''' did not succeed [[Talk:Chairperson/Archive_3#Requested_move_22_March_2019]], a decision that was contested and  endorsed in move review ([[Wikipedia:Move_review/Log/2019_May#Archive_4]]).

Despite this history, I still think the issue of this title is not yet quite settled, but before we have a hopefully final RM to get that done, I think we need to find consensus about the answer to the following question:

{{big|'''IF'''}} (that's a big "if") this article were to be moved to '''Chair (''disambiguator'')''', what would be the best disambiguator, ''and why''?

# executive
# officer
# person
# presiding officer
# role
# parliamentary procedure
# title
# officeholder
# position

'''''Note''': Let's please keep the discussion in this section focused on the best disambiguator question. In particular, please refrain from opining about any other title (like '''Chairperson''' or '''Chairman''')  being better or worse than any  '''Chair (disambiguator)''' option - that's for another section, or for a future RM.'' 

--[[User:Born2cycle|–í¬≤C]] [[User_talk:Born2cycle#top|‚òé]] 01:35, 19 December 2019 (UTC)}}


=== [[Talk:Minimum wage#rfc_9051646|Talk:Minimum wage]] expired 2020-01-18 16:01 ===
* Id: 9051646
* User: Squatch347
* Date: 2019-12-19 15:12:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|931552625|ECON 931552625}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|936395874|ECON 936395874}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There is an ongoing discussion above about several works included on the main page that recieved popular press attention, but were not submitted to academic review, nor published in any journal.  I think ideally we wouldn't include sources of that nature in this article, which is more technical in focus, and would rely on peer-reviewed academic work, specificially peer-reviewed secondary sources per [[WP:SCHOLARSHIP]]. But at a minimum, we need to include language clarifying that these works recieved no academic review and have recieved some criticism from economists. 

However, another editor has argued that retention for retention of the source, arguing that it meets [[WP:RS]] guidelines, and does not want any hedging language included for fear of not presenting [[WP:NPOV]]. 

I'd like to request comments on whether inclusion of this type of work is warranted here, and what the best language to include might be to clarify its relative standing with other academic works a la [[WP:SCHOLARSHIP]].
[[User:Squatch347|Squatch347]] ([[User talk:Squatch347|talk]]) 15:12, 19 December 2019 (UTC)}}

*'''Option 3:''' Generally [[WP:QUESTIONABLE|unreliable]] for factual reporting

=== [[Talk:Efforts to impeach Donald Trump#rfc_BFC2482|Talk:Efforts to impeach Donald Trump]] expired 2020-01-24 20:01 ===
* Id: BFC2482
* User: StanTheMan0131
* Date: 2019-12-25 19:25:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|932419932|POL 932419932}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|937401794|POL 937401794}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 Under the [[Efforts_to_impeach_Donald_Trump#Commentary_and_opinion|4th Section]] of this article, Commentary & Opinion, there is a subsection titled 'Statements by Democrats'. There is no other subsection for any other political party (i.e. Libertarian, Republican, etc.) I propose we either wipe the 'Statements by Democrats' section completely, or we add more titles to include ALL political parties in the United States:

- Statements by Republicans
- Statements by Libertarians
- Statements by Green Party
- Statements by Constitution Party

All encyclopedic content on Wikipedia must be written from a neutral point of view (NPOV), which means representing fairly, proportionately, and, as far as possible, without editorial bias, all of the significant views that have been published by reliable sources on a topic. --[[User:StanTheMan0131|StanTheMan0131]] ([[User talk:StanTheMan0131|talk]]) 19:25, 25 December 2019 (UTC)}}

Which option best describes The New Republic?

*'''Option 1:''' Generally [[WP:RS|reliable]] for factual reporting
*'''Option 2:''' Unclear or additional considerations apply

*'''Option 4:''' Publishes false or fabricated information, and should be [[WP:DEPS|deprecated]]

=== [[Talk:Gas van#rfc_ED63441|Talk:Gas van]] expired 2020-01-25 19:01 ===
* Id: ED63441
* User: My very best wishes
* Date: 2019-12-26 18:54:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|932548849|HIST 932548849}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|932548852|POL 932548852}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|937549711|HIST 937549711}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|937549714|POL 937549714}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should content sourced to books by [[Petro Grigorenko]] and [[:ru:–®—Ä–µ–π–¥–µ—Ä, –ú–∏—Ö–∞–∏–ª –ü–∞–≤–ª–æ–≤–∏—á|Mikhail Schreider]] be included to this page, <u>with explicit attribution to the authors</u>, as something similar to last paragraph in [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Gas_van&oldid=932467581#Soviet_Union this section]? The book by the [[Soviet dissident]] Grigorenko ("One can meet only rats in the underground") was the first of many publications which revealed, among many other things, the existence of Soviet gas vans in 1930s. The book was published in 1981 in New York in Russian, translated to English as "Memoirs" and received many positive reviews: [https://www.jstor.org/stable/2150260?origin=crossref&seq=1#metadata_info_tab_contents], [https://www.jstor.org/stable/20041606?origin=crossref&seq=1#metadata_info_tab_contents][https://www.zeit.de/1982/22/der-hauptheld-ist-die-wahrheit],[https://www.jstor.org/stable/41036232?seq=1#metadata_info_tab_contents]. Here is some info about Schredier [https://books.google.com/books?id=sge44FaZDREC&pg=PA283&lpg=PA283&dq=mikhail+Shreider&source=bl&ots=rpy8ftSf_h&sig=ACfU3U0USNjxT_reUL-f-gjoloG1JECTBg&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwiKruic46blAhWYvJ4KHU61C1oQ6AEwBHoECAgQAQ#v=onepage&q=mikhail%20Shreider&f=false]. [[User:My very best wishes|My very best wishes]] ([[User talk:My very best wishes|talk]]) 18:54, 26 December 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Illegal immigration to the United States#rfc_45B01A4|Talk:Illegal immigration to the United States]] expired 2020-01-25 20:01 ===
* Id: 45B01A4
* User: Edit5001
* Date: 2019-12-26 19:11:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|932714735|POL 932714735}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|937558141|POL 937558141}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the lead mention opinion polls regarding US citizen's opinions towards illegal immigration? There is currently debate on whether the lead should including the following sentence; "[[Illegal immigration]] has been a matter of intense debate in the United States since the 1980s, and opinion polls show a majority of Americans either oppose illegal immigration or view it as a problem." Sources for these polls/surveys include (but don't have to be limited to) [https://www.rasmussenreports.com/public_content/politics/current_events/immigration/july_2019/voters_still_worry_about_illegal_immigration_but_are_divided_by_the_wall Rasmussen polls], [https://www.opportunityagenda.org/explore/resources-publications/synthesis-research-findings-public-opinion-immigration Opportunity Agenda immigration attitudes surveys] and [https://www.migrationpolicy.org/research/americas-views-immigration-evidence-public-opinion-surveys Migration Policy Institute research]. === [[Talk:Oswestry#rfc_D6DEFD0|Talk:Oswestry]] expired 2020-01-27 01:01 ===
* Id: D6DEFD0
* User: Llemiles
* Date: 2019-12-28 00:58:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|932697850|LANG 932697850}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|932697853|STYLE 932697853}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|932697854|POLICY 932697854}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|937747922|LANG 937747922}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|937747929|STYLE 937747929}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|937747934|POLICY 937747934}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 '''For this article, should the introduction include the translated name <del>Caer Ogyrfan</del>{{lang-cy|Croesoswallt }}?'''

There has been a long dispute here raised by some who feel <del>Caer Ogyrfan</del>. "{{lang-cy|Croesoswallt}}" (the Welsh name for Oswestry) should not be used in the introduction. Among registered users I believe there is a consensus for including the Welsh name, however the arguments go back to 2010 and the matter has not been settled formally.

Pinging to previously interested editors {{reply to|Hoary}} {{reply to|Kentynet}} {{reply to|Shropshire70}} {{reply to|DrFrench}} {{reply to|Skinmeister}} {{reply to|Ehrenkater}} {{reply to|Cosnahang}}

You may wish to respond below with voting ‚Ä¢ For or ‚Ä¢ Against. Please be respectful, assume [[WP:GOODFAITH]], and remember this is [[WP:NOTVOTE]] but a way to find a consensus.

[[User:Llemiles|Llemiles]] ([[User talk:Llemiles|talk]]) 00:58, 28 December 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Template messages/Cleanup#rfc_4ECB71C|Wikipedia talk:Template messages/Cleanup]] expired 2020-01-28 19:01 ===
* Id: 4ECB71C
* User: SUM1
* Date: 2019-12-29 18:48:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|933057532|TECH 933057532}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|938033760|TECH 938033760}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
[[Template:More citations needed]] and [[Template:Citations needed]] have had automatic, [[Template:DATE|substituted dates]] for years. You just insert the template and that's it, no need to add or paste anything manually. It looks like this:

{{Quote|text='''Month and year'''<br><nowiki>{{subst:CURRENTMONTHNAME}}</nowiki><br><nowiki>{{subst:CURRENTYEAR}}</nowiki>|sign=|source=}}

But all (or most) other [[cleanup templates]], like [[Template:Tone]], [[Template:POV]], [[Template:Cleanup reorganize]], etc. seem to lack this feature for some unexplained reason (or just due to lack of attention to the issue). I'm aware that some bot is supposed to go around and do this job (of adding missing dates), but I've seen numerous cleanup templates without dates, and there seems to be no good reason why [[Template:More citations needed]] and [[Template:Citations needed]] have this feature but other cleanup templates don't. I've looked at the template date source codes, but they seemed to be the same. If those templates can have that feature, why not lift that reliance on the bot for all the templates?

Should automatic date substitutions be added to all cleanup templates? [[User:SUM1|SUM1]] ([[User talk:SUM1|talk]]) 18:48, 29 December 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/China and Chinese-related articles#rfc_60B7BF6|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/China and Chinese-related articles]] expired 2020-01-28 20:01 ===
* Id: 60B7BF6
* User: WhisperToMe
* Date: 2019-12-29 19:04:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|933066453|LANG 933066453}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|938043402|LANG 938043402}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
{{ping|Geographyinitiative}}
The question is whether the [[Traditional Chinese]] or [[Simplified Chinese]] forms of [[Standard Mandarin]] count as the same name or as different names in regards to names of places or people. This determines whether both forms should be displayed in the [[Template:Chinese]] infobox, or whether only one or the other should. For example, would a simplified Chinese form of a name of a person in the Republic of China like leader [[Chiang Kai-shek]] be considered a "foreign language name" and therefore excluded from the template ([https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Chiang_Kai-shek&diff=916941725&oldid=916332404&diffmode=source see reasoning in this edit])?

(for people unfamiliar with Chinese history, the [[Republic of China]] controlled the Mainland until 1949, then moved to Taiwan, while Simplified Chinese was introduced in Mainland China by the [[People's Republic of China]] after that; Chiang never changed his allegiance from the ROC and remained on Taiwan)

This may affect multiple articles, including historical Chinese figures who lived before the advent of simplified Chinese characters so I believe it is necessary to do the RFC here.

For further info see:
* [[Wikipedia_talk:Manual_of_Style/China_and_Chinese-related_articles#Should_the_Chinese_infobox_display_both_Simplified_and_Traditional_Chinese_for_all_Greater_China_and/or_Sinosphere-related_subjects,_or_should_it_only_display_the_relevant_ones_per_territory/area?]] (previous discussion on whether articles related to Chinese should have both Traditional or Simplified forms)
* [[Talk:Chiang_Kai-shek#Simplified_character_names]] (discussion which triggered this particular RFC)

Pinging those involved in the first discussion and other interested parties:
* {{ping|Kdm852}} {{ping|Szqecs}} {{ping|Wefk423}} {{ping|White whirlwind}} {{ping|JohnBlackburne}} {{ping|Simonm223}} {{ping|Zanhe}} {{ping|Hayman30}} {{ping|Kusma}}
[[User:WhisperToMe|WhisperToMe]] ([[User talk:WhisperToMe|talk]]) 19:04, 29 December 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)#rfc_40BC9F3|Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)]] expired 2020-01-31 09:01 ===
* Id: 40BC9F3
* Date: 2020-01-27 07:30:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|937797906|POLICY 937797906}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|937797910|PROP 937797910}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|938456971|POLICY 938456971}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|938456973|PROP 938456973}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The [[Wikipedia:Wikipedia Signpost/2020-01-27/From the editor|January 27 ''Signpost'' "From the editor" column]] describes the several years-long and ongoing paid advocacy abuse by [[Status Labs]] (formerly Wiki-PR), including their community ban from the English Wikipedia, their global ban imposed by the Foundation, a [https://blog.wikimedia.org/2013/11/19/wikimedia-foundation-sends-cease-and-desist-letter-to-wikipr/ cease-and-desist letter sent in 2013], and [https://www.wsj.com/articles/how-the-1-scrubs-its-image-online-11576233000 six recent and ongoing paid advocacy abuses reported by the ''Wall Street Journal'' last month]. Foundation officials told the ''Signpost'' that they would only take further action if the English Wikipedia community requests such "through its usual governing processes." Accordingly, this RFC asks the Wikimedia Foundation to enforce the Terms of Use against Status Labs violations, such as by reporting infringement of the [[Computer Fraud and Abuse Act]], seeking civil penalties for those violations, and any other actions which the Foundation's attorneys believe will most likely halt the ongoing abuses. 07:30, 27 January 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Refactoring talk pages#rfc_961DEF0|Wikipedia talk:Refactoring talk pages]] expired 2020-02-01 01:01 ===

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Hello! [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wikipedia%3ARefactoring_talk_pages&type=revision&diff=929450979&oldid=929449926 In this change], I had added text to this page which listed fixing [[WP:Link rot|dead links]] in other peoples comments ([https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=User%3ATheAwesomeHwyh&type=revision&diff=933602368&oldid=933602179 see example]). However, the change was based only on what was [[Help:Archiving a talk page#Choosing_a_bot._Table_comparing_the_2_main_bots|implied in a table on a mostly unrelated page]].  That is why I ask whether it is appropriate to change other people's talkpage comments so to fix dead links. Please vote '''yes''' or '''no''' below. {{rfcquote|text=
Putting an RfC tag on this (with a 1-2-3 question format) since the discussion above is dwindling but without clear resolution.

'''Should our guidelines:'''
# '''advise not using {{para|nationality}} or {{para|citizenship}} when the country would match that found in {{para|birthplace}}''';
# '''advise filling in at least one of {{para|nationality}} or {{para|citizenship}} even if the country would match that found in {{para|birthplace}}''';
# '''remain silent on the matter''';
# '''advise filling in {{para|nationality}} or {{para|citizenship}}, even if the same, when it cannot be automatically inferred from birthplace''' <small>(i.e., for any country not listed at [[Jus soli#Unrestricted jus soli]], for modern subjects)</small>?
The original post opening the discussion is above (and was in turn a followup to discussion at [[Template talk:Infobox person]] and [[User talk:MB]]).  PS: I think the material in question (under version 1 or version 2) belongs in [[MOS:BIO]] rather than [[MOS:INFOBOX]], because it is bio-specific and doesn't pertain to infoboxes in general. === [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Sports#rfc_832BDB4|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Sports]] expired 2020-02-03 07:01 ===
* Id: 832BDB4
* User: BattleshipMan
* Date: 2020-01-04 06:14:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|934114400|SOC 934114400}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|938931357|SOC 938931357}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
For the purpose of gaining WikiProject consensus, I'm starting a discussion regarding a proposal about whatever or not we should have templates for NHL teams that won the [[Stanley Cup]] with the list of players and coaches who won the championship in their respective seasons. We got templates for Super Bowl winning NFL teams, NBA teams who won the NBA Finals and MLB teams who won the World Series. Plus, we got a template for the hockey players who won the [[Triple Gold Club]]. For those reasons, it is possible to have templates for NHL teams who won the Stanley Cup. 

'''Discussion'''

The discussion of this proposal are about putting in navbox templates for NHL teams who won the Stanley Cup in their respective seasons, like the ones we have in teams who won the Super Bowl, NBA Finals and the World Series. Option 1 is '''Support''' for inclusion of the templates. Option 2 is '''Oppose''' of not having them. '''Neutral''' is for those who are indecisive. Please state your comments about the proposal of having navigation boxes of NHL teams who won the Stanley Cup in their Stanley Cup winning seasons. [[User:BattleshipMan|BattleshipMan]] ([[User talk:BattleshipMan|talk]]) 06:14, 4 January 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:WikiLeaks#rfc_F8981F3|Talk:WikiLeaks]] expired 2020-02-04 13:01 ===
* Id: F8981F3
* User: Burrobert
* Date: 2020-01-05 12:31:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|934236834|POL 934236834}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|934236836|SOC 934236836}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|939115818|POL 939115818}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|939115820|SOC 939115820}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the following text be added to the Wikileaks page:

 In 2019 Wikileaks released documents related to the 2018 Douma chemical attack. [[Robert Fisk]] said that documents released by Wikileaks indicate that the [[Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons]] "suppressed or failed to publish, or simply preferred to ignore, the conclusions of up to 20 other members of its staff who became so upset at what they regarded as the misleading conclusions of the final report that they officially sought to have it changed in order to represent the truth".<ref name="independent020120">{{cite news |last1=Fisk |first1=Robert |title=The Syrian conflict is awash with propaganda ‚Äì chemical warfare bodies should not be caught up in it |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/syria-war-chemical-weapons-watchdog-opcw-assad-damascus-russia-a9262336.html |accessdate=3 January 2020 |publisher=The Independent |date=2 January 2020}}</ref>
 In a meeting held by the OPCW on 6 June 2018 involving toxicologists and pharmacists who were specialists in [[Chemical warfare]], the experts concluded  that there was "no correlation between symptoms [of the victims] and chlorine exposure" and that "the onset of excessive frothing, as a result of pulmonary edema observed in photos and reported by witnesses would not occur in the short time period between the reported occurrence of the alleged incident and the time the videos were recorded".<ref name="independent020120" />
 An email dated 22 June 2018 from an OPCW whistleblower states that the OPCW report "seriously misrepresents" the facts and distorts "crucial facts".<ref>{{cite news |last1=Morley |first1=Jefferson |title=Why the Douma Chemical Attack Wasn‚Äôt a ‚ÄòManaged Massacre‚Äô |url=https://www.counterpunch.org/2019/12/06/why-the-douma-chemical-attack-wasnt-a-managed-massacre/ |accessdate=3 January 2020 |publisher=Counter Punch |date=6 December 2019 |ref=cp061219}}</ref>

[[User:Burrobert|Burrobert]] ([[User talk:Burrobert|talk]]) 12:31, 5 January 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_A8431D4|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2020-02-05 04:01 ===
* Id: A8431D4
* User: Adamant1
* Date: 2020-01-23 04:44:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|937204295|ECON 937204295}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|937204301|POLICY 937204301}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|939227770|ECON 939227770}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|939227774|POLICY 939227774}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Does a restaurant having a [[Michelin star]] rating, especially if its the only source, make the restaurant notable? I know the notability guidelines say top 100 and similar lists are not reliable sources, but I'm not sure if Michelin ratings would fit into that or not. The star rating system doesn't seem to give a detailed review of the restaurant receiving the rating. So I think that should disqualify it automatically, but even if there was details I don't think it would be a reliable source on its own or even with other better sources backing it up. I ask because I requested an article for the restaurant [['t Brouwerskolkje]] be deleted due to lack of notability, but two people said the restaurant having a Michelin star rating was enough to keep the article. Although, the article lacks any other reliable sources. Let alone broad coverage. --[[User:Adamant1|Adamant1]] ([[User talk:Adamant1|talk]]) 04:44, 23 January 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Tulsi Gabbard#rfc_6F3D4B4|Talk:Tulsi Gabbard]] expired 2020-02-05 14:01 ===
* Id: 6F3D4B4
* User: Humanengr
* Date: 2020-01-07 22:42:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|934689643|BIO 934689643}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|934689649|POL 934689649}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|939514643|BIO 939514643}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|939514651|POL 939514651}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
When the previous [[#RFC on Science of Identity Foundation|RFC]] on whether there should be mention of the [[Science of Identity Foundation|SIF]] in Gabbard's BLP was closed, the closer stated there was a majority in favor of 'yes' but noted: "A few editors objected to the phrasing of the RfC statement, because it does not specify the exact wording that would be used in the article." The closer left the [[Talk:Tulsi Gabbard#Proposed wordings|Proposed wordings]] section open for workshopping of text. That section was not used but some proposed wording was put under a new section that been created for another purpose. To open the matter to broad participation and centralize discussion, this RfC is for workshopping text pertaining to SIF and Gabbard appropriate for her BLP. 

Related material for reference:
* [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#Honolulu Civil Beat|RSN#Honolulu Civil Beat [active]]]
* [[Talk:Tulsi Gabbard#RFC: Should the article include Honolulu Civil Beat's investigation of forum postings about Tulsi Gabbard's involvement with the Science of Identity Foundation?|RFC: Should the article include Honolulu Civil Beat's investigation of forum postings about Tulsi Gabbard's involvement with the Science of Identity Foundation? [active]]]
* [[Talk:Tulsi Gabbard#Proposed wordings|Proposed wordings [old]]]
* [[Talk:Tulsi Gabbard#Workshop for SIF material|Workshop for SIF material [old]]]
[[User:Humanengr|Humanengr]] ([[User talk:Humanengr|talk]]) 22:42, 7 January 2020 (UTC)}}

Since this is a source that's never been discussed before, I'd like some opinions on [[PureM√©dias]]:
*'''Option 1:''' Generally [[WP:RS|reliable]] for factual reporting
*'''Option 2:''' Unclear or additional considerations apply
*'''Option 3:''' Generally [[WP:QUESTIONABLE|unreliable]] for factual reporting
*'''Option 4:''' Publishes false or fabricated information, and should be [[WP:DEPS|deprecated]]

=== [[Talk:Tulsa race riot#rfc_A735371|Talk:Tulsa race riot]] expired 2020-02-08 00:01 ===
* Id: A735371
* User: Waidawut
* Date: 2020-02-07 21:04:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|939663473|HIST 939663473}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|939663475|POL 939663475}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|939663477|SOC 939663477}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|939676911|HIST 939676911}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|939676916|POL 939676916}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|939676920|SOC 939676920}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
[[:Tulsa race riot]] ‚Üí {{no redirect|Tulsa race massacre}} ‚Äì It's now been six months since the full move request discussion from August 8 2019, and many reliable sources are now referring to the event as a Massacre rather than as a Riot.
For example, when searching "site:nytimes.com tulsa race", we can see the latest article the Times has published refers to the event as a massacre: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/05/us/tulsa-race-massacre-mass-grave.html (titled "Nearly 100 Years After Tulsa Massacre, City Plans to Search Cemetery for Victims"). Similarly, "site:washingtonpost.com tulsa race" gives us https://www.washingtonpost.com/history/2020/02/03/tulsa-mass-graves-excavation/ (titled "Tulsa plans to dig for suspected mass graves from a 1921 race massacre"), and "site:npr.org tulsa race" gives us https://www.npr.org/2019/12/17/789015343/new-research-identifies-possible-mass-graves-from1921-tulsa-race-massacre (titled "New Research Identifies Possible Mass Graves From 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre"). NPR also has a transcript of an All Things Considered piece from the same day at https://www.npr.org/2019/12/17/789036767/new-discoveries-open-old-chapter-in-tulsa-race-riots-of-1921 which is titled "New Discoveries Open Old Chapter In Tulsa Race Riots Of 1921," but the transcript of the story itself consistently refers to the event as a Massacre, and does not say Riot.
As these three organizations represent sources of record, I believe that we now have enough support from sources to make this move, and as the waiting period [[User:El_C|El_C]] requested has now ended, this seems like an excellent time to re-open the discussion. CC [[User:Drmies|Drmies]]. [[User:Waidawut|Waidawut]] ([[User talk:Waidawut|talk]]) 21:04, 7 February 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Quillette#rfc_AF15881|Talk:Quillette]] expired 2020-02-09 03:01 ===
* Id: AF15881
* User: Bacondrum
* Date: 2020-01-10 02:06:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|935175105|MEDIA 935175105}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|935175106|POL 935175106}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|935175109|SOC 935175109}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|939849966|MEDIA 939849966}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|939849968|POL 939849968}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|939849969|SOC 939849969}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Based on this discussion regarding claims made in a respected, reliable source at the [[Wikipedia:Reliable_sources/Noticeboard#The_Nation|reliable sources noticeboard]], where uninvolved editors unanimously support the source and the claim (with attribution), I propose adding this to the ideology section (or perhaps the controversy section?):

:In December 2019, [[Donna Minkowitz]] accused Quillette of repeatedly published [[pseudo-scientific]] claims that black people are Intellectually and morally inferior to white people. Minkowitz noted a number of contributors to Quillette are proponents of the [[Human biodiversity|Human Biodiversity]] Movement (HBD), including [[Vdare]] blogger [[Steve Sailer]], Ben Winegard, Bo Winegard, [[Brian Boutwell]], and [[John Paul Wright]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Minkowitz |first1=Donna |title=Why Racists (and Liberals!) Keep Writing for ‚ÄòQuillette‚Äô |url=https://www.thenation.com/article/quillette-fascist-creep/ |website=The Nation |publisher=The Nation Company, L.P |accessdate=6 January 2020}}</ref> 

[[User:Bacondrum|Bacondrum]] ([[User talk:Bacondrum|talk]]) 02:06, 10 January 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_0BBA118|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2020-02-09 04:01 ===
* Id: 0BBA118
* User: Mariogoods
* Date: 2020-01-30 05:20:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|938282530|POL 938282530}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|938282533|SOC 938282533}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|939856926|POL 939856926}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|939856930|SOC 939856930}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Here is the website: https://www.guancha.cn/ It is a Chinese source, and I raised the discussion because I noticed is has been used in topics such as [[Zhang Weiwei]], [[Arab Winter]] (Chinese professor Zhang Weiwei first..) and [[2019‚Äì20 Wuhan coronavirus outbreak]]. The discussion is not about Fengwen part of the website since it is user-generated, the discussion is about the news and comment part of the website. I believed the website is a questionable source at least in politic since it may be highly promotional of Chinese nationalism. If we needs to cite official statement, government websites and state-run media are more realiable. If we needs to cite nationalism content, Global Times may be more realiable. And how should we treat contents in guancha.cn that are or are not much related to politics? 
*'''Option 1:''' Generally [[WP:RS|reliable]] for factual reporting
*'''Option 2:''' Unclear or additional considerations apply
*'''Option 3:''' Generally [[WP:QUESTIONABLE|unreliable]] for factual reporting
*'''Option 4:''' Publishes false or fabricated information, and should be [[WP:DEPS|deprecated]]
[[User:Mariogoods|Mariogoods]] ([[User talk:Mariogoods|talk]]) 05:20, 30 January 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019#rfc_8C86BE2|Talk:Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019]] expired 2020-02-10 12:01 ===
* Id: 8C86BE2
* Date: 2020-01-11 11:23:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|935240744|POL 935240744}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|940079069|POL 940079069}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the second line of the lead of the article be modified from:

 It amended the Citizenship Act of 1955 by providing a path to Indian citizenship for Hindu, Sikh, Buddhist, Jain, Parsi, and Christian religious minorities that had fled persecution from Pakistan, Bangladesh and Afghanistan before December 2014 [https://pib.gov.in/newsite/PrintRelease.aspx?relid=195783 pib.gov.in]

to:

 It amended the Citizenship Act of 1955 by providing a path to Indian citizenship for Hindu, Sikh, Buddhist, Jain, Parsi, and Christian religious minorities that had fled persecution from Pakistan, Bangladesh and Afghanistan before December 2014 {{hl|''<big>and who have been exempted by the Central Government under the Passport (Entry into India) Act, 1920 or the Foreigners Act, 1946 [https://www.scconline.com/blog/post/2019/12/11/live-citizenship-amendment-bill-2019-tabled-in-rajya-sabha/ scconline.com]</big>''}}

Please choose from the Options listed below in the `Survey` section and also give your reasons and comments in the `Threaded discussion` below.

11:23, 11 January 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Albums#rfc_8B6183E|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Albums]] expired 2020-02-11 15:01 ===
* Id: 8B6183E
* User: Ojorojo
* Date: 2020-01-15 15:51:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|935921711|MEDIA 935921711}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|940270617|MEDIA 940270617}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
[Continued from "Executive producers" section above]

The current practice for most album articles is to include all the producers credited in the album liner notes or other reliable sources. The template guidance indicates: "Enter the name of the person(s) credited with the '''[[record producer|record production]]'''. This is someone who oversees the recording process and is usually different from the artist or songwriter. For multiple entries, see Notes[instructions for using class=hlist] for details." While historically albums list one to three producers, it has become more common for albums to have different producers for each song or producers who play a limited role. Sometimes this results in a long entry of 20‚Äì30 names in the album infobox producer(s)= field. Additionally, the list may include persons who only produced one or two tracks (not the album) or whose role doesn't involve actual music production (such as in some executive capacity). 

To best represent the article, should the infobox list of producers be limited in some way? Please indicate '''Limit''', '''Unlimited''', or '''Comment''' and an explanation. ‚Äî[[User:Ojorojo|Ojorojo]] ([[User talk:Ojorojo|talk]]) 15:51, 15 January 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Round the Horne#rfc_4BEE136|Talk:Round the Horne]] expired 2020-02-11 19:01 ===
* Id: 4BEE136
* User: Jcejhay
* Date: 2020-02-11 17:29:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|940294538|POLICY 940294538}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|940302681|POLICY 940302681}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Is it appropriate for one party to a two-party disagreement to give themselves the last word and unilaterally close the discussion (re. "James Bond spoofs")? I would have thought that determining that a discussion needed to be closed would fall to an editor watching from the sidelines, someone without a stake in the disagreement. Whereas, if you're one of two people in a dispute and you don't want to continue it, all you have to do is stop commenting. [[User:Jcejhay|Jcejhay]] ([[User talk:Jcejhay|talk]]) 17:29, 11 February 2020 (UTC)}}

For the article's "Background" section, which wording is preferable?
* '''A''': In May 1967, the Beatles album ''[[Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band]]'' was released to commercial and critical success. It sold 250,000 copies in its first week and topped the UK charts for 27 weeks, through to the start of February 1968.
* '''B''':  By 1968, the Beatles had achieved commercial and critical success. The group's mid-1967 release, ''Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band'', was number one in the UK for 27 weeks, through to the start of February 1968, having sold 250,000 copies in the first week after release.

=== [[Template talk:Infobox song#rfc_31C1263|Template talk:Infobox song]] expired 2020-02-15 10:01 ===
* Id: 31C1263
* User: Aria1561
* Date: 2020-02-15 04:43:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|940877568|MEDIA 940877568}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|940902229|MEDIA 940902229}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
All downloads are digital by nature, therefore the word "digital" doesn't need to be included when downloads are mentioned in an article or infobox. It's as simple as that. Using it would be as ridiculous as using "digital streaming" instead of simply "streaming" in the infobox. I've been told that this is the "widely accepted" way of noting a download format in the infobox, which in turn means that we're promoting redundancies, which I ''thought'' was something we try to avoid when editing Wikipedia. Pinging {{ping|Gagaluv1}} and {{ping|MarioSoulTruthFan}} as I have been involved in edit exchanges with them both over this issue. I think it's time for a change here. [[User:Aria1561|Aria1561]] ([[User talk:Aria1561|talk]]) 04:43, 15 February 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Grace VanderWaal#rfc_A20FFDF|Talk:Grace VanderWaal]] expired 2020-02-15 22:01 ===
* Id: A20FFDF
* User: Anastrophe
* Date: 2020-02-05 19:19:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|939328660|BIO 939328660}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|940983782|BIO 940983782}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The following line is in dispute for inclusion in the article:

"In its 2019 profile of VanderWaal, ''Forbes'' stated that she had accumulated 8 million followers on social media.<ref>[https://www.forbes.com/profile/grace-vanderwaal "Grace VanderWaal"], ''Forbes'' 2019</ref> As of 2020, VanderWaal's Instagram account has more than 3 million followers,<ref>VanderWaal, Grace. [https://www.instagram.com/gracevanderwaal "gracevanderwaal"], [[Instagram]]. Retrieved December 12, 2018</ref> her YouTube channel has more than 3 million subscribers,<ref>VanderWaal, Grace. [https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC2qc1KM4zgRoOpysqVEaNbw "Oh Never Mind It's Just Me ‚Äì Grace VanderWaal"], YouTube. Retrieved December 12, 2018</ref> and her Facebook page has more than 1 million followers.<ref>VanderWaal, Grace. [https://www.facebook.com/GraceVanderWaalMusic "Grace VanderWaal"], Facebook. Retrieved March 30, 2018</ref>"
{{reftalk}}

* The arguments for exclusion are violation of [[WP:BLP]] (because the material is disputed), [[WP:NOT]] (an indiscriminate collection of information), [[WP:FANCRUFT]] (only relevant to fans) and [[WP:POV]] (I'm unable to find the rationale for this last). [[WP:BLPREQUESTRESTORE]] has been cited as rationale for exclusion, absent consensus on the suitability of the material.
* The arguments for inclusion are that it it does not violate [[WP:BLP]], is not excessive to the point of triggering [[WP:NOT]] for the BLP of an actively engaged and followed media personality, is not [[WP:FANCRUFT]] (for the same reason), and [[WP:BLPREQUESTRESTORE]] is a guideline for admins, not editors so isn't a trigger until admin intervention. 

Should this material be included or excluded from the article? [[User:Anastrophe|Anastrophe]] ([[User talk:Anastrophe|talk]]) 19:19, 5 February 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Equinox#rfc_347FC4E|Talk:Equinox]] expired 2020-02-16 12:01 ===
* Id: 347FC4E
* User: Shhhnotsoloud
* Date: 2020-02-16 09:43:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|941056760|HIST 941056760}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|941056763|SCI 941056763}}

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|941069041|SCI 941069041}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should session-specific redirects (e.g. "Spring Equinox") which are not further disambiguated (e.g. "Autumn equinox (northern hemisphere)):
:'''(a)''' target [[Equinox]], or 
:'''(b)''' use a northern hemisphere perspective, so target either [[March equinox]] or [[September equinox]], or
:'''(c)''' target a disambiguation page 
The details can be worked out: this is a question of principle. Please state a preference for '''(a)''', '''(b)''' or '''(c).  [[User:Shhhnotsoloud|Shhhnotsoloud]] ([[User talk:Shhhnotsoloud|talk]]) 09:43, 16 February 2020 (UTC)}}

I have provided the four main paths, discussed at length above, to resolve the naming dispute regarding this article. Please comment under each topic below about how we should move forward.

* 1) Merge this article into [[Libertarianism]] 
* 2) Merge [[Left-libertarianism]] and [[Right-libertarianism]] 
* 3) Reduce [[Right-libertarianism]] to a disambiguation page about the term 
* 4) Rename this article [[Libertarian]] and rework it to reflect the typology

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I have requested this article be split into two separate articles. One regarding the Anti-NATO group of deputies in the second Russian State Duma, and the other about general opposition to NATO globally, as one is a group specific to one country, the other is a global school of thought/ideology.

Most of the first paragraph could be put into the article about the Russian State Duma, the rest is relevant to general opposition to NATO. We probably need more information on the State Duma group, as I‚Äôm not sure whether or not it meets notability criteria for a Wikipedia article. [[User:Helper201|Helper201]] ([[User talk:Helper201|talk]]) 17:51, 20 January 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Boris Johnson#rfc_28B4790|Talk:Boris Johnson]] expired 2020-02-21 16:01 ===
* Id: 28B4790
* User: CityPride
* Date: 2020-02-19 13:45:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|941588471|BIO 941588471}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|941942101|BIO 941942101}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 I propose that we begin to number Prime Ministers by tenure, and not by person, hence Boris Johnson would be the 77th PM (and not the 55th); for more information on the differences, please view [[List of prime ministers of the United Kingdom by tenure start]].

I propose this with the following reasons:

:1) It is widely accepted that Robert Walpole is the first PM - he is listed as such on the UK Governments official website<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.gov.uk/government/history/past-prime-ministers}}</ref> and on our own Wikipedia page for the UK Prime Minister. 

:2) It is also widely accepted that BJ is the 77th Prime Minister - again, this is backed up by the official UK Government website and our own Wikipedia pages. 

:3) A quick Google search reveals that multiple mainstream media reports Boris Johnson as the 77th PM, and Theresa May the 76th, David Cameron the 75th, and so on - further reinforcing the numbering system as accurate and widely accepted, and the fact that people do refer to PM's by their tenure number.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/boris-johnson-set-assume-office-britain-s-77th-prime-minister-n1033281}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://theweek.com/speedreads/635741/theresa-may-becomes-britains-76th-prime-minister}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2016/07/13/brexit-overshadow-david-camerons-legacy/87020394/}}</ref>

:4) Numbering is not exclusive to the USA, as previously suggested - looking at other countries, such as Singapore, New Zealand, and Australia, they all number their PMs. 

:5) Numbering leaders would give much more clarity as to the chronological order of the Prime Ministers tenure when viewing their respective pages, without having to consult the full list.

[[User:CityPride|CityPride]] ([[User talk:CityPride|talk]]) 13:45, 19 February 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:List of music considered the worst#rfc_E837ECE|Talk:List of music considered the worst]] expired 2020-02-21 19:01 ===
* Id: E837ECE
* User: The Grand Delusion
* Date: 2020-01-22 18:45:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|937065130|MEDIA 937065130}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|941965995|MEDIA 941965995}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I feel that we should probably change the name of the article from '''List of music considered the worst''' to '''List of music notable for negative reception'''. As it currently stands, the article's criteria for inclusion only allows music that has been explicitly considered "the worst ever" by reliable sources, and thus is too confining. The proposed name change would allow more flexibility in listing critically-lambasted music. Thoughts? [[User:The Grand Delusion|<span style="color:#6600ff;">The</span> <span style="color:#6666ff;">Grand</span> <span style="color:#6699ff;">Delusion</span>]]<sup>([[User talk:The Grand Delusion|Send a message]])</sup> 18:45, 22 January 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Hospitalized cases in the vaping lung illness outbreak#rfc_D6D721A|Talk:Hospitalized cases in the vaping lung illness outbreak]] expired 2020-02-21 22:01 ===
* Id: D6D721A
* User: Beland
* Date: 2020-02-03 19:55:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|939011017|BIO 939011017}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|939011019|SCI 939011019}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|941989838|BIO 941989838}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|941989841|SCI 941989841}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the inclusion criteria for Wikipedia coverage hospitalized cases in the vaping lung illness outbreak be limited to notable cases? This would exclude most individual cases that receive press coverage from reliable sources simply because they are a patient that is part of the outbreak. We would provide (as we already do at [[2019‚Äì20 vaping lung illness outbreak]]) statistics instead and general information like symptoms, treatment, complications, etc. Notable cases might include people who have a Wikipedia biography, or those who are notable in the course of the outbreak, such as being the only case in a particular country, filing a class-action lawsuit, being the first recognized case, or having contributed in an unusual way to medical knowledge about the condition. -- [[User:Beland|Beland]] ([[User talk:Beland|talk]]) 19:55, 3 February 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#rfc_85FCE9B|Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)]] expired 2020-02-22 00:01 ===
* Id: 85FCE9B
* User: Fastily
* Date: 2020-01-22 23:36:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|937104907|POLICY 937104907}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|942002987|POLICY 942002987}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Hi folks.  Not to specifically call anyone out, but I have noticed that some editors are wholesale blanking userspace sandboxes of established, but inactive editors, citing guideline [[WP:STALEDRAFT]], #2.  This is a bad practice IMO.  Not only is it a nuisance for inactive editors for when they return, but also it encourages unhelpful busy work amongst active editors.

So my question is as follows:  '''Is it acceptable to blank userspace sandboxes of long-term/established, but inactive editors?''' -[[User talk:Fastily|<span style="font-family:'Trebuchet MS';color:Indigo;font-weight:bold;"><span style="font-size:120%;">F</span><span style="font-size:90%;">ASTILY</span></span>]] 23:36, 22 January 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:2020 Iowa Democratic caucuses#rfc_8EC9FB6|Talk:2020 Iowa Democratic caucuses]] expired 2020-02-22 21:01 ===
* Id: 8EC9FB6
* User: Xenagoras
* Date: 2020-02-13 21:23:00
