** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|940662810|POL 940662810}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|942138043|POL 942138043}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Proposal for change to infobox for caucus results:
# Shall the infobox for a caucus display the ''first alignment'' vote count and percentage as the <s>''popular vote''</s> "''First alignment (popular vote)''"?
# Shall the infobox for a caucus display the ''final alignment'' vote count and percentage below the line of the <s>''popular vote''</s> "''First alignment (popular vote)''"? (together with a mouse-over hint explaining: "supporters of candidates below 15% per precinct realigned themselves to other candidates")

Several reliable sources say that first alignment is the popular vote (see details below). These two proposals would result in an infobox display like [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2020_Iowa_Democratic_caucuses&oldid=940495487 this]. 

'''Edit 20 February''': changed proposed text from "''popular vote''" to "''First alignment (popular vote)''" to adapt to editors' comments. [[User:Xenagoras|Xenagoras]] ([[User talk:Xenagoras|talk]]) 21:23, 13 February 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Richard Grenell#rfc_68FCBA8|Talk:Richard Grenell]] expired 2020-02-23 15:01 ===
* Id: 68FCBA8
* User: Datamaster1
* Date: 2020-02-20 16:57:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|941974583|BIO 941974583}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|942247575|BIO 942247575}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
A couple of questions have come up:

* Is a ranking-status member of the cabinet the samething as a member of the cabinet?
* Is a acting ranking member of the cabinet (unconfirmed by the senate) a official member of the cabinet? [[User:Datamaster1|Datamaster1]] ([[User talk:Datamaster1|talk]]) 16:57, 20 February 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Redirects for discussion#rfc_20D1888|Wikipedia talk:Redirects for discussion]] expired 2020-02-23 23:01 ===
* Id: 20D1888
* User: Trialpears
* Date: 2020-01-24 22:12:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|938354410|POLICY 938354410}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|938354414|PROJ 938354414}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|938354418|TECH 938354418}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|942313927|POLICY 942313927}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|942313932|PROJ 942313932}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|942313933|TECH 942313933}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
'''What should be the venue for discussing rcat ([[WP:Redirect categorization]]) templates/categories?'''

This question is prompted by [[Wikipedia:Templates for discussion/Log/2020 January 20#Template:R from meme]] where this question was raised. I personally think it should be at RfD since the audience at RfD will likely be more experienced with redirect categories making them better at making decisions about them then the audiences at TfD or CfD. While this is quite different from RfDs regular content I still believe that they are the most suitable for handling these template with RfDers generally having experience using them. Both TfD and CfD have a reasonable claim since they are templates and they are used for categorizing pages. I will transclude this section at [[WT:RFD]], [[WT:TFD]] and [[WT:CFD]] so all interested parties can participate. ‚Äë‚Äë[[User:Trialpears|Trialpears]] ([[User talk:Trialpears|talk]]) 22:12, 24 January 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Article titles#rfc_BAA4289|Wikipedia talk:Article titles]] expired 2020-02-25 18:01 ===
* Id: BAA4289
* User: Obi2canibe
* Date: 2020-01-26 17:57:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|941132316|POL 941132316}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|941132319|STYLE 941132319}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|942602548|POL 942602548}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|942602551|STYLE 942602551}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There is currently no explicit naming convention for government/cabinet articles. This has led to a lot of inconsistency and inevitably disputes. There are three main inconsistencies - capitalisation, numbering format and syntax.
* Capitalisation - Some editors have taken the view that governments/cabinets aren't [[proper name]]s and have not capitalised (other than where required by [[WP:NCCAPS]]) ([[Fourth Merkel cabinet]], [[Second Johnson ministry]], [[Second Philippe government]]). Others have taken the view that they are proper names and capitalised the full title ([[Second Morrison Ministry]], [[Conte II Cabinet]], [[13th Government of Slovenia]]).
* Numbering format - Variations include full ordinal number ([[Second Modi ministry]]), abbreviated ordinal number ([[29th Canadian Ministry]]) or Roman numbering ([[S√°nchez II Government]]).
* Syntax - There are several combinations including
** ''[Ordinal number] [Head of government] [government/cabinet/ministry]'' ([[Fourth Merkel cabinet]]);
** ''[Ordinal number] [government/cabinet/ministry] of [Head of government]'' ([[Second cabinet of Geir Haarde]]); and
** ''[Head of government] [ordinal number] [government/cabinet/ministry]'' ([[Michel II Government]]).
We really need an explicit naming convention to avoid such inconsistency.--[[Special:Contributions/Obi2canibe|Obi2canibe]] ([[User talk:Obi2canibe|talk)]] 17:57, 26 January 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Catholicism#rfc_2E95F3F|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Catholicism]] expired 2020-02-27 07:01 ===
* Id: 2E95F3F
* User: Elizium23
* Date: 2020-01-28 06:43:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|937955285|RELI 937955285}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|942851288|RELI 942851288}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Per [[MOS:HON]] and [[MOS:SAINTS]] we all know to eschew honorifics such as "Saint" and "Reverend" in the normal course of writing articles, and in infoboxes, etc. However, I see a large variance when it comes to the lede sentence of a biography. What is the consensus here?
#Always omit "Saint" (& "Blessed", "Venerable", etc.) in the lede sentence and everywhere else in the article, except direct discussion of the path to sainthood and canonization.
#Any editor or article may include "Saint" etc. in the lede sentence only, omit in other places as above.
#Editor discretion is to be used. Establish consensus on a single-article basis for or against inclusion. [[User:Elizium23|Elizium23]] ([[User talk:Elizium23|talk]]) 06:43, 28 January 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#rfc_83D60E5|Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)]] expired 2020-02-28 19:01 ===
* Id: 83D60E5
* Date: 2020-02-21 22:24:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|941996619|HIST 941996619}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|941996622|POL 941996622}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|941996626|POLICY 941996626}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|946733219|HIST 946733219}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|946733224|POL 946733224}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|946733230|POLICY 946733230}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
'''Question''': What should the general rule/principle/guideline be for categorizing ''current'' localities by ''historical'' administrative subdivision <u>in Central and Eastern Europe</u>? There are quite a few articles of cities and towns that have been categorized not only in which administrative subdivision they currently are in, but also by the former subdivisions. 

'''Typical example''': [[Ei≈°i≈°kƒós]], a small town in Lithuania, is in these categories: [[:Category:Cities in Lithuania]], [[:Category:Cities in Vilnius County]], [[:Category:≈†alƒçininkai District Municipality]], [[:Category:Vilnius Voivodeship]], [[:Category:Lidsky Uyezd]], [[:Category:Nowogr√≥dek Voivodeship (1919‚Äì1939)]]. The first 3 categories reflect the current administrative subdivision. [[Vilnius Voivodeship]] was a subdivision in 1413‚Äì1795. [[Lidsky Uyezd]] was a 2nd-level subdivision sometime between 1795‚Äì1915. [[Nowogr√≥dek Voivodeship (1919‚Äì1939)]] was an inter-war subdivision.

'''General options''':
*'''A''': categorization should be limited - by what? Whether it is referenced in the article? How long the subdivision lasted? How large the subdivision was? To the 1st-level former subdivision? To how recent subdivision was? Etc?
*'''B''': categorization should not be allowed (i.e. current localities should be removed from the former subdivision categories; historical information could be preserved in a different venue like a separate list or an addition to the locality article or something similar to the "historical affiliation" box as in [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=G%C3%B6rlitz&oldid=939805164#History G√∂rlitz#History]) 
*'''C''': ''status quo''; no general rules; specific issues with individual categories should be addressed at [[WP:CfD]]
22:24, 21 February 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Republican Party (United States)#rfc_D6CFF16|Talk:Republican Party (United States)]] expired 2020-03-02 19:01 ===
* Id: D6CFF16
* User: Snooganssnoogans
* Date: 2020-02-01 18:17:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|938677074|HIST 938677074}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|938677082|POL 938677082}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|943586774|HIST 943586774}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|943586783|POL 943586783}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the lead include mention of the fact that the Republican Party shifted its racial and geographical composition to the South and White Americans after the successes of the Civil Rights movement in the 60s, and that the party appealed to racial conservatism after the passage of the 1964 Civil Rights Act? 

The text in question would summarize the "Composition" section of the body[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)#Composition], and would reflect the contents of more than a dozen peer-reviewed studies on the matter. [[User:Snooganssnoogans|Snooganssnoogans]] ([[User talk:Snooganssnoogans|talk]]) 18:17, 1 February 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Featured article candidates#rfc_D0C4B90|Wikipedia talk:Featured article candidates]] expired 2020-03-02 20:01 ===
* Id: D0C4B90
* User: Mike_Christie
* Date: 2020-03-02 11:43:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|943535946|UNSORTED 943535946}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|943595264|UNSORTED 943595264}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
[[Template:FAC-instructions|FAC instructions]] currently include these sentences, numbered below for reference:

# An editor is allowed to be the sole nominator of only one article at a time, but two nominations may be allowed if the editor is a co-nominator on at least one of them.
# If a nomination is archived, the nominator(s) should take adequate time to work on resolving issues before re-nominating.
# None of the nominators may nominate or co-nominate any article for two weeks unless given leave to do so by a coordinator; if such an article is nominated without asking for leave, a coordinator will decide whether to remove it.
# A coordinator may exempt from this restriction an archived nomination that attracted no (or minimal) feedback.

This RfC proposes three things:

* '''A''': Change sentence 1 to "An editor is allowed to be the sole nominator of only two articles at a time, but three nominations are allowed if the editor is a co-nominator on at least one of them".
* '''B''': Add the following after sentence 1: "At their discretion, the Featured article review coordinators may grant a fourth nomination or co-nomination to editors who actively engage in improving Featured articles in that process".
* '''C''': Modify sentences 3 & 4.  (Note that sentence 3 refers to the nominator(s) of an archived article, per sentence 2.) How to modify them is open for discussion: suggested options are to leave them unchanged; to remove the restriction; or to suggest a different restriction or different wording.

-- [[User:Mike Christie|Mike Christie]] ([[User_talk:Mike Christie|talk]] - [[Special:Contributions/Mike_Christie|contribs]] -  [[User:Mike Christie/Reference library|library]]) 11:43, 2 March 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Ian Smith#rfc_4882276|Talk:Ian Smith]] expired 2020-03-04 11:01 ===
* Id: 4882276
* User: Zubin12
* Date: 2020-02-03 10:33:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|938950213|BIO 938950213}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|938950218|HIST 938950218}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|943876370|BIO 943876370}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|943876374|HIST 943876374}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the following changes [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ian_Smith&diff=938946036&oldid=938945766 Changes] be included in the introduction ?
: As part of an attempt to remedy an unfortunate pro-smith bias in the article which I have elaborated in previous talk-page discussion, I made some changes to the introduction to correct this imbalance. The introduction is emblematic of the way the article is subtly biased with meaningless cruft from an obituary put into prominence " a man of integrity and vision who understood the uncomfortable truths of Africa,{{sfn|BBC|2007}}{{vague|date=December 2019}} while critics describe" which don't mean anything without context regarding what exactly those uncomfortable truths are. Furthermore, the use of the term predominantly implies some level of non-white representation in Rhodesias Goverment but during the UDI there was not a single non-white minister in the government. The figure of only 500 black electors is from the Book State of Africa which is extensively used throughout the article. [[User:Zubin12|Zubin12]] ([[User talk:Zubin12|talk]]) 10:33, 3 February 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Zina Bash#rfc_3DB027E|Talk:Zina Bash]] expired 2020-03-04 14:01 ===
* Id: 3DB027E
* User: Attic Salt
* Date: 2020-02-03 13:55:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|938966612|BIO 938966612}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|957477786|BIO 957477786}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should a short paragraph in the article about [[Zina Bash]] read:

:'''1.''' In September 2018, Bash was accused of making a white power hand sign during Kavanaugh's nomination hearing.[21][22] Her husband condemned the accusations, calling them "repulsive" and a "vicious conspiracy theory".[23][24][25][26][27]

or should it read:

:'''2.''' In September 2018, a conspiracy theory emerged which falsely accused Bash of making a white power hand sign during Kavanaugh's nomination hearing.[21][22] Her husband condemned the accusations, which were debunked by a number of media outlets, calling them "repulsive" and a "vicious conspiracy theory".[23][24][25][26][27]

Thank you, [[User:Attic Salt|Attic Salt]] ([[User talk:Attic Salt|talk]]) 13:55, 3 February 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Carnivore diet#rfc_F338793|Talk:Carnivore diet]] expired 2020-03-04 16:01 ===
* Id: F338793
* User: BecomeFree
* Date: 2020-02-03 15:11:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|938980187|SCI 938980187}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|938980191|SOC 938980191}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|943915334|SCI 943915334}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|943915338|SOC 943915338}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
PKD is a form of [[carnivore diet]] (subject of this article). Clinical researchers in Hungary have been using PKD for 6+ years to try to treat various conditions. They published their [[case reports]] in peer-reviewed journals. Two editors object to its inclusion citing [[WP:MEDASSESS]], however I argue that [[WP:MEDASSESS]] applies only when making factual statements or recommendations in regards to dietary health, which the removed section (see diff[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnivore_diet&diff=938969643&oldid=938967530&diffmode=source] or rendered[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnivore_diet&oldid=938967530#Anecdotes_and_case_studies]) does not. [[User:BecomeFree|BecomeFree]] ([[User talk:BecomeFree|talk]]) 15:11, 3 February 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Iranian Revolution#rfc_4F60B6A|Talk:Iranian Revolution]] expired 2020-03-05 06:01 ===
* Id: 4F60B6A
* Date: 2020-02-14 03:19:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|940712023|HIST 940712023}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|940712029|POL 940712029}}

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The lead sentence currently reads:
{{tq2|The '''Iranian Revolution'''&nbsp;... also known as the '''Islamic Revolution''' or the '''1979 Revolution''', was a series of events that culminated in the overthrow of the last [[List of monarchs of Persia|monarch of Iran]], [[Shah]] [[Mohammad Reza Pahlavi]], and the replacement of his government with an [[Islamic republic]] under the [[Marja'|Grand Ayatollah]] [[Ruhollah Khomeini]], {{highlight|who was supported by the [[United States]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.newsmax.com/larrybell/ayatollah-oil-prices-reagan/2018/02/05/id/841485/|title=Thank Jimmy Carter for Current Iran Mess|last=Bell|first=Larry|date=2018-02-05|website=Newsmax|access-date=2019-12-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/jun/10/ayatollah-khomeini-jimmy-carter-administration-iran-revolution|title=US had extensive contact with Ayatollah Khomeini before Iran revolution|last=Washington|first=Saeed Kamali Dehghan David Smith in|date=2016-06-10|work=The Guardian|access-date=2019-12-31|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-36431160|title=America's secret engagement with Khomeini|last=Fattahi|first=Kambiz|date=3 June 2016|publisher=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=31 December 2019|language=en-GB}}</ref>}} and was a leader of one of the factions in the revolt.}}
{{reflist talk}}

'''RfC questions:'''
#In the lead sentence, should {{tq|q=y|who was supported by the [[United States]]}} be removed?
#In the infobox, should "United States" be removed from the list of the Revolution Council/Interim Government's supporters?
RFC posted: 03:19, 14 February 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Soccer in South Africa#rfc_09E0830|Talk:Soccer in South Africa]] expired 2020-03-06 02:01 ===
* Id: 09E0830
* User: S.A. Julio#top
* Date: 2020-02-05 01:10:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|939213912|LANG 939213912}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|939213919|SOC 939213919}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|939213920|STYLE 939213920}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|944154370|LANG 944154370}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|944154372|SOC 944154372}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|944154375|STYLE 944154375}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should "soccer" or "football" be used in articles related to the sport in South African? Or should the unambiguous term "association football" be used? Ideally, Wikipedia should use consistent wording in South African association football articles per [[MOS:TIES]]. Currently, the wording used is inconsistent across Wikipedia articles, including titles. For example, the national team article is located at [[South Africa national football team]], but the article on the sport in the country is located at [[Soccer in South Africa]]. This inconsistency is also reflected in category/template naming. I have included a list below of all the pages related to South Africa which use "soccer" and "football" in the title. [[User:S.A. Julio|S.A. Julio]] ([[User talk:S.A. Julio#top|talk]]) 01:10, 5 February 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Hong Kong#rfc_C9C9902|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Hong Kong]] expired 2020-03-06 14:01 ===
* Id: C9C9902
* Date: 2020-02-05 13:23:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|939281657|POL 939281657}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|944223128|POL 944223128}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 [[User:Owennson]] has been adding sections to articles on MTR stations listing, in detail, the vandalism inflicted by [[2019‚Äì20 Hong Kong protests|pro-democratic protesters]] at each station, along with images or image galleries showing this vandalism (Examples: [[Wong Tai Sin station]], [[Mong Kok East station]], [[Fanling station]]). So far he/she has systematically added such sections for all stations on the East Rail and Kwun Tong lines, and is now on the Tsuen Wan line, suggesting an intention to add vandalism subsections to ALL MTR station articles.

I have two concerns, related to [[WP:NPOV]] and [[WP:UNDUE]] respectively. Judging by the content of the user's talk page (a passage critical of the U.S. advocating democracy and human rights), I am concerned that the additions to the MTR pages are simply being made to push a political point, e.g. to make pro-democratic protesters look bad. [[WP:NOT|Wikipedia is not a vehicle for political advocacy]]. Secondly, the level of detail provided is beyond excessive. Nearly ALL MTR stations have been subject to vandalism during the protests. We don't need a dedicated subsection for every single MTR station page. The number of images added to illustrate vandalised ticket machines and other fixtures is excessive and needlessly stretches out the pages.

Owennson's counter-argument (on my talk page) is, in essence, that because the [[2019 Yuen Long attack]] and [[2019 Prince Edward station attack]] (e.g. attacks against people carried out by pro-government forces) are covered on Wikipedia, that it would be a double standard not to cover vandalism by pro-democratic protesters. I don't object to mentioning the vandalism within the articles where the vandalism is more serious. But the level of detail currently being given is seriously [[WP:UNDUE]], and I object to these additions being made seemingly just for political purposes. '''[[User:Citobun|Citobun]]''' ([[User_talk:Citobun|talk]]) 13:23, 5 February 2020 (UTC)}}

*the English "[[National Pacification Army]]"
*the pinyin transliteration "[[Anguojun]]"

*the alternative spelling "[[An-kuo-chun]]"

* Id: 399FCE3
* User: Feminist
* Date: 2020-03-08 07:13:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|944508685|POLICY 944508685}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|944508686|PROP 944508686}}

{{rfcquote|text=
[[Wikipedia:2015 administrator election reform/Phase II/RfC|In 2015]], the community agreed to advertise [[WP:RFA|requests for adminship]] on [[MediaWiki:Watchlist-details]] and on [[Template:Centralized discussion]]. Should this be extended to [[WP:RFB|requests for bureaucratship]] as well?

'''Survey'''

*'''Yes'''. Bureaucrats possess greater powers than administrators and require a higher proportion of support for passing. RfB discussions should at least be advertised as much as RfA discussions are. [[User talk:Feminist|feminist]] ([[User talk:Feminist#top|talk]]) 07:13, 8 March 2020 (UTC)}}

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|940430688|POL 940430688}}

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the sentence that it is "{{tq|A Senior State Department Official said that they never said that the MEK was involved in the assassinations of Iranian nuclear scientists}}" be included in the lede? [[User:Saff V.|Saff V.]] ([[User talk:Saff V.|talk]]) 13:27, 12 February 2020 (UTC)}}

* Date: 2020-02-09 08:05:00

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should {{tlx|Supplement}} be deprecated due to the confusion it causes regarding the level of community acceptance (gives a given [[WP:Essays|essay]] more weight?). Essays in question thus should use {{tlx|Information page}} (<small>the banner template for pages that are more just informational and non-opinionated </small>) or {{tlx|Essay|interprets{{=}}}} (t<small>he banner template for pages that are more opinionated then instructional or technical</small>) or  {{tlx|Wikipedia how-to}} (<small>the banner template for pages that are more directly instructional and non-opinionated)</small>. 

<small>See [[#Criteria for use|above for long discussion]]</small>.
;Essays in question...
<small>[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:CategoryTree?target=Category%3AWikipedia+supplemental+pages&mode=all&namespaces=&title=Special%3ACategoryTree ‚Äé Essays taged as "supplemental pages‚Äé" (112 P)]</small>
;Essential reading...

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style#rfc_7EA4EAB|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style]] expired 2020-03-10 10:01 ===
* Id: 7EA4EAB
* User: ComplexRational
* Date: 2020-03-10 00:46:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|944805039|STYLE 944805039}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|944855182|STYLE 944855182}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
As a follow-up to topic-specific discussions at [[Talk:Hassium]] and [[User talk:DePiep#MOS and NBSP]], it seems that the current MOS guideline on the usage of non-breaking spaces when separating numbers from written-out units (e.g. 5 kilometers (instead of 5 km); 118 elements) is open to interpretation. It advises to use non-breaking spaces when line breaks are awkward, which they seem to be in this case; however, implementing this would apparently require making heavy changes to lots of articles, as it is not strongly established as are the examples given in the MOS section.

I thus ask, should the same guideline for quantities and abbreviated units be followed for fully spelled-out units? Should non-breaking spaces be used only with abbreviations, or always with units and quantities? I would like to establish a more definite MOS guideline, in which one or the other is widely agreed upon as common practice. [[User:ComplexRational|ComplexRational]] ([[User talk:ComplexRational|talk]]) 00:46, 10 March 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Template talk:Kenneth Branagh#rfc_DBDA7A5|Template talk:Kenneth Branagh]] expired 2020-03-10 15:01 ===
* Id: DBDA7A5
* User: Nicholas0
* Date: 2020-02-09 14:51:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|939923773|MEDIA 939923773}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|944889076|MEDIA 944889076}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
My argument is that each director's films are properly subdivided according to format or medium, which is standard for Wikipedia. In contrast, [[User:Picsovina]] argues that Kenneth Branagh is well known for Shakespeare adaptations so therefore his Shakespeare adaptations as well as his Agatha Christie adaptations (which have nothing to do with Shakespeare so I don't understand how Picsovia's argument about Branagh being famous for Shakespeare adaptations justifies subdividing Agatha Christie adaptations into a separate group as well) should both be subdivided into separate sections in [[:Template:Kenneth Branagh]], leading to an unwieldy and highly confusing structure according to each film's subject matter rather than format. Other directors famous for directing Shakespeare adaptations include [[Laurence Olivier]] and [[Orson Welles]] yet their director templates do not subdivide their Shakespeare adaptations into separate sections. [[John G. Avildsen]] is famous for directing the ''Karate Kid'' movies yet his director template is not divided between ''Karate Kid'' films and ''Other'' films. [[George Miller (director)|George Miller]] is famous for directing the ''Mad Max'' films yet his director template is not divided between ''Mad Max'' films and ''Other'' films. [[Guy Hamilton]] is famous for directing four ''James Bond'' films yet his director template is not divided between ''James Bond'' films and ''Other'' films. There is therefore no real standard established precedent for doing so. Each director's films are properly subdivided according to format or medium, which is standard for Wikipedia. Agree or disagree. --[[User:Nicholas0|Nicholas0]] ([[User talk:Nicholas0|talk]]) 14:51, 9 February 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Nicolle Wallace#rfc_B6791CE|Talk:Nicolle Wallace]] expired 2020-03-10 22:01 ===

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Ms. Wallace in an interview stated she was no longer a "practicing Republican", but still a registered republican.  The word "practicing" seems to be a material fact in that otherwise all wikipedia will show is republican losing the nuance of "practicing."

*'''Option 1''' - Include the quote "practicing republican"

*'''Option 2''' - Exclude the quote "practicing republican".

For info, this is the sentence that would be included:
While she stated in a November 2019 interview that she was still a registered [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]], she claims she is no longer a "practicing Republican".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thewrap.com/msnbcs-nicolle-wallace-says-gop-is-sad-now-and-shes-no-longer-a-republican-video/|website=[[TheWrap]]|title=MSNBC's Nicolle Wallace Says GOP Is 'Sad' Now and She's No Longer a Republican (Video)|last=Ellefson|first=Lindsey|date=November 14, 2019|access-date=March 7, 2020}}</ref>

=== [[Talk:Lend-Lease#rfc_E7B2457|Talk:Lend-Lease]] expired 2020-03-12 16:01 ===
* Id: E7B2457
* User: Shimbo
* Date: 2020-02-11 16:00:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|940278366|HIST 940278366}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|945223811|HIST 945223811}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
User [[Talleyrand20]], seems determined to exclude the following quote by Russian historian [[Boris Vadimovich Sokolov]] from the article and has deleted it multiple times. The same quote has also been deleted multiple times by IP address [[178.155.64.26]].
 
<blockquote>On the whole the following conclusion can be drawn: that without these Western shipments under Lend-Lease the Soviet Union not only would not have been able to win the Great Patriotic War, it would not have been able even to oppose the German invaders, since it could not itself produce sufficient quantities of arms and military equipment or adequate supplies of fuel and ammunition. The Soviet authorities were well aware of this dependency on Lend-Lease. Thus, Stalin told Harry Hopkins [FDR's emissary to Moscow in July 1941] that the U.S.S.R. could not match Germany's might as an occupier of Europe and its resources.</blockquote>

Which is sourced to "Weeks 2004, p. 9"

The quote appears to me to be referenced and NPOV as it is assigned to its author. 

[[Talleyrand20]] however appears to believe it is "biased". 

The IP address user who has deleted the quote claimed it is "dull", which does not seem like a valid reason to not include the information. 

What would be the best thing to do about this? [[User:Shimbo|Shimbo]] ([[User talk:Shimbo|talk]]) 16:00, 11 February 2020 (UTC)}}

What should the scope of this article be?

# Any place or building which was formerly another place of worship and became a mosque, whether conquered and forcibly converted, repurposed by its worshipers who had converted, or abandoned by its worshipers and then purchased by a Muslim congregation
# Places or buildings that were conquered and forcibly converted, and those whose worshipers converted to Islam and repurposed the site, but '''not''' those which ceased to be used by members of their religion and were later purchased by a Muslim group

# Something else

=== [[Wikipedia:New pages patrol/Source guide discussions/Ghana#rfc_FF1A7D5|Wikipedia:New pages patrol/Source guide discussions/Ghana]] expired 2020-03-13 20:01 ===
* Id: FF1A7D5
* User: Rosguill
* Date: 2020-02-12 19:12:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|940480416|PROJ 940480416}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|945410489|PROJ 945410489}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This is a request for input about the general reliability of news sources in the Ghanaian media landscape. This discussion is intended to be part of a series of discussions assessing the reliability of news sources in a  range of regions and topics currently not widely discussed at RSN, and particularly those affected by [[WP:BIAS|systemic bias]], with the primary intent of distributing editor knowledge and providing a consensus-driven resource for [[WP:NPP|new page reviewers]] to use when evaluating sources in articles about subjects with which they are not personally familiar and which they are ill-equipped to research on their own. Results will be used to further expand the [[WP:NPPSG|New page patrol source guide]]; in the case of particularly strong consensuses, they may also be used to expand the [[WP:RSP|perennial sources list]].  <sub>signed, </sub>[[User:Rosguill|'''''Rosguill''''']] <sup>[[User talk:Rosguill|''talk'']]</sup> 19:12, 12 February 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Julian Assange#rfc_66B1ECD|Talk:Julian Assange]] expired 2020-03-13 23:01 ===
* Id: 66B1ECD
* User: Darouet
* Date: 2020-02-12 22:29:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|940504798|BIO 940504798}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|940504804|POL 940504804}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|945432762|BIO 945432762}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|945432768|POL 945432768}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Recently, newspapers have described an appeal by 130 prominent figures in Germany for Assange to be released, citing their concern for a free press and the rule of law. Should we include this information in the article in some form?

*'''Option 1''' Include two sentences in the article body, in the section [[Julian Assange#Reactions to the US indictment|Reactions to the US indictment]]. The proposed text is,
::{{talk quote|In February 2020, over 130 prominent German politicians, journalists and artists issued an appeal calling for Assange's release from prison, citing [[Nils Melzer|Melzer's]] assessment of Assange's health.(refs 1-5) Investigative journalist [[G√ºnter Wallraff]] stated that the appeal aimed to defend whistleblowers and freedom of the press; former [[Foreign Minister of Germany|foreign minister]] [[Sigmar Gabriel]] argued that for Assange, the rule of law had been set aside for political reasons.(refs 3,5)}}
::The references are [https://www.standard.co.uk/news/world/german-politicians-julian-assange-free-from-prison-a4355801.html 1][https://www.dw.com/en/prominent-germans-appeal-for-julian-assanges-release/a-52277571 2][https://www.sueddeutsche.de/politik/assange-freilassung-prozess-1.4787355 3][https://www.dw.com/de/breiter-appell-f%C3%BCr-freilassung-von-wikileaks-gr%C3%BCnder-assange/a-52274494 4][https://www.tagesschau.de/ausland/assange-aufruf-101.html 5]
*'''Option 2''' Exclude this information from any location within Assange's biography.
Please present your views below. -[[User:Darouet|Darouet]] ([[User talk:Darouet|talk]]) 22:29, 12 February 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Neutral point of view/Noticeboard#rfc_BCC345C|Wikipedia:Neutral point of view/Noticeboard]] expired 2020-03-17 05:01 ===
* Id: BCC345C
* User: CatcherStorm
* Date: 2020-02-23 01:35:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:

=== [[Talk:Singapore#rfc_FDECF5B|Talk:Singapore]] expired 2020-03-17 13:01 ===
* Id: FDECF5B
* User: DreamLinker
* Date: 2020-02-16 12:08:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|941075311|HIST 941075311}}

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|942002986|RELI 942002986}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|946000162|HIST 946000162}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|946000165|POL 946000165}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|946000167|RELI 946000167}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|946000171|SOC 946000171}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
How should the lead mention Singapore's religious diversity? ([https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Talk:Singapore&oldid=940085277#Highest_religious_diversity Link to previous discussion])

*'''A'''. Singapore's population is [[Cultural diversity|culturally]] and [[Religious pluralism|religiously diverse]]
*'''B'''. Singapore's population is [[Cultural diversity|culturally]] diverse and has one of the highest [[Religious pluralism|religious diversity]] in the world.<ref name=":1">{{cite web|title=Global Religious Diversity|url=http://www.pewforum.org/2014/04/04/global-religious-diversity/|publisher=Pew Research|date=4 April 2014|access-date=15 April 2014}}</ref><ref name=pew>[http://www.globalreligiousfutures.org/countries/singapore/religious_demography#/?affiliations_religion_id=0&affiliations_year=2010 Pew Research Center's Religion & Public Life Project: Singapore]. [[Pew Research Center]]. 2010.</ref>
*'''C''' A 2014 study by Pew Research Center found that Singapore has the highest religious diversity of any country.<ref name=":1">{{cite web|title=Global Religious Diversity|url=http://www.pewforum.org/2014/04/04/global-religious-diversity/|publisher=Pew Research|date=4 April 2014|access-date=15 April 2014}}</ref><ref name=pew>[http://www.globalreligiousfutures.org/countries/singapore/religious_demography#/?affiliations_religion_id=0&affiliations_year=2010 Pew Research Center's Religion & Public Life Project: Singapore]. [[Pew Research Center]]. 2010.</ref>
*'''D''' Any other suggestion
{{reflist-talk}}
Please mention your preference in the survey section.--[[User:DreamLinker|DreamLinker]] ([[User talk:DreamLinker|talk]]) 12:08, 16 February 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Template talk:2019‚Äì20 coronavirus pandemic data#rfc_A1C49A0|Template talk:2019‚Äì20 coronavirus pandemic data]] expired 2020-03-18 07:01 ===
* Id: A1C49A0
* User: Checco
* Date: 2020-03-14 10:24:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|945498819|HIST 945498819}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|945498820|POL 945498820}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|946126081|HIST 946126081}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|946126084|POL 946126084}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I think we need to have the countries/territories/dependencies issue settled once for all.<br>Are '''territories and dependencies''' {{small|(full list from [[List of countries and dependencies by population]]: Hong Kong, Puerto Rico, Macau, New Caledonia, French Polynesia, Guam, Cura√ßao, Aruba, Jersey, U.S. Virgin Islands, Isle of Man, Cayman Islands, Bermuda, Guernsey, American Samoa, Greenland, Northern Mariana Islands, Faroe Islands, Turks and Caicos Islands, Sint Maarten, Saint Martin, Gibraltar, British Virgin Islands, √Öland Islands, Cook Islands, Anguilla, Wallis and Futuna, Saint Barth√©lemy, Saint Pierre and Miquelon, Saint Helena, Ascension
and Tristan da Cunha, Montserrat, Falkland Islands, Christmas Island, Norfolk Island, Niue, Tokelau, Cocos (Keeling) Islands, Pitcairn Islands)}} as well as '''scarcely or not universally recognised countries''' {{small|(Taiwan, Kosovo, Western Sahara, Transnistria, Northern Cyprus, Abkhazia, Artsakh, South Ossetia)}} '''to be included in their respective countries' counts''' or not?<br>As of now, two dependent territories (namely Hong Kong and Macau, so that China is referred to as "China {{small|(mainland)}}"), along with scarcely or not universally recognised countries are listes separately from their respective countries, others are not. The count is made more complicate by the fact that most sources (notably including [https://gisanddata.maps.arcgis.com/apps/opsdashboard/index.html#/bda7594740fd40299423467b48e9ecf6 Coronavirus COVID-19 Global Cases by Johns Hopkins CSSE] and [https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/#countries Coronavirus Update - Worldometer]) list all dependencies separately.<br>Please, have your say! --[[User:Checco|Checco]] ([[User talk:Checco|talk]]) 10:24, 14 March 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Deep South#rfc_3146CA8|Talk:Deep South]] expired 2020-03-21 16:01 ===
* Id: 3146CA8
* User: Guy Macon
* Date: 2020-02-20 15:46:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|941772376|HIST 941772376}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|960256685|HIST 960256685}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the further reading section contain references about the Black Belt?

Background:

At<br>
[[Talk:Black Belt (geological formation)#Content Seems to Conflict with Sources]]<br>
and<br>
[[Talk:Black Belt (geological formation)#Obsolete term?]]<br>
there was a consensus that the term "black belt" is not in common usage the way phrases like "sun belt" and "rust belt" are used and is not a commonly-used phase today outside of [[physical geography]].<br>
The page was renamed from [[Black Belt (U.S. region)]] to [[Black Belt (geological formation)]] without objection.

{{userlinks|Rjensen}} then created [[Black Belt in the American South]] which, while not a phrase that is in common use the way "bible belt" is, is clearly used by enough sources to justify a Wikipedia article. 

Rjensen then inserted content into [[Deep South]] referring to the page he created[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Deep_South&type=revision&diff=940738184&oldid=939961440] and inserted multiple references to the black belt into the further reading section of [[Deep South]] article.[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Deep_South&type=revision&diff=941057289&oldid=940953906][https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Deep_South&type=revision&diff=941740448&oldid=941695442] 

The question before us is whether material about the black belt but not about the deep south should be retained to the further reading section of the deep south article. --[[User:Guy Macon|Guy Macon]] ([[User talk:Guy Macon|talk]]) 15:46, 20 February 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Template talk:2019‚Äì20 coronavirus pandemic data#rfc_406F609|Template talk:2019‚Äì20 coronavirus pandemic data]] expired 2020-03-23 07:01 ===
* Id: 406F609
* User: Redav
* Date: 2020-03-18 14:24:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|946178470|HIST 946178470}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|946178472|POL 946178472}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|946930919|HIST 946930919}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|946930924|POL 946930924}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I have understood that - de facto - the figures presented for Netherlands are an aggregate for the '''Kingdom''' of the Netherlands, consisting of the a) '''country''' of the Netherlands, b) Aruba, c) Cura√ßao, and d) Sint Maarten. Since, however, the sole name ''Netherlands'' is ambiguous, I plead for at least adding - and keeping added - as a note that ''Netherlands'' as mentioned in the table is to be understood the whole kingdom consisting of the four countries each with their own responsible authority. I think this is essential for a good understanding of the nature of the figures. This is a matter of both geography (one country lies in Europe, one in the southeastern Caribbean, two in the northeastern Caribbean) and politics (since it concerns the political division of one kingdom into four countries). Notes to this end have been added and removed several times. Why and by whom they have been removed, I cannot seem to retrace in the edit history, either because the rate of edits is rather high or because no comment was added from which I succeeded to understand that it concerned a change with respect to Netherlands. Those who like to have such a note removed, please provide arguments.[[User:Redav|Redav]] ([[User talk:Redav|talk]]) 14:24, 18 March 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Biography#rfc_5B47D03|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Biography]] expired 2020-03-23 12:01 ===
* Id: 5B47D03
* User: SergeWoodzing
* Date: 2020-02-22 11:14:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|942072282|BIO 942072282}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|942072284|STYLE 942072284}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|942072285|POLICY 942072285}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|946955789|BIO 946955789}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|946955792|STYLE 946955792}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|946955793|POLICY 946955793}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
"Unless the cause of death is itself a reason for notability, a single sentence describing the death is usually sufficient, and often none is included in the lead at all, just a death date."

Is this guideline clear enough to be useful to a user trying to determine whether somebody's cause of death should be included in the lead of their bio?
What I see as a lack of clarity - especially with wording like ''often none is included'' - can lead to long animated discussions such as [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Caroline_Flack#Death_does_not_go_in_lead_in_this_case this recent one]. Those discussions wouldn't be such a waste of time and effort if briefer, or if altogether unnecessary, given we had a clearer guideline.

Being rather a strong anti-sensationalist myself, hoping always that Wikipedia articles about people will not develop into tabloid-type material, perhaps I have misunderstood the guideline along those lines. If ''normal'' (statisticlly) suicides, car crashes, drug overdoses, for example are to be considered by Wikipedia as defining factors in what's notable about those people, then I am wrong in removing them from leads, whereas with a clearly notable death such as that of [[Christine Chubbuck]] I would not do that. If a celebrity's cause of death is widely reported in media, and that alone makes the cause of death in itself a reason for notability, then I am also wrong in feeling it should be removed from the lead as non-notable. 

I am inviting other editors to chime in here, and to help write a clearer guideline in this detail. --[[User:SergeWoodzing|SergeWoodzing]] ([[User talk:SergeWoodzing|talk]]) 11:14, 22 February 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:British Raj#rfc_7EA12A2|Talk:British Raj]] expired 2020-03-23 19:01 ===
* Id: 7EA12A2
* User: Anupam
* Date: 2020-03-23 16:33:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|946992877|HIST 946992877}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|947009048|HIST 947009048}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the infobox of this article contain a photograph of the Star of India? [[User:Anupam|Anupam]]<sup>[[User talk:Anupam|Talk]]</sup> 16:33, 23 March 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Christopher Columbus#rfc_2FBC75B|Talk:Christopher Columbus]] expired 2020-03-23 22:01 ===
* Id: 2FBC75B
* User: Tarl N.#top
* Date: 2020-02-22 21:19:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|942146013|HIST 942146013}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|947033889|HIST 947033889}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Currently, the [[Christopher Columbus]] page completely eschews the use of the word "discovery". This has gone back and forth over the years, I think it's time to get a wider commentary on this. The cited references pretty much all use the word, and indeed, several of them have the word in the title of the work. Refusing to use the word seems to be a mixture of [[WP:RECENTISM]] (the fashion for excising "discovery" is fairly recent) and [[WP:CENSOR]] ("discovery" as a dirty word). Either way, it means we're going out of our way to not follow our cited sources.

I understand the changes in current fashion, but I think Wikipedia is ill-served by bending to them. It is beyond question that when Columbus made his initial voyages, they were discoveries that hit both sides of the Atlantic like a thunderbolt. We can quibble over the terminology (perhaps say "discovery of the route" or "discovery from the point of view of both Americans and Eurasians"), but only with caution. It would be easy to get so tied up in precision as to make the article unreadable. [[User:Tarl_N.|<b style="color:green">Tarl N.</b>]] ([[User talk:Tarl N.#top|<span style="color:teal">discuss</span>]]) 21:19, 22 February 2020 (UTC)}}

In trying to keep consistent with [[Template:2019‚Äì20 coronavirus pandemic data]] and [[2019‚Äì20 coronavirus pandemic in mainland China]], I changed this total to subtract Hong Kong and Macau from the "mainland" total. This edit has been reverted. I feel that it is very important to be very consistent and having different totals for the same place is not consistent. The numbers from China come from this source: [http://www.nhc.gov.cn/xcs/yqtb/202003/fbd8871d80574991a4913cd180f83402.shtml]. I would like to know what others think about this. [[User:United States Man|United States Man]] ([[User talk:United States Man#top|talk]]) 02:36, 24 March 2020 (UTC)}}

Rfc participants are asked to support any of the following position statements, give their reasoning, and make any general comments or observations they might have.

'''Position statement #1:''' This article's [[readability]] is poor.<br/>
'''Position statement #2:''' The lead requires improvement to comply with [[Wikipedia:Summary style]].<br/>
'''Position statement #3:''' {{free diff|942223230|942223054|Article version #1}} is unacceptably pro-electronic cigarette, advocates that readers should take up electronic cigarettes, or evangelises for e-cigarettes in any way.<br/>
'''Position statement #4:''' {{free diff|942223230|942223054|Article version #1}} is preferable to {{free diff|942250849|942250316|article version #2}}.<br/>

Thanks for participating!‚Äî[[User:S Marshall|<b style="font-family: Verdana; color: Maroon;">S&nbsp;Marshall</b>]]&nbsp;<small>[[User talk:S Marshall|T]]/[[Special:Contributions/S Marshall|C]]</small> 16:37, 23 February 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Directors Guild of America Award for Outstanding Directing ‚Äì Feature Film#rfc_8E2936D|Talk:Directors Guild of America Award for Outstanding Directing ‚Äì Feature Film]] expired 2020-03-24 23:01 ===
* Id: 8E2936D
* User: Binksternet
* Date: 2020-02-23 22:12:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|942313921|MEDIA 942313921}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|947206399|MEDIA 947206399}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should we host indicators of prominent awards in articles about other awards, in cases where the two awards are not mentioned by a reliable source listing both? For instance, indicating Academy Awards in other film awards articles, or indicating Emmy Awards in other television awards articles, or indicating Tony Awards in other theatre awards articles. Of course, the two awards would always be supported by two separate groups of sources ‚Äì the combining of the two awards is the question here. [[User:Binksternet|Binksternet]] ([[User talk:Binksternet|talk]]) 22:12, 23 February 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Template talk:2019‚Äì20 coronavirus pandemic data#rfc_808B045|Template talk:2019‚Äì20 coronavirus pandemic data]] expired 2020-03-25 07:01 ===
* Id: 808B045
* User: Checco
* Date: 2020-03-21 09:58:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|946625601|HIST 946625601}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|946625603|POL 946625603}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|949218054|HIST 949218054}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|949218057|POL 949218057}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This is an ongoing issue, thus I am re-proposing this RfC. We need to settle the countries/territories/dependencies issue settled once for all.<br>Are '''territories and dependencies''' {{small|(full list from [[List of countries and dependencies by population]]: Hong Kong, Puerto Rico, Macau, New Caledonia, French Polynesia, Guam, Cura√ßao, Aruba, Jersey, U.S. Virgin Islands, Isle of Man, Cayman Islands, Bermuda, Guernsey, American Samoa, Greenland, Northern Mariana Islands, Faroe Islands, Turks and Caicos Islands, Sint Maarten, Saint Martin, Gibraltar, British Virgin Islands, √Öland Islands, Cook Islands, Anguilla, Wallis and Futuna, Saint Barth√©lemy, Saint Pierre and Miquelon, Saint Helena, Ascension
and Tristan da Cunha, Montserrat, Falkland Islands, Christmas Island, Norfolk Island, Niue, Tokelau, Cocos (Keeling) Islands, Pitcairn Islands)}} as well as '''scarcely or not universally recognised countries''' {{small|(Taiwan, Kosovo, Western Sahara, Transnistria, Northern Cyprus, Abkhazia, Artsakh, South Ossetia)}} '''to be included in their respective countries' counts''' or not?<br>As of now, two dependent territories (namely Hong Kong and Macau, so that China is referred to as "China {{small|(mainland)}}"), along with scarcely or not universally recognised countries are listes separately from their respective countries, others are not. The count is made more complicate by the fact that most sources (notably including [https://gisanddata.maps.arcgis.com/apps/opsdashboard/index.html#/bda7594740fd40299423467b48e9ecf6 Coronavirus COVID-19 Global Cases by Johns Hopkins CSSE] and [https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/#countries Coronavirus Update - Worldometer]) list all dependencies separately.<br>Please, have your say! --[[User:Checco|Checco]] ([[User talk:Checco|talk]]) 09:58, 21 March 2020 (UTC)}}

Should the lead include mention of the fact that the Republican Party shifted its racial and geographical composition to the South and White Americans after the successes of the Civil Rights movement in the 60s, and that the party appealed to racial conservatism after the passage of the 1964 Civil Rights Act?

=== [[Talk:2020 Democratic Party presidential primaries#rfc_7DDB6BB|Talk:2020 Democratic Party presidential primaries]] expired 2020-03-27 02:01 ===
* Id: 7DDB6BB
* User: Smith0124
* Date: 2020-03-04 23:28:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|944006118|POL 944006118}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|948967978|POL 948967978}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This is an Rfc exclusively regarding the infobox template for the [[2020 Democratic presidential primaries]]. Previously, there was an Rfc about state pages, and this does not affect that result.<br>

The question is:<br>
'''Should withdrawn candidates that have delegates (Buttigieg, Klobuchar, Bloomberg) and candidates still in but with no possible path to victory (Gabbard) still be included in the infobox?'''

The options are:<br>
'''A - Remove all withdrawn candidates and candidates with no possible path.'''<br>
'''B - Remove withdrawn candidates but keep all candidates still in the race. Possibly with a 5% threshold?'''<br>
'''C - Keep as is.'''<br>
'''D - Other.'''<br>

Thanks all! [[User:Smith0124|Smith0124]] ([[User talk:Smith0124|talk]]) 23:28, 4 March 2020 (UTC)}}


=== [[Talk:2020 Democratic Party presidential primaries#rfc_776A9CA|Talk:2020 Democratic Party presidential primaries]] expired 2020-03-27 02:01 ===
* Id: 776A9CA
* Date: 2020-02-26 01:43:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|942662991|POL 942662991}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|947562799|POL 947562799}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 This is a two part RfC.

A. Prior to a caucus or primary, should candidates only be included in the infoboxes of primary and caucus articles if they are polling at an average of 5% or above on FiveThirtyEight.com?

B. After a caucus or primary, should candidates only be included in the infoboxes of primary and caucus articles if they have won delegates in that contest? 
- [[user:MrX|Mr]][[user talk:MrX|X]] üñã 01:43, 26 February 2020 (UTC)}}

[[User:KyleJoan|<span style="font-family:Consolas; color:#CD8C95">'''K'''yle'''J'''oan</span>]]<sup>[[User talk:KyleJoan|<span style="font-family:Consolas; color:#8B6969">talk</span>]]</sup>  04:38, 27 March 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:About Time (2013 film)#rfc_F7E653E|Talk:About Time (2013 film)]] expired 2020-03-27 18:01 ===
* Id: F7E653E
* User: ZarhanFastfire
* Date: 2020-02-26 17:09:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|943410462|MEDIA 943410462}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|947659362|MEDIA 947659362}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Several years ago one editor pursued an agenda of attacking the film using original research and was opposed. The editor then found individual sources for individual points but continued to allow their personal POV to stand in the form of a separate section which enumerated the rules of the film, which the sources cited did not do. They appear to be fixated on this. I have made an attempt to balance the section by not treating the topic of plot holes any differently from other topics praised or decried by different critics of the film, as we normally do in film articles. There is no need for a separate section on a single topic like this. It is UNDUE and POV and SYNTH to do that and to enumerate a list of rules when these are and should be referred to ONCE in the plot itself. This is not a fan site where the film can be nitpicked to death by one person. This is an encylopedia article where we report what was said and no more in the appropriate places. The rules may be described in the plot but they do not need to be rehashed by the editor in reception under a separate banner. Finally, the language used by the editor in reporting / quoting the sources is undue, making it sound like these are not reviewer's opinions but stated facts. 

This RfC asks one question: is the reception section fine as it is, or should it be reworked in some manner based on the above? For those interested in what it could look like should these suggestions be followed, I redid it once myself and it was reverted this morning. I reverted back but probably should have made this comment and RfC first. It has since been reverted again, and I was "ordered" not to revert again on my talk page, unsigned. [[User:ZarhanFastfire|ZarhanFastfire]] ([[User talk:ZarhanFastfire|talk]]) 17:09, 26 February 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Boxing#rfc_1E8B613|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Boxing]] expired 2020-03-27 21:01 ===
* Id: 1E8B613
* User: SaskatchewanSenator
* Date: 2020-02-26 20:17:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|942796213|SOC 942796213}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|947682561|SOC 947682561}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should we add the following section to the [[Wikipedia:WikiProject_Boxing/MOSGuidelines|WikiProject Boxing Manual of Style]]?

'''Lineal champions'''<br>
There is no single canonical list of lineal champions. Don't include the lineal championship in lists of champions, record tables or succession boxes.

Lineal championships are a point of view and should follow the [[WP:NPOV|neutral point of view]] policy:
* Avoid stating it as a fact. A lineal championship is an opinion and should not be stated in Wikipedia's voice.
* Undue weight - Don't include it in the lead unless it is a widely held viewpoint (ex. You need more sources than just the Cyber Boxing Zone list.)--[[User:SaskatchewanSenator|SaskatchewanSenator]] ([[User talk:SaskatchewanSenator|talk]]) 20:17, 26 February 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Vita#rfc_A7D13CF|Talk:Vita]] expired 2020-03-28 04:01 ===
* Id: A7D13CF
* User: Davidbena

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|947736423|TECH 947736423}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
A dispute has arisen whether or not "Vita" can be used as an entry on this Disambiguation page when referring specifically to a book by that title, written by the 1st-century historian [[Josephus]]. One of the conditions for adding a name to [[WP:DAB]] is: "Ensuring that a reader who searches for a topic using a particular term can get to the information on that topic quickly and easily, whichever of the possible topics it might be." For the relative arguments (''pros'' and ''cons'') of adding the name "Vita (Josephus)" to this page, see the discussion [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User_talk:Drmies#%22Vita%22_-_the_Life_of_Josephus here]. Please advise.[[User:Davidbena|Davidbena]] ([[User talk:Davidbena|talk]]) 03:43, 27 February 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Template talk:2019‚Äì20 coronavirus pandemic data#rfc_26B6E2B|Template talk:2019‚Äì20 coronavirus pandemic data]] expired 2020-03-30 07:01 ===

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Catholicism#rfc_4D87ABA|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Catholicism]] expired 2020-03-30 11:01 ===
* Id: 4D87ABA
* User: Elizium23
* Date: 2020-02-29 10:22:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|943184861|POLICY 943184861}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|948142003|POLICY 948142003}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Hello, there is currently debate about the proper use of self-published sources.
#Editors in most areas of the Wikipedia seem to use self-published sources ([[WP:SPS]]) according to the verifiability policy set forth there: in a nutshell, that SPS can be used with caution as long as they meet certain criteria, and secondary, indepdent sources should typically be preferred as the basis for a good article. Any business org article can be seen to use SPS in this fashion, such as [[Boeing]], [[Google]], and [[Apple Inc.]] There has been little to no resistance or protest against using SPS for all manner of statistics and information, as long as reliable secondary indepdent sources are preferred for analysis and support.
#Editors editing in the anti-abortion topic area have adopted a novel interpretation: SPS are never to be used because their information is considered promotional. For example, an organization publishing its membership numbers or revenue cannot be used as a source, because the organizations always inflate those numbers falsely, making the SPS a decidedly unreliable source. In particular, view #2 has been adopted by {{user|Avatar317}}, on the article [[Knights of Columbus]] and related articles.
RFC question: So which view is correct? Should the [[WP:SPS]] policy be interpreted so strictly that we practically never use SPS? If #2 is true, then what are the actual acceptable criteria? What is the action plan for implementing the reinterpretation across vast swaths of topic areas that apparently have had it wrong all this time? [[User:Elizium23|Elizium23]] ([[User talk:Elizium23|talk]]) 10:22, 29 February 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Biographies of living persons/Noticeboard#rfc_4674B3E|Wikipedia:Biographies of living persons/Noticeboard]] expired 2020-03-30 20:01 ===
* Id: 4674B3E
* User: LaundryPizza03
* Date: 2020-03-24 04:59:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|947080717|BIO 947080717}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|947080724|POLICY 947080724}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|948217604|BIO 948217604}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|948217609|POLICY 948217609}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The redirect [[Barack Osama]] and its lowercase form [[Barack osama]] were deleted 8 times in total, always per [[WP:G10|G10]] or a similar rationale except for one [[WP:G1|G1]] in May 2007, before being salted in June 2008 and March 2009, respectively.

On the other hand, this typo is common enough ([https://www.seattletimes.com/nation-world/oops-barack-osama-appears-on-ny-ballots/ example 1], [https://deadline.com/2018/08/100000-pyramid-evan-kaufman-tim-meadows-obama-osama-abc-1202444990/ example 2]) that it may actually warrant a redirect [[WP:IAR|despite this]], like its counterpart [[Obama bin Laden]]/[[Obama Bin Laden]]/[[Obama bin laden]] that have been kept three times at RfD.

In brief: Should [[Barack Osama]]/[[Barack osama]] exist as a redirect to [[Barack Obama]]? ‚Äì[[User:LaundryPizza03|<b style="color:#77b">Laundry</b><b style="color:#fb0">Pizza</b><b style="color:#b00">03</b>]] ([[User talk:LaundryPizza03|<span style="color:#0d0">d</span>]][[Special:Contribs/LaundryPizza03|<span style="color:#0bf">cÃÑ</span>]]) 04:59, 24 March 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Gender studies#rfc_A557048|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Gender studies]] expired 2020-03-30 23:01 ===
* Id: A557048
* User: Sangdeboeuf

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Featured article candidates#rfc_C3B37FC|Wikipedia talk:Featured article candidates]] expired 2020-04-01 12:01 ===
* Id: C3B37FC
* User: Mike_Christie
* Date: 2020-03-02 11:43:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|943595259|PROJ 943595259}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|943595262|PROP 943595262}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|948504601|PROJ 948504601}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|948504602|PROP 948504602}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
[[Template:FAC-instructions|FAC instructions]] currently include these sentences, numbered below for reference:

# An editor is allowed to be the sole nominator of only one article at a time, but two nominations may be allowed if the editor is a co-nominator on at least one of them.
# If a nomination is archived, the nominator(s) should take adequate time to work on resolving issues before re-nominating.
# None of the nominators may nominate or co-nominate any article for two weeks unless given leave to do so by a coordinator; if such an article is nominated without asking for leave, a coordinator will decide whether to remove it.
# A coordinator may exempt from this restriction an archived nomination that attracted no (or minimal) feedback.

This RfC proposes three things:

* '''A''': Change sentence 1 to "An editor is allowed to be the sole nominator of only two articles at a time, but three nominations are allowed if the editor is a co-nominator on at least one of them".
* '''B''': Add the following after sentence 1: "At their discretion, the Featured article review coordinators may grant a fourth nomination or co-nomination to editors who actively engage in improving Featured articles in that process".
* '''C''': Modify sentences 3 & 4.  (Note that sentence 3 refers to the nominator(s) of an archived article, per sentence 2.) How to modify them is open for discussion: suggested options are to leave them unchanged; to remove the restriction; or to suggest a different restriction or different wording.

-- [[User:Mike Christie|Mike Christie]] ([[User_talk:Mike Christie|talk]] - [[Special:Contributions/Mike_Christie|contribs]] -  [[User:Mike Christie/Reference library|library]]) 11:43, 2 March 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Rules for Fools#rfc_FFF4E9F|Wikipedia talk:Rules for Fools]] expired 2020-04-02 00:01 ===

* User: 107.77.173.61
* Date: 2020-04-01 10:49:00

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Rules for Fools#rfc_22FA791|Wikipedia talk:Rules for Fools]] expired 2020-04-02 00:01 ===
* Id: 22FA791
* User: 107.77.173.61
* Date: 2020-04-01 10:00:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|948538065|POLICY 948538065}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|948591384|PROP 948591384}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|948605681|POLICY 948605681}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|948605684|PROP 948605684}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
It was funny when 'General Tomfoolery' got changed to 'General Jerryfoolery'. But when users are edit warring over section titles as happened in the past four years, moving the page randomly to other titles, as happened in 2017, unnecessarily duplicating the page as happened in 2020, blanking entire sections as happened in 2019 and 2020, messing with the text font, orientation, or size, or the css as happened in 2018, 2019, and 2020, linking to random external links, and performing other such examples of vandalism on the yearly April Fools documentation page, it becomes too excessive and out of hand, and the Wikipedia administrators should crack down upon these violations of Wikipedia policy. [[Special:Contributions/107.77.173.61|107.77.173.61]] ([[User talk:107.77.173.61|talk]]) 10:00, 1 April 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:1976 Tangshan earthquake#rfc_77D2B33|Talk:1976 Tangshan earthquake]] expired 2020-04-02 08:01 ===
* Id: 77D2B33
* Date: 2020-03-03 07:16:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|943673109|HIST 943673109}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|943673111|SCI 943673111}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|948656414|HIST 948656414}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|948656442|SCI 948656442}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the lead article have the sentence {{tq|In minutes the city of Tangshan, an industrial city with approximately one million inhabitants, ceased to exist.}}? Please decide on one of the three following proposals:
#Keep {{quote|In minutes the city of Tangshan, an industrial city with approximately one million inhabitants, ceased to exist. Eighty-five percent of the buildings in the city collapsed or were unusable, all services failed, and most of the highway and railway bridges collapsed or were seriously damaged.}}
#Replace with {{quote|In minutes, eighty-five percent of the buildings in Tangshan, an industrial city with approximately one million inhabitants, collapsed or were unusable, all services failed, and most of the highway and railway bridges collapsed or were seriously damaged.}} (with or without the {{tq|an industrial city with approximately one million inhabitants}} sub-clause)
#Replace with {{quote|In minutes the city of Tangshan, an industrial city with approximately one million inhabitants, ceased to exist as a functioning entity. Eighty-five percent of the buildings in the city collapsed or were unusable, all services failed, and most of the highway and railway bridges collapsed or were seriously damaged.}}
Thanks in advance. 07:16, 3 March 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Biography#rfc_057C97B|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Biography]] expired 2020-04-05 19:01 ===
* Id: 057C97B
* Date: 2020-03-06 18:46:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|944265150|POL 944265150}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|944265152|STYLE 944265152}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|944265156|POLICY 944265156}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|949308473|POL 949308473}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|949308476|STYLE 949308476}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|949308479|POLICY 949308479}}
* RFC Text:

As seen above on this page, [[MOS:JOBTITLES]] has been disputed numerous times due to strong disagreements in whether the names of political offices should be capitalised in the lead sentences of political office articles and elsewhere following the article/modifier. A retrospective analysis of 19 of these discussions dating back to 2011 (above) showed that the overall view is against the guideline as it reads now by approximately 2:1, but no discussion has ever been able to come to a reasonable solution.

Should the Manual of Style section be removed entirely as a guideline that does not have "general" support? (A substitute can be added later if it does have general support.) <span style="background-color:#c4c4c4;border-radius:8px;padding:0px 2px;">[[User:SUM1|<span style="color:#000;font-weight:bold;">¬∑&nbsp;‚Ä¢&nbsp;SUM1&nbsp;‚Ä¢&nbsp;¬∑</span>]]</span>&nbsp;<span style="color:#000;font-weight:bold;font-size:.8em;">([[User_talk:SUM1|talk]])</span> 18:46, 6 March 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Naming conventions (video games)#rfc_9062229|Wikipedia talk:Naming conventions (video games)]] expired 2020-04-06 01:01 ===
* Id: 9062229
* User: Steel1943
* Date: 2020-03-07 00:21:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|944309720|STYLE 944309720}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|949357247|STYLE 949357247}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Per the close of [[Talk:Ninja (video game player)#Requested move 12 January 2020]], the fact that [[Wikipedia:Naming conventions (video games)#People]] says that the disambiguators "(gamer)" or "(video game player)" can be used in titles to describe a person who plays video games professionally is problematic seems evident. So ... which disambiguator should be stated in the aforementioned guideline? ...Since apparently, only one can prevail. [[User:Steel1943|<span style="color: #2F4F4F;">'''''Steel1943'''''</span>]] ([[User talk:Steel1943|talk]]) 00:21, 7 March 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Antifa (United States)#rfc_6FB7974|Talk:Antifa (United States)]] expired 2020-04-06 08:01 ===
* Id: 6FB7974
* User: Feminist
* Date: 2020-03-07 07:19:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|944347838|POL 944347838}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|944347840|SOC 944347840}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|949400305|POL 949400305}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|949400309|SOC 949400309}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=

=== [[Talk:2019‚Äì20 coronavirus pandemic#rfc_648A5DC|Talk:2019‚Äì20 coronavirus pandemic]] expired 2020-04-07 07:01 ===
* Id: 648A5DC
* User: Tiiliskivi
* Date: 2020-04-02 11:18:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|948679976|SOC 948679976}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|950225493|SOC 950225493}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The sentence about xenophobia and racism related to the pandemic keeps getting edited back and forth by me and other users, so I believe it's appropriate to create an RfC about it. The current formatting of the sentence is "Misinformation and conspiracy theories about the virus have spread online as well as xenophobia and discrimination against Chinese people, people of Asian descent, and others from hotspots.", added by me.

Three versions of the sentence have been included lately:
#...as well as xenophobia and discrimination against Chinese people and people of Asian descent. (Sentence mentioning discrimination against people of Asian descent only.)
#...as well as xenophobia and discrimination against Chinese people, people of Asian descent, and others from hotspots. (Sentence mentioning discrimination against people from other hotspots, but highlighting Asians.)
#...while xenophobia and discrimination against various ethnic groups has increased internationally. (More ambiguous formatting not mentioning specific groups.)
So I am asking, which the three versions is the most appropriate and neutral. It's also worth asking, if the word "Asians" should specify "East Asians", considering Asian is quite a wide term, at least in most usages. --[[User:Tiiliskivi|Tiiliskivi]] ([[User talk:Tiiliskivi|talk]]) 11:18, 2 April 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Kevin Richardson (zookeeper)#rfc_D052A8B|Talk:Kevin Richardson (zookeeper)]] expired 2020-04-07 18:01 ===
* Id: D052A8B
* User: Erakura
* Date: 2020-03-08 17:45:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|944578014|BIO 944578014}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|944578024|STYLE 944578024}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|949645118|BIO 949645118}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|949645128|STYLE 949645128}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
While [[Special:Diff/944385399|this particular edit]] wasn't terribly constructive on its own, it does bring up a good point that I hadn't considered before I reverted it: is 'zookeeper' an accurate disambiguator for this person? He owns and operates a wildlife sanctuary, which is not a [[zoo]], so I'm inclined to believe it isn't. If others agree this is not a good word choice, what word/words are better suited for this? Perhaps [[Kevin Richardson (sanctuary owner)]] or [[Kevin Richardson (conservationist)]], but I'm not completely sold on either one. (Between the two I'd lean towards 'sanctuary owner'.) I've made this an RFC as I suspect this will not be seen otherwise. Thank you! ‚Äì[[User:Erakura|'''<span style="color:black">Erakura</span>''']][[User talk:Erakura|<sup><span style="color:darkgreen">(talk)</span></sup>]] 17:45, 8 March 2020 (UTC)}}
