=== [[Talk:Deep state in the United States#rfc_D51C5F8|Talk:Deep state in the United States]] expired 2020-04-09 21:01 ===
* Id: D51C5F8
* User: TMLutas
* Date: 2020-04-09 16:04:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|949984259|POL 949984259}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|950025366|POL 950025366}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should 'deep state in the United States' be solely described as a conspiracy theory, as it currently is?

Replies: 

There are currently four article footnotes describing non-conspiracy theories of what the deep state is. 

They are as follows: 

#{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/the-deep-state_us_58c94a64e4b01d0d473bcfa3|title=The Deep State Is A Very Real Thing|last=Friedman|first=George|authorlink=George Friedman|date=March 15, 2017|website=[[The HuffingtonPost]]|publisher=|access-date=|quote=}}
#{{cite web |url=https://billmoyers.com/story/the-deep-state-explained/|title=The Deep State, Explained|last=Light |first=John |date=March 31, 2017 |website=[[Moyers & Company]]|publisher=|access-date=July 6, 2019 |quote=}}
#[[Michael Crowley (journalist)|Crowley, Michael {September/October 2017) [https://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2017/09/05/deep-state-real-cia-fbi-intelligence-215537 "The Deep State is Real: But it might not be what you think"] ''[[Politico|Politico Magazine]]''
#{{cite web |title="Deep State" in American History {{!}} C-SPAN.org |url=https://www.c-span.org/video/?461976-2/deep-state-american-history |website=www.c-span.org |language=en-us}}

It should be recognized in the lead paragraph that conspiracy theories exist in parallel with non-conspiracy theories of the deep state in America. [[User:TMLutas|TMLutas]] ([[User talk:TMLutas|talk]]) 16:04, 9 April 2020 (UTC)}}

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Are geonotices such as [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wikipedia:Geonotice/list.json&diff=945036801&oldid=944744716 this one] (requested by {{u|EllenCT}}, added by {{u|Deryck Chan}}, full request [[Wikipedia:Geonotice#Open access for federally funded research|here]]) appropriate? My opinion is that '''no''', it is not okay to use Wikipedia for political activism, regardless of how noble the cause. I've asked for removal, but I doubt the geonotice request page gets much traffic, so in the mean time, I think this is probably worth bringing up here to get some wider input. &ndash;[[User:Deacon Vorbis|Deacon Vorbis]]&nbsp;([[User Talk:Deacon Vorbis|carbon]]&nbsp;&bull;&nbsp;[[Special:Contributions/Deacon Vorbis|videos]]) 13:49, 11 March 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Reverting#rfc_79A5D0A|Wikipedia talk:Reverting]] expired 2020-04-11 09:01 ===
* Id: 79A5D0A
* User: Sdkb
* Date: 2020-03-12 08:42:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|945317627|POLICY 945317627}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|956067212|POLICY 956067212}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should we add the following section directly after the "when to revert" section?

{{tq2|'''<big>Do a partial reversion when appropriate</big>'''

{{shortcut|WP:CAUGHTUP|WP:REVONLY|WP:EXPLAINALLPARTS}}

{{Further|Wikipedia:Restoring part of a reverted edit}}

[[File:Baby being bathed on the kitchen table, ca. 1918 (7001966537).jpg|thumb|150px|[[Don't throw out the baby with the bathwater]]!]]

Often, editors bundle multiple changes into a single edit, such as adding a new section while also fixing a copy error elsewhere on the page. If you object to only part of an edit, be careful to ''revert only the part you disagree with, leaving the rest alone''. The encyclopedia is damaged when positive contributions are caught up and lost in a revert. It is also impolite to the editor you are reverting, since if they wish to restore the uncontroversial portion of their edit, they must edit the page again, which can make it seem to others superficially reviewing the page history like they are edit warring, when actually they are not.

If you do feel that all parts of an edit containing multiple distinct changes warrant reversion, it is best practice to ''explain or at least note your objection to each change in the edit summary''. Otherwise, the other editor may reinstate the unaddressed portion of their edit, believing it to be uncontroversial.}}

- [[User:Sdkb|Sdkb]] ([[User talk:Sdkb|talk]]) 08:42, 12 March 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[User talk:Trackinfo/Kyle Kulinski#rfc_58345FA|User talk:Trackinfo/Kyle Kulinski]] expired 2020-04-12 13:01 ===
* Id: 58345FA
* User: Trackinfo/Kyle Kulinski#rfc_58345FA
* Date: 2020-04-12 07:29:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|950473803|MEDIA 950473803}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|950473809|POL 950473809}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|950511767|MEDIA 950511767}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|950511773|POL 950511773}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
At [[#WP:ENTERTAINER]] above, the question, "Does anyone claim that Kulinski does not meet WP:ENTERTAINER?" has resulted in no responses in over a month, during which time Kulinski's total YouTube views have increased by 3% or 21 million. Because of the difficult history of this draft, we should obtain clear consensus before requesting creation again. Therefore, yes or no, does Kulinski meet the [[WP:ENTERTAINER]] notability critera, specifically that he as an "opinion maker," has had a significant role in his YouTube productions, has a large fan base, and has made unique and prolific contributions to political commentary entertainment? For those concerned with recent sources, please note that [https://thehill.com/hilltv/rising/492248-kyle-kulinski-what-went-wrong-for-the-sanders-campaign he continues to be covered as a headliner authority by ''The Hill TV.''] 07:29, 12 April 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Donald Trump#rfc_05354D0|Talk:Donald Trump]] expired 2020-04-13 00:01 ===
* Id: 05354D0
* User: Amorals
* Date: 2020-04-12 22:53:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|950600764|BIO 950600764}}

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|950610197|POL 950610197}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
2 issues of wording have been raised by editors:

'''Issue 1-''' It has been contended that the wording "''over-promised'' testing"is not the most encyclopedic reflection of the RS. The proposed replacement wording is...

      '''Trump also issued conflicting statements on the availability of testing for the virus....afterwards health officials clarified that testing would be available only to those with a doctor's prescription. Yet, many still struggled to get a test even with a doctor's prescription.'''

In '''support''' of this proposed text so far: [[User talk:Markbassett]], [[User talk:Bus stop]], [[User talk:MelanieN]], [[User talk:Bsubprime7]], and myself.

In '''opposition''' of this proposed text so far: [[User talk:SPECIFICO]] and [[User talk:MrX]]


'''Issue 2-'''  Should, "He [Trump] ''"rejected"'' health experts...be rephrased as Trump ''"disregarded?"'' 

*Only one editor has made a clear position known on issue 2 so far. 
[[User:Amorals|Amorals]] ([[User talk:Amorals|talk]]) 22:53, 12 April 2020 (UTC)}}

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
How should Wikipedia cover endorsements of political candidates during elections?
# Wikipedia should exclude endorsements of poltiical candidates during elections.
# Wikipedia should include only those endorsements which are noted by [[WP:RS|reliable independent sources]].
# Wikipedia should continue to include lists of endorsements based on primary sources (e.g. Tweets).
17:59, 15 April 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Millennials#rfc_96B4240|Talk:Millennials]] expired 2020-04-17 06:01 ===
* Id: 96B4240
* User: CherokeeJack1
* Date: 2020-03-18 05:37:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|946121808|SOC 946121808}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|951445444|SOC 951445444}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 I've a proposal to modify the lead of the "Millennials" article from saying,

"Researchers and popular media use the early 1980s as starting birth years and the mid-1990s to early 2000s as ending birth years, with 1981 to 1996 a widely accepted defining range for the generation."

to "Researchers and popular media ''typically'' use the early 1980s as starting birth years and the mid-1990s as ending birth years, with 1981 to 1996 a widely accepted defining range for the generation."

My justification here, as I've mentioned before, is that a whopping 27 sources in this article ended Millennials in the mid 90s. Only 4 sources in the body end the generation in the early 2000s (2000-2003), one of the them (the Census Bureau) even saying they don't officially define Millennials, another (CNN) saying "sometimes 1980‚Äì2000" (emphasis on "sometimes"), and the other two (Elwood Carlson and U.S. PIRG) being outdated sources from when this generation's identity was still heavily in flux.--[[User:CherokeeJack1|CherokeeJack1]] ([[User talk:CherokeeJack1|talk]]) 05:37, 18 March 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Redirects for discussion/Common outcomes#rfc_E46F304|Wikipedia talk:Redirects for discussion/Common outcomes]] expired 2020-04-17 20:01 ===
* Id: E46F304
* User: Steel1943
* Date: 2020-03-18 19:58:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|946211901|POLICY 946211901}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|951568376|POLICY 951568376}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The section which [[WP:XY]] points, in its current state, is confusing. The reason being is that the section stated that "{{Tq|Redirects that could equally point to multiple targets are usually deleted}}", but then the examples it provides are all examples that include the word "and" in a way that joins at least two distinct topics/words. This is misleading since I have recently seen examples where [[WP:XY]] has been cited as a reason for deletion when the nominated redirect only contains ''one word'', and the claim is that the redirect could target multiple targets. With this being said, I propose that one of three resolutions occur ... and I honestly do not care which one, as long as the current state of this section does not remain:
#Change the wording from "{{Tq|Redirects that could equally point to multiple targets are usually deleted}}" to something like "{{Tq|Redirects that '''''contain multiple distinct subjects''''' are usually deleted}}"
#Add examples of RfDs where [[WP:XY]] has been cited where the redirect's title is only one word and/or does not contain a conjunction
#The first option, plus creating a new subsection of [[Wikipedia:Redirects for discussion/Common outcomes]] to reference discussions that are ambiguous but do not contain multiple distinct subjects in its title connected by a conjunction.
...? <small>(This discussion was started earlier than the date this RfC was opened. Please see the next line for the original time stamp.)</small> [[User:Steel1943|<span style="color: #2F4F4F;">'''''Steel1943'''''</span>]] ([[User talk:Steel1943|talk]]) 19:58, 18 March 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Compartmental models in epidemiology#rfc_737FF72|Talk:Compartmental models in epidemiology]] expired 2020-04-18 16:02 ===
* Id: 737FF72
* User: Redav
* Date: 2020-03-19 16:00:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|946344182|SCI 946344182}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|951732969|SCI 951732969}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 In the article, at some points the symbol R is used for the recovered, at other points it is used for the recovered and the deceased. I suspect there may be conditions or assumptions under which no essential mathematical difference arises from this inconsistency. But I prefer to have the definitions clear, and their use consistent. So, could we agree to sticking to defining and using R for recoveries only?[[User:Redav|Redav]] ([[User talk:Redav|talk]]) 16:00, 19 March 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Naming conventions (sportspeople)#rfc_2E5D832|Wikipedia talk:Naming conventions (sportspeople)]] expired 2020-04-18 20:01 ===
* Id: 2E5D832
* User: Steel1943
* Date: 2020-03-19 19:49:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|946378788|STYLE 946378788}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|951771052|STYLE 951771052}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I've been noticing that there are quite a few articles for sports players that play [[Gaelic football]] that use the disambiguator "(Gaelic footballer)" instead of "(footballer)". (See [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Special:Search&limit=100&offset=0&ns0=1&search=Gaelic+footballer&advancedSearch-current={} here] for some examples; most of the examples do not have an equivalent "NAME (footballer)" article in existence.) In the present state of the section at [[Wikipedia:Naming conventions (sportspeople)#Association football (soccer)]], considering that the word "Gaelic" is currently nowhere on [[Wikipedia:Naming conventions (sportspeople)]], the current wording of this guideline states that "footballer" should be used by default.

...Does this need to be changed to state that article titles for players of [[Gaelic football]] should use the "(Gaelic footballer)" disambiguator instead of "(footballer)", or should those titles use "(footballer)" and add that "(footballer)" also applies to players of [[Gaelic football]] if "(footballer)" is not ambiguous otherwise? <small>(Original timestamp on next line.)</small> [[User:Steel1943|<span style="color: #2F4F4F;">'''''Steel1943'''''</span>]] ([[User talk:Steel1943|talk]]) 19:49, 19 March 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Requested moves/Current discussions#rfc_6E17486|Wikipedia:Requested moves/Current discussions]] expired 2020-04-21 04:01 ===
* Id: 6E17486
* User: LaundryPizza03
* Date: 2020-04-21 02:40:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|952208074|TECH 952208074}}

{{rfcquote|text=
</noinclude>  Six different names with five different formats for nine similar templates. It's confusing and frustrating for those who work across projects, especially since there are insufficient redirects. To which title format should these templates be unified? Note that this is an [[WP:RfC|RfC]] ''and'' an [[WP:RM|RM]] because of how important this is. ‚Äì[[User:LaundryPizza03|<b style="color:#77b">Laundry</b><b style="color:#fb0">Pizza</b><b style="color:#b00">03</b>]] ([[User talk:LaundryPizza03|<span style="color:#0d0">d</span>]][[Special:Contribs/LaundryPizza03|<span style="color:#0bf">cÃÑ</span>]]) 02:40, 21 April 2020 (UTC)}}


=== [[Wikipedia:Requested moves/Current discussions (alt)#rfc_ACED400|Wikipedia:Requested moves/Current discussions (alt)]] expired 2020-04-21 04:01 ===
* Id: ACED400
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|952208074|TECH 952208074}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|952216796|TECH 952216796}}
=== [[Template talk:2019‚Äì20 coronavirus pandemic data#rfc_0FAC4A3|Template talk:2019‚Äì20 coronavirus pandemic data]] expired 2020-04-21 07:01 ===
* Id: 0FAC4A3
* User: MarioGom
* Date: 2020-04-07 19:41:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|949663946|HIST 949663946}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|949663949|SCI 949663949}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|952240228|HIST 952240228}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|952240231|SCI 952240231}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
From 27 to 30 March, we ran an RfC that resulted in the split of some territories ([[Template talk:2019‚Äì20 coronavirus pandemic data/Archive 8#New RfC on countries/dependencies|Link to RfC]]). While the decision did lead to a more stable situation, it did not cover all possible territories. These were deferred to a future discussion but no agreement was reached so far ([[Template talk:2019‚Äì20 coronavirus pandemic data/Archive 9#United States source|1]], [[Template talk:2019‚Äì20 coronavirus pandemic data/Archive 9#French overseas regions|2]], [[Template talk:2019‚Äì20 coronavirus pandemic data/Archive 9#Inconsistent Notes: Disputed Territories (Yes, again)|3]], [[Template talk:2019‚Äì20 coronavirus pandemic data/Archive 9#Abkhazia is listed as a country?|4]], [[Special:Permalink/949297092#Luhansk and Donetsk|5]], [[Special:Permalink/949297092#Flags of dependencies (especially those French ones)|6]], [[Special:Permalink/949297092#Lack of clarity and double counting. The same old debate on dependencies|7]], [[Special:Permalink/949297092#√Öland Islands merged back|8]], [[Special:Permalink/949297092#Sahrawi PDR|9]]). After the implementation of the decision, we also faced some implementation problems such as the lack of reliable sources for [[overseas France]] after 26 March ([[Template talk:2019‚Äì20 coronavirus pandemic data/Archive 9#French overseas regions|example discussion]]) or that our criteria for some territories such as √Öland Islands and the Akrotiri and Dhekelia was completely unique and not backed by any reliable source. Further discussions did not lead to any clear consensus to solve these disputes, and the original RfC did not provide enough guidance to solve them either. The goal of this RfC is to agree on more comprehensive criteria for territory listing. --[[User:MarioGom|MarioGom]] ([[User talk:MarioGom|talk]]) 19:41, 7 April 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Template talk:Afd notice#rfc_F9F2DAC|Template talk:Afd notice]] expired 2020-04-21 22:01 ===
* Id: F9F2DAC
* User: LaundryPizza03
* Date: 2020-04-21 02:40:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|952208074|TECH 952208074}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|952367152|TECH 952367152}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
</noinclude>

{{requested move/dated|multiple=yes
|current1=Template:Afd notice|new1=?|current2=Template:Cfd-notify|new2=?|current3=Template:Cfdnotice2|new3=?|current4=Template:RFDNote|new4=?|current5=Template:Tfdnotice|new5=?|current6=Template:Tfmnotice|new6=?|current7=Template:Fdw|new7=?|current8=Template:Fdw-multi|new8=?|current9=Template:Mfd notice|new9=?|}}

* [[:Template:Afd notice]] ‚Üí ?
* [[:Template:Cfd-notify]] ‚Üí ?
* [[:Template:Cfdnotice2]] ‚Üí ?
* [[:Template:RFDNote]] ‚Üí ?
* [[:Template:Tfdnotice]] ‚Üí ?
* [[:Template:Tfmnotice]] ‚Üí ?
* [[:Template:Fdw]] ‚Üí ?
* [[:Template:Fdw-multi]] ‚Üí ?
* [[:Template:Mfd notice]] ‚Üí ?
‚Äì Six different names with five different formats for nine similar templates. It's confusing and frustrating for those who work across projects, especially since there are insufficient redirects. To which title format should these templates be unified? Note that this is an [[WP:RfC|RfC]] ''and'' an [[WP:RM|RM]] because of how important this is. ‚Äì[[User:LaundryPizza03|<b style="color:#77b">Laundry</b><b style="color:#fb0">Pizza</b><b style="color:#b00">03</b>]] ([[User talk:LaundryPizza03|<span style="color:#0d0">d</span>]][[Special:Contribs/LaundryPizza03|<span style="color:#0bf">cÃÑ</span>]]) 02:40, 21 April 2020 (UTC)}}

Should something be improved [[User:ArtemevaMariia|ArtemevaMariia]] ([[User talk:ArtemevaMariia|talk]]) 08:14, 21 April 2020 (UTC)}}


=== [[Talk:People's Mujahedin of Iran#rfc_1290564|Talk:People's Mujahedin of Iran]] expired 2020-04-21 23:01 ===

=== [[Talk:Dave Fanning#rfc_F2DA931|Talk:Dave Fanning]] expired 2020-04-25 15:01 ===
* Id: F2DA931
* User: Y2kcrazyjoker4
* Date: 2020-03-26 14:27:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|947473274|MEDIA 947473274}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|953066177|MEDIA 953066177}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
A flurry of edits have been made to this article, on [[Dave Fanning]], in the last month from two users: {{usertcb|johnoil9}} and {{usertcb|Davefanning12}}. While that in itself is not very noteworthy, it's a bit curious that for both accounts, no edits have been made to any other page on Wikipedia. This makes me slightly suspicious that it is the same person using multiple accounts. Per [[WP:MULTIPLE]], it is preferable that users not use multiple accounts (or disclose it where necessary) to avoid sockpuppetry issues. What also has me a little suspicious is the activity coming from Davefanning12. Several photos have been uploaded to Wikimedia Commons by this user that depict Fanning with prominent musicians ([https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Dave_Fanning_and_U2_in_studio.jpg U2], [https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Dave_and_Bono.jpg Bono], [https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Dave_and_Billie_Eilish.jpg Billie Eilish]). The photos appear to be from Fanning's personal collection (the photo with Eilish was originally posted by the real-life Fanning [https://twitter.com/fanningrte/status/1167503883649855488/photo/1 in a tweet]). And the Commons file pages claim that they are the user Davefanning12's own work. So I see two possibilities: 1.) this user is just a fan of Fanning and improperly uploaded copyrighted, [[WP:NONFREE]] images to Commons, or 2.) the user is actually Fanning and owns the rights to the images but is creating a [[WP:COI|conflict of interest]] by editing his own page. I would appreciate others opinions on this. [[User:Y2kcrazyjoker4|Y2Kcrazyjoker4]] ([[User talk:Y2kcrazyjoker4|talk]] &bull;  [[Special:Contributions/Y2kcrazyjoker4|contributions]]) 14:27, 26 March 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[User talk:BunbunYU/StudyingWikiCommons#rfc_8CCB912|User talk:BunbunYU/StudyingWikiCommons]] expired 2020-04-25 19:01 ===
* Id: 8CCB912
* User: BunbunYU/StudyingWikiCommons#rfc_8CCB912
* Date: 2020-04-25 01:34:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|952977645|PROJ 952977645}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|953107997|PROJ 953107997}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
==RFC'''

Hi there! We are proposing a research project to study the intersection between Wikimedia Commons and the needs and goals of other Wikimedia projects. We have four research questions: 
#What are the goals of the Commons?
#What are the goals of Commons curators (editors), and how do they participate to improve Commons?
#How do the goals of Commons curators (editors) align with the needs and goals of other Wikimedia projects?
#How do editors of other Wikimedia projects leverage the content of Commons to improve the quality of their projects?
We‚Äôd like to invite individual Commons Curators and Wikipedia Editors for a ~45 min interview to talk about their experience with contributing to Commons and/or using multimedia contents from Commons to illustrate other projects. Please help review our project page. Any comments/critics from the community would be appreciated! 

[[User:BunbunYU|BunbunYU]] ([[User talk:BunbunYU|talk]]) 01:34, 25 April 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Article titles#rfc_E8C2551|Wikipedia talk:Article titles]] expired 2020-04-26 04:01 ===
* Id: E8C2551
* User: King of Hearts
* Date: 2020-04-25 03:17:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|952993946|STYLE 952993946}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|952993948|POLICY 952993948}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|958313580|STYLE 958313580}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|958313584|POLICY 958313584}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
It has been long-standing policy to disambiguate only when necessary, and otherwise choose a title that best incorporates the naming principles described at [[WP:CRITERIA]]. The logical conclusion of this, is that [[WP:PARENDIS|parenthetical disambiguation]] is not permitted unless the base title contains a disambiguation page, another article (i.e. the [[WP:PTOPIC|primary topic]]), or a [[WP:PRIMARYREDIRECT|primary redirect]] to a different page. In particular, the base title is not allowed to be empty or a primary redirect to the aforementioned parenthetically disambiguated title. However, there is a notable exception in [[WP:MUSICSERIES]], which mandates that Haydn's 100th symphony be called [[Symphony No. 100 (Haydn)]] even though he was the only composer to have written 100 notable symphonies, and in fact [[Symphony No. 100]] redirects there. The intuition behind this naming convention is that a name like "Symphony No. 100" is inherently ambiguous and should not contain an article on Haydn's work simply by happenstance. This principle may, perhaps, have relevance outside of generically numbered musical works.

'''Question:''' What is our view on parenthetically disambiguated titles which are not strictly necessary from a disambiguation point of view, but are part of a numbered series whose meaning is inherently ambiguous? [[Ahkam|Borrowing from the Koran]], should they be: 1) '''required'''; 2) '''recommended'''; 3) '''permitted'''; 4) '''discouraged'''; or 5) '''prohibited'''? Examples and further explanation to follow. [[User:King of Hearts|King of]] [[User:King of Hearts|<font color="red">&hearts;</font>]] [[User talk:King of Hearts|<font color="red">&diams;</font>]] [[Special:Contributions/King of Hearts|<font color="black">&clubs;</font>]] &spades; 03:17, 25 April 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:2020 coronavirus pandemic in the United States#rfc_89E7363|Talk:2020 coronavirus pandemic in the United States]] expired 2020-04-26 07:01 ===
* Id: 89E7363
* User: JoelleJay
* Date: 2020-04-19 07:38:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|951857848|HIST 951857848}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|951857855|POL 951857855}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|951857859|SOC 951857859}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|953209195|HIST 953209195}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|953209201|POL 953209201}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|953209204|SOC 953209204}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Where in the article should the [[Template:2019-20 coronavirus pandemic data/United States medical cases chart|total US cases chart]] and the [[Template:2019-20 coronavirus pandemic data/U.S. cases by state|US cases by state table]] be located? At the [[2020_coronavirus_pandemic_in_the_United_States#Statistics|end of the article]] in the Statistics section as they are currently, or in a section at the beginning of the article (example revision is here[[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2020_coronavirus_pandemic_in_the_United_States&oldid=951790039#Current_number_of_non-repatriated_cases_by_state_and_territory|beginning]])? Are the data in these templates informative/relevant/compelling enough to readers to warrant being in the first section? [[User:JoelleJay|JoelleJay]] ([[User talk:JoelleJay|talk]]) 07:38, 19 April 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Gay anthem#rfc_795F830|Talk:Gay anthem]] expired 2020-04-26 16:01 ===
* Id: 795F830
* User: JDDJS
* Date: 2020-03-27 15:09:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|947659362|MEDIA 947659362}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|953276536|MEDIA 953276536}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I'm proposing to remove the  "List of historically significant gay anthem songs" from this article. The table provides no context to entries. It doesn't explain what qualifies as them as a Gay Anthem (a lot of them weren't written to have LGBT themes, so without the context explaining how they became gay anthems anyway is leading out important information). The years are misleading because a lot of these songs became gay anthems years/decades after being released. And there's nothing to explain why these songs are historically significant, which a lot of them aren't. I would support a section in prose which includes a smaller list of noteworthy of gay anthems that provides context to how they became gay anthems and why they're particularly significantly. <span style="color:green;">[[User:JDDJS|<span style="color:green;">JDDJS</span>]] ([[User talk:JDDJS|<span style="color:purple;">talk to me</span>]] ‚Ä¢ [[Special:Contributions/JDDJS|<span style="color:purple;">see what I've done</span>]])</span> 15:09, 27 March 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:List of Australian bushfire seasons#rfc_70A62A8|Talk:List of Australian bushfire seasons]] expired 2020-04-26 19:01 ===
* Id: 70A62A8
* User: Skyring
* Date: 2020-03-27 18:53:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|947666752|HIST 947666752}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|947666756|TECH 947666756}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|960256685|HIST 960256685}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|960256690|TECH 960256690}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
In new Australian bushfire season articles, how do we indicate end dates?
* '''By Season''' As per longstanding practice in articles from [[2002‚Äì03 Australian bushfire season|2002/03]] to [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2018%E2%80%9319_Australian_bushfire_season&oldid=939946593 20018/19]. eg. "Winter (June) 2015 ‚Äì Autumn (May) 2016" or slight variations.
* '''By Dates''' As per previous practice to list the beginning and end of significant fires, such as [[1974‚Äì75 Australian bushfire season]] eg. "October 1974 ‚Äì February 1975"

Sourcing for bushfire season is as per [http://www.bom.gov.au/weather-services/fire-weather-centre/bushfire-weather/index.shtml Bureau of Meteorology]. Sourcing for dates is per RS pertinent to that year. More information and many sources may be found at [[Bushfires_in_Australia#Seasonality]] --[[User:Skyring|Pete]] ([[User talk:Skyring|talk]]) 18:53, 27 March 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Trauma trigger#rfc_F5CF5B4|Talk:Trauma trigger]] expired 2020-04-26 21:01 ===

* User: Pengortm
* Date: 2020-03-27 21:00:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|947682545|SCI 947682545}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|947682556|POL 947682556}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|953327564|SCI 953327564}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|953327565|POL 953327565}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 Should the article include a summary of the opinions of scientists about trigger warnings that are in the body of the article in the lead (see [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Trauma_trigger#Trigger_warning_-_medical_consensus] for extensive previous discussion)? One editor thinks several relevant scientists being critical of trigger warnings should be included in the lead. Another editor thinks [[WP:MEDRS]] means criticism should only be included after more peer reviewed research is conducted and the non peer-reviewed opinions of these scientists should not be summarized in the lead. UPDATE: Two editors have the opinion that the current body is missing content and that the body of the article needs to be focused on first before attempting to summarize in the lead.  -[[User:Pengortm|Pengortm]] ([[User talk:Pengortm|talk]]) 21:00, 27 March 2020 (UTC)}}

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
{{Infobox royalty
 |name         = Whatshisname IV{{cisb|uncollapse me|titlestyle=background-color:transparent}}
 |succession   = Archduke of alignment
 |moretext     = {{Infobox|child=yes
 |headerstyle  = line-height:1.3em;font-weight:normal;
 |header1      = '''Reign'''
 |header2      = 22 September 1848 ‚Äì 12 September 1866}}
 |successor    = You, me, everyone
 |succession1  = [[Special:MyPage|Sultan of short syllables]]
 |reign1       = 22 April 1848 ‚Äì 12 June 1866
 |succession2  = [[Special:MyPage|Lord of line handling]]
 |reign2       = 22 September 1848&nbsp;‚Äì {{nowr|12 September 1866}}
 |succession3  = [[Special:MyPage|Baron of bad wrapping]]
 |reign3       = 22 September 1848 ‚Äì 12 September 1866
 |pre-type3    = &nbsp;
 |predecessor3 = 22 September 1848 ‚Äì 12 May 1866{{cise}}
}}

{{rfcquote|text=
Does [[Sydney]]'s page warrant a montage featuring known or recognisable landmarks and attractions? It is very hard to quantify those who support, because while they have been vocal about their support, they are not as vehement in their agenda as those who oppose the montage, who I believe receive pings or updates every time a new discussion is raised about said montage. === [[Talk:Ethosuximide#rfc_57EC1EC|Talk:Ethosuximide]] expired 2020-04-30 01:01 ===
* Id: 57EC1EC
* User: Doc James
* Date: 2020-03-31 00:37:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|948257410|SCI 948257410}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|953972964|SCI 953972964}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
We have the sentence "As of 2008 it was generally affordable in many areas of the world."

Based on a [https://www.google.com/books/edition/The_Treatment_of_Epilepsy/vFQFePTM-oAC?hl=en&gbpv=1&dq=Ethosuximide+cost&pg=PA147  2008 textbook from Wiley on Epilepsy] that states {{quote|In 28 countries, which contain over 40% of the world population, the per capita annual gross nation product barely suffices to buy a year's supply of carbamazepine or valproate for one or two patients... For most patients living in these countries, only phenobarbital, phenytoin, and ethosuximdie may be avaliable at prices affordable by the general population, and many of the newer drugs may not be avaliable at all.}} [[User:Doc James|<span style="color:#0000f1">'''Doc James'''</span>]] ([[User talk:Doc James|talk]] ¬∑ [[Special:Contributions/Doc James|contribs]] ¬∑ [[Special:EmailUser/Doc James|email]]) 00:37, 31 March 2020 (UTC)}}

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|954140867|MEDIA 954140867}}

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the sentence "It is produced by [[Nelvana]]." be included in the lede? It is one of the most important pieces of information about the show, but the lede currently only lists the US broadcaster and not the Canadian studio that makes the show. [[User:Guillyman|Guillyman]] ([[User talk:Guillyman|talk]]) 21:54, 30 April 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Rules for Fools#rfc_526FAC7|Wikipedia talk:Rules for Fools]] expired 2020-05-02 00:02 ===
* Id: 526FAC7
* User: Mz7
* Date: 2020-04-01 23:50:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|948673635|POLICY 948673635}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|948673638|PROP 948673638}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|954350086|POLICY 954350086}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|954350093|PROP 954350093}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I am consolidating all of the RfCs on this page into one. They all relate to April Fools' Day. They are:
*Edit warring and vandalism on individual years' April Fools page
*Rules regarding joke AfDs should apply to Requested moves, mergers, splits, and RfDs as well
*No pranks on mainspace and help talk pages or Wikiproject pages
*Blanket ban on joke XfD
*Blanket ban on joke adminship/de-adminship/bureaucratship requests
*Restrict all April Fools activities apart from [[WP:AFMP]] to subpages of [[Wikipedia:April Fools]]
*Let the [[Wikipedia:Department of Fun|Department of Fun]] organise April Fools
*[[#Require disclosure of jokes on the Main Page|Revoke the Main Page's exemption from the disclosure requirement]] <sup>Added by {{user|Sdkb}}</sup>
[[User:Mz7|Mz7]] ([[User talk:Mz7|talk]]) 23:50, 1 April 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Naming conventions (Chinese)#rfc_5306A96|Wikipedia talk:Naming conventions (Chinese)]] expired 2020-05-02 02:01 ===
* Id: 5306A96
* Date: 2020-04-02 01:10:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|948621846|POL 948621846}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|948621849|STYLE 948621849}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|954366532|POL 954366532}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|954366536|STYLE 954366536}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Hello everybody, there was a [[Talk:2019‚Äì20_coronavirus_pandemic_in_mainland_China#Requested_move_27_March_2020|request]] to move "2019‚Äì20 coronavirus pandemic in mainland China" to "2019‚Äì20 coronavirus pandemic in China". There was a '''clear consensus not to move'''. Because arguments there doesn't necessarily constrain to the virus page only, I want to request for comments from the community if we can apply it to all pages


Should we use "mainland China" instead of "China" in article titles, given that the article covers area under the direct jurisdiction of the [[People's Republic of China]] only and excludes the [[special administrative regions]] of [[Hong Kong]] and [[Macau]] and the [[Political status of Taiwan|disputed]] [[Taiwan]]. 

Please, have a say! -- [[User:Akira_CA|<span style="color:#DD0000;">'''Akira'''</span>]]üòº[[User_talk:Akira_CA|<span style="color:#000080;">'''CA'''</span>]] 01:10, 2 April 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Nova Scotia killings#rfc_D2C4566|Talk:Nova Scotia killings]] expired 2020-05-02 19:01 ===
* Id: D2C4566
* Revisions affecting this RFC:

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|956180226|POL 956180226}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|956180230|SOC 956180230}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|956180232|STYLE 956180232}}
=== [[Draft talk:Effects of Hurricane Dorian on the United States Mainland#rfc_E3A78ED|Draft talk:Effects of Hurricane Dorian on the United States Mainland]] expired 2020-05-03 07:01 ===
* Id: E3A78ED
* User: Hurricane Noah
* Date: 2020-05-02 21:01:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|954526154|SCI 954526154}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|954682824|SCI 954682824}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
==RfC on the title'''

*'''Note this is not a request for a move/rename, but rather what the name of this and future articles should be'''
Some editors and I have a disagreement about the title of the draft article. I moved the page from ''Effects of Hurricane Dorian in the United States'' to its current title per [[WP:PRECISION]] because it excludes US territories (United States Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico). In order to be "in the United States", I feel it must include all affected land that is owned by the United States. Without the territories, I think that that title would create ambiguity. [[List of United States hurricanes]] includes Alaska, Hawaii, and all territories. The other editors feel that United States itself implies only the mainland. I would appreciate feedback on this issue so we can establish a consensus on handling future articles. [[User:Hurricane Noah|<span style="white-space:nowrap;text-shadow:#009200 0.3em 0.4em 1.0em,#009200 -0.2em -0.2em 1.0em;color:#009200"><b>Noah</b></span>]]<sup>[[User talk:Hurricane Noah|<span style="color:#ff0000"><b>Talk</b></span>]]</sup> 21:01, 2 May 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:2020 Nova Scotia attacks#rfc_1993FE2|Talk:2020 Nova Scotia attacks]] expired 2020-05-03 07:01 ===
* Id: 1993FE2
* User: Headbomb
* Date: 2020-04-24 17:29:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|954585092|SOC 954585092}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|954585096|STYLE 954585096}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Basically, should the first sentence begin with something like [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Nova_Scotia_killings&oldid=952883881 this], with the topic first, then the dates (What, Where, When, By Who)
:A) {{xt|<u>Multiple shootings</u> occurred in <u>Nova Scotia</u> <u>during 18‚àí19 April 2020</u>, when <u>Gabriel Wortman</u> engaged in a killing spree throughout various locations.}}
or with something like this [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Nova_Scotia_killings&oldid=952902599 this], with the dates first, then the event (When, By Who, What, Where)
:B) {{xt|<u>On April 18 and 19, 2020, Gabriel Wortman</u> committed <u>multiple shootings</u> and set fires throughout the Canadian province of <u>Nova Scotia</u>.}}
&#32;<span style="font-variant:small-caps; whitespace:nowrap;">[[User:Headbomb|Headbomb]] {[[User talk:Headbomb|t]] ¬∑ [[Special:Contributions/Headbomb|c]] ¬∑ [[WP:PHYS|p]] ¬∑ [[WP:WBOOKS|b]]}</span> 17:29, 24 April 2020 (UTC)}}

Should the {{para|based_on}} parameter in {{t|Infobox film}} on the article credit creators ([[Arnold Drake]], [[Gene Colan]]) of the original team? The film is not based on the original [[Guardians of the Galaxy (1969 team)|1969 team]] but its rehashed [[Guardians of the Galaxy (2008 team)|2008]] version but that shouldn't discount the original work by Drake and Colan especially when you consider that MCU films are mostly based on later stories but original creators are credited in infoboxes. They are not credited in-film but that shouldn't be an issue as them being the original creators is unambiguous. [[User:Gotitbro|Gotitbro]] ([[User talk:Gotitbro|talk]]) 01:30, 4 May 2020 (UTC)}}

* Date: 2020-04-04 21:25:00

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|954903802|STYLE 954903802}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
&#32;
:Should [[Instruction on transliteration of Belarusian geographical names with letters of Latin script]] be promoted to a guideline? It has been a de facto guideline by the United Nations Group of Experts on Geographical Names (UNGEGN) since [http://www.eki.ee/wgrs/rom1_be.htm February 2013]. Let us formalize it now, and thus align with how we treat other languages.--[[User:W|W]] ([[User talk:W|talk]]) 21:25, 4 April 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Cities#rfc_88F8B0A|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Cities]] expired 2020-05-08 14:01 ===
* Id: 88F8B0A
* User: Krazytea
* Date: 2020-04-08 14:00:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|950760484|HIST 950760484}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|950760495|POLICY 950760495}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|955561373|HIST 955561373}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|955561382|POLICY 955561382}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The question whether or not to use relief maps in the infobox for cities has come up often. There seems to be no set guidelines on these policies. For my part the relieft maps are more than a little distracting. Political maps properly show the placement of cities with the various political regions. While a relief map might be of use when commenting on the geography of a city and perhaps lay in that section. I would argue that political maps without relief should be the default. What is the actual policy on this though? It seems to be quite arbitrary on how and when these rules are applied. Thank you for any comment on this MoS for city infoboxes. '''[[User:Krazytea|<span style="color: #FF0000;">Krazytea</span>]]'''<span style="color: #00FF00;">([[User talk:Krazytea|talk]])</span> 14:00, 8 April 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Welcoming committee/Welcome templates#rfc_F986EB4|Wikipedia talk:Welcoming committee/Welcome templates]] expired 2020-05-09 21:01 ===
* Id: F986EB4
* User: Naypta
* Date: 2020-05-09 07:52:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|955696927|TECH 955696927}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|955696931|PROP 955696931}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|955792754|TECH 955792754}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|955792755|PROP 955792755}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
[[Template:Welcome|The main welcome template]] was recently updated to a new style with a small set of large buttons, following [[Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)#Proposal to streamline the welcome template|discussion on the topic at the Village Pump]]. There has been discussion over whether, in the spirit of [[WP:CONSOLIDATE]], other welcome templates should be adjusted to become wrapper templates, either of [[Template:Welcome]] itself or any of a number of ''core'' templates.

The request for comment in this venue is specifically on the below questions:

'''Should all but a ''core'' of welcome templates become wrappers of members of that core?'''
* If so: {{ordered list|type=lower-latin
  | what should be the defining characteristic of the core?
  | which templates should wrap which?
}}
* If not: {{ordered list|start=3|type=lower-latin
  | is ''any'' modularisation of the templates a good idea?
  | how should welcome templates be kept in sync with each other - should they be at all?
}}

[[User:Naypta|Naypta]] ‚ò∫ &#124; <small>[[User talk:Naypta|‚úâ talk page]]</small> &#124; 07:52, 9 May 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Gothic architecture#rfc_5B88674|Talk:Gothic architecture]] expired 2020-05-09 23:01 ===
* Id: 5B88674
* User: GPinkerton
* Date: 2020-04-09 22:16:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|950044437|HIST 950044437}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|950044438|MEDIA 950044438}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|950044442|RELI 950044442}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|955810877|HIST 955810877}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|955810881|MEDIA 955810881}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|955810884|RELI 955810884}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This article is twice the size any article ought to be. It furthermore harps on excessively on ecclesiastical Gothic - misleadingly titled "cathedrals" - to the exclusion of other types and uses of this type of architecture. This discussion deserves a new page, under Gothic Churches, which would also discuss those Gothic churches that are deemed cathedrals. I have requested the split, but the article also has numerous other issues and faults. It is primarily the doing of two editors, whose edits and additions dwarf the content added by anyone else, and the article, which is a popular one, and its talk page, require attention from other editors for balance and objectivity. [[User:GPinkerton|GPinkerton]] ([[User talk:GPinkerton|talk]]) 22:16, 9 April 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Requests for comment/2020 left sidebar update#rfc_13223D6|Wikipedia:Requests for comment/2020 left sidebar update]] expired 2020-05-10 22:01 ===
* Id: 13223D6
* User: Sdkb
* Date: 2020-04-10 21:46:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|950225495|STYLE 950225495}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|950225500|TECH 950225500}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|950225502|PROP 950225502}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|955983142|STYLE 955983142}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|955983145|TECH 955983145}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|955983146|PROP 955983146}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
[[File:Annotated Wikipedia Vector interface (logged-out).png|thumb|An annotated version of the Wikipedia Vector interface as a logged-out user, with the main sidebar at left]]
This {{Abbr|RfC|Request for Comment}} consists of a series of independent proposals to modify the sidebar located on the left side of every page in the desktop default [[Wikipedia:Skin|skin]] view of Wikipedia (encoded at [[MediaWiki:Sidebar]]), aimed at improving usability and ease of navigation.

It is being launched and listed on the [[Wikipedia:Centralized discussion|centralized discussion]] template (among other places) following a [[Special:PermanentLink/950222091#Updating the left sidebar|half-month incubation period at the Village Pump Idea Lab]].

You may participate by !voting in the polls or contributing to the discussion section under each proposal, or by adding new proposals. [[WP:Refactoring|Refactoring]] may be done as needed to keep this RfC organized. ‚Äì <span style="color:#AAA"><small>&#123;{u&#124;</small><span style="border-radius:9em;padding:0 5px;background:#088">[[User:Sdkb|<span style="color:#FFF">'''Sdkb'''</span>]]</span><small>}&#125;</small></span>‚ÄØ<sup>[[User talk:Sdkb|'''talk''']]</sup> 21:46, 10 April 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_6B755A1|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2020-05-11 14:01 ===
* Id: 6B755A1
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|955998392|UNSORTED 955998392}}
=== [[Wikipedia talk:Article titles#rfc_FBB3C5B|Wikipedia talk:Article titles]] expired 2020-05-11 15:01 ===
* Id: FBB3C5B
* User: SilkTork
* Date: 2020-04-11 14:55:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|950335700|MEDIA 950335700}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|956107012|MEDIA 956107012}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The Television Wikiproject have a strong consensus to default to official titles rather than common names per this discussion: [[Wikipedia_talk:WikiProject_Television#Episode_title_discussion]]. The RfC was notified here among other venues, so the assumption is that the matter has broad consensus. As such, if it is agreed that there is a broad consensus, it would be appropriate to make some form of amendment to the policy to indicate that [[WP:COMMONNAME]] does not apply to television programmes. I am not advocating one way or another, but setting this up so there is some clarity on the issue and prevent conflict between community policy and WikiProject practise. 

The question is: Should WP:COMMONNAME be amended to allow television episodes to default to official titles? [[User:SilkTork|SilkTork]] ([[User talk:SilkTork|talk]]) 14:55, 11 April 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Non-free content#rfc_BEB4F70|Wikipedia talk:Non-free content]] expired 2020-05-11 19:01 ===
* Id: BEB4F70
* User: Mike Peel
* Date: 2020-04-11 18:44:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|950372656|POLICY 950372656}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|956147735|POLICY 956147735}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 
We use [[Wikipedia:Non-free content|non-free content]] to illustrate articles where no freely licensed image is available. These files have limited usage due to legal restrictions, and they have to be locally uploaded as they are not allowed on Commons (or a number of other language Wikipedias). However, they can still have the same filenames as images on Commons, and when that happens, the local file gets priority over the one from Commons, which can cause legal issues from automated bot edits (e.g., [[Wikipedia:Bots/Noticeboard#Re-examination of ListeriaBot|Listeria]]) or other automatic transclusions, or if a local non-free image is uploaded to the same filename as a popular freely-licensed image. Additionally, it is not clear for reusers of our content that images are not freely licenced when looking at their filenames, which may cause downstream legal problems. It is also not clear when looking at article wikitext that the images aren't freely licenced, which may mean that we are using non-free content where we could be using freely-licensed content instead.

I proposes that all non-free media, i.e., those using {{tl|Non-free media}}, are renamed to include '(non-free)' in their filenames - or a similar phrase that is unlikely to be used in Commons filenames. This can be automatically changed by bot (which I can write and operate if there is consensus to do so), and will affect around 650,000 non-free files and their uses in a similar number of articles. Additionally, [[Wikipedia:Non-free content#Policy]] would be modified to add an 11th criteria: "Clear filename: the filename must include '(non-free)' to indicate that it is not freely-licenced". This will avoid non-free files shadowing commons files in the future; the accidental use of non-free files when trying to include freely-licensed files; and will generally make it more obvious that the use of these files is restricted. Thanks. [[User:Mike Peel|Mike Peel]] ([[User talk:Mike Peel|talk]]) 18:44, 11 April 2020 (UTC)}}

*''Option 2'': Unclear or additional considerations apply
*''Option 3'': Generally unreliable for factual reporting
*''Option 4'': Publishes false or fabricated information

=== [[Talk:Ehsan Sehgal#rfc_1561C9F|Talk:Ehsan Sehgal]] expired 2020-05-17 16:01 ===
* Id: 1561C9F

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Catholicism#rfc_953CFA4|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Catholicism]] expired 2020-05-17 18:01 ===
* Id: 953CFA4
* User: Elizium23
* Date: 2020-05-13 22:21:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|956540949|BIO 956540949}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|956540960|RELI 956540960}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|956540964|STYLE 956540964}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|962245775|BIO 962245775}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|962245782|RELI 962245782}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|962245788|STYLE 962245788}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Bearing in mind [[MOS:POSTNOM]], in the case of post-nominals indicating membership in a religious institute ({{xt|S.J., O.F.M., C.Ss.R.}}, etc) where in an article is it proper to attach these to people's names?
#In the lede section of this person's biography.
#When the article specifically brings up the post-nominals to discuss them. {{xt|he joined the Society of Jesus and therefore received the right to place "S.J." after his name}}
#Anywhere the person is mentioned in a list.
#In an infobox.
#Anywhere the person is mentioned in prose, even in an article not about him or her.
#Other times (specify).
Submitted for your consideration by [[User:Elizium23|Elizium23]] ([[User talk:Elizium23|talk]]) 22:21, 13 May 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_F095617|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2020-05-18 04:01 ===
* Id: F095617
* Date: 2020-05-11 16:39:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|956315754|MEDIA 956315754}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|957920990|MEDIA 957920990}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There was [[Talk:ContraPoints#"Controversies"|a discussion back in January]] on the talk page of the article for [[ContraPoints]], in which the reliability of [https://www.pride.com/ Pride.com] was briefly discussed. In the discussion, I asserted that the reliability of the website should probably be taken on a case-by-case basis. The site is said to [https://web.archive.org/web/20180130204433/http://www.magazine.org/industry-news/press-releases/member-press-releases/here-media-introduces-pridecom prominently feature user-submitted content], but it also has an editorial director, and features content by established figures. For example, [https://twitter.com/jessiegender Jessie Earl], who has also written for ''[[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]]'', has written articles for Pride.com. Fellow editor [[User:Bilorv|Bilorv]] agreed that the Pride.com article used on the ContraPoints page was an acceptable source in that case. However, I'd like more editors to weigh in, so perhaps a consensus regarding the site's status as generally reliable, generally unreliable, or marginally reliable could be listed at [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Perennial sources|WP:RSP]]. This is my first time starting a discussion on this noticeboard, so I hope I'm doing this correctly. ‚Äî'''''[[User:MatthewHoobin|<span style="color:#0640e0; text-shadow:#66ff66 0.2em 0.2em 0.4em;">Matthew</span>]]''''' - <span style="font-size:80%">([[User_talk:MatthewHoobin|talk]])</span> 16:39, 11 May 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Richard Nixon#rfc_E18283C|Talk:Richard Nixon]] expired 2020-05-20 03:01 ===
* Id: E18283C
* User: Rowsdower45
* Date: 2020-04-20 02:41:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|952006212|STYLE 952006212}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|957693941|STYLE 957693941}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Please see the above section of this talk page, and the relevant edits in which the above user takes the position that terms such as "president" and "vice president" should be in lower-case when used in [[Template:Infobox officeholder]] and certain inline contexts. I admit I can't find the exact words to explain why we do what we do, but I believe my interpretation of [[MOS:JOBTITLES]] is closer to being accurate than theirs, and that their interpretation would require a radical change in the way we stylize articles on elected officials. [[User:Rowsdower45|Rowsdower45]] ([[User talk:Rowsdower45|talk]]) 02:41, 20 April 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_0911A25|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2020-05-21 04:01 ===
* Id: 0911A25
* User: Kaldari
* Date: 2020-05-11 16:07:00

[https://www.peopo.org/ PeoPo.org] is a Chinese (Taiwanese?) "citizen journalism platform" "encouraging citizens to register as users and report on public issues".[https://www.peopo.org/events/about/english/P2.htm] In other words, it is a site for user-generated content, which according to [[WP:USERGENERATED]] is "generally unacceptable". I tried [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=North%E2%80%93South_divide_in_Taiwan&type=revision&diff=944940971&oldid=944251998 removing it as a citation] from [[North‚ÄìSouth divide in Taiwan]], but was reverted and asked to bring the issue here. === [[Wikipedia talk:Content translation tool#rfc_7326C1E|Wikipedia talk:Content translation tool]] expired 2020-05-21 06:01 ===
* Id: 7326C1E
* User: HaussmannSaintLazare
* Date: 2020-04-21 05:42:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|952299477|PROJ 952299477}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|957936228|PROJ 957936228}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
It is not possible to use machine translation in the English version of Content translation tool today (in April 2020).

However, this rule has not been changed in response to the January 2019 contract between GOOGLE and Wikimedia Foundation regarding GOOGLE translate.

Therefore, perhaps it assume Yandex translate which could be used before January 2019.

Comparing Yandex and GOOGLE translations, from my experience Yandex translation is awful (maybe it depends on the source and destination languages).
However, according to my experience, the GOOGLE translation into English is considerably higher quality than the GOOGLE translation into Japanese, and I (a non-English speaker and an English beginner) can understand the translated text. Therefore, when translating from other language to Japanese, in parallel I make English translation using GOOGLE translation. (I posted some text of them to DRAFT, as you can see in my post history)
I know, of course, that the translated text produced by GOOGLE Translator are not sufficient for English speakers.
However, I consider that an English-speaking person can correct an English expression by reading the English sentence created by the translation, even if he or she has little knowledge about the source language.
Therefore, I propose to enable machine translation for DRAFT and user page. I don't propose to enable machine translation for the standard space because I think some improvements by English speakers (as described above) should be done.

Thank you !!!

--[[User:HaussmannSaintLazare|HaussmannSaintLazare]] ([[User talk:HaussmannSaintLazare|talk]]) 05:42, 21 April 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Joe Biden sexual assault allegation#rfc_3CA4ACA|Talk:Joe Biden sexual assault allegation]] expired 2020-05-21 19:01 ===
* Id: 3CA4ACA
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|958033655|BIO 958033655}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|958033670|MEDIA 958033670}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|958033678|POL 958033678}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|958033681|SOC 958033681}}
=== [[Wikipedia talk:Naming conventions (chemistry)#rfc_3E3D41A|Wikipedia talk:Naming conventions (chemistry)]] expired 2020-05-22 00:02 ===
* Id: 3E3D41A
* User: King of Hearts
* Date: 2020-04-21 23:57:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|952386402|SCI 952386402}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|952386408|STYLE 952386408}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|958103316|SCI 958103316}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|958103320|STYLE 958103320}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Currently, [[Wikipedia:Naming conventions (chemistry)#Use of Stock nomenclature]] states:
<blockquote>Stock nomenclature should not be used for compounds with mixed or non-integral oxidation numbers: hence {{xt|{{nowrap|triiron tetraoxide}}}} ''not'' {{!xt|{{nowrap|iron(II,III) oxide}}}} (in fact, this article is difficult to name and, as an exception, redirects to [[magnetite]]).</blockquote>
The section on [[stock nomenclature]] has existed since [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wikipedia%3ANaming_conventions_%28chemistry%29&type=revision&diff=18320566&oldid=16660257 July 2005]. However, one can see that there, in fact, does exist an article at [[Iron(II,III) oxide]] which is distinct from the [[Magnetite]] article and it was created in [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Iron%28II%2CIII%29_oxide&type=revision&diff=207144589&oldid=32825194 April 2008]. So for 12 years, apparently no one (apart from [[User:Double sharp|Double sharp]] above) has noticed this discrepancy in the very example that the guideline is trying to use to illustrate what not to do, suggesting that the guideline is not being enforced in practice. So what do we do here? I see several possibilities:
# Stock nomenclature #5 does not represent current community consensus, and should be struck or modified.
# [[Iron(II,III) oxide]] should be moved to [[Triiron tetraoxide]] to comply with the guideline.
# [[Iron(II,III) oxide]] should be merged into [[Magnetite]] to comply with the guideline.
I don't have a strong view but the current situation is rather risible. [[User:King of Hearts|King of]] [[User:King of Hearts|<font color="red">&hearts;</font>]] [[User talk:King of Hearts|<font color="red">&diams;</font>]] [[Special:Contributions/King of Hearts|<font color="black">&clubs;</font>]] &spades; 23:57, 21 April 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Michael Flynn#rfc_4A848FE|Talk:Michael Flynn]] expired 2020-05-22 05:01 ===
* Id: 4A848FE
* User: Korny O&#39;Near

On April 24, 2020, there was a release of previously-unseen documents relating to the investigation of Michael Flynn, including one that shows that, before the meeting with Flynn, one FBI agent had written, "What's our goal? === [[Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)#rfc_D4E67F3|Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)]] expired 2020-05-22 16:01 ===
* Id: D4E67F3
* User: Pintoch
* Date: 2020-04-23 19:02:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|952728788|STYLE 952728788}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|952728795|TECH 952728795}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|958227199|STYLE 958227199}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|958227205|TECH 958227205}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I propose to change the behaviour of the [[Help:Citation Style 1|CS1]]/[[Help:Citation Style 2|2]] citation templates: the auto-linking mechanism (which provides a default value for {{para|url}} when {{para|pmc}} is available) would also cover {{para|doi}} with {{para|doi-access|free}}.

In short: if {{para|url}}, {{para|chapter-url}} and {{para|pmc}} are not set, but {{para|doi}} and {{para|doi-access|free}} are set, the title of the citation would be linked using the DOI.

'''Example'''

With the following code:

<code><nowiki>
{{cite journal |author1= Hoffman S.J. |author2=Lavis J.N. |author3=Bennett S. | year = 2009 | title = The Use of Research Evidence in Two International Organizations' Recommendations about Health Systems | journal = Healthcare Policy | volume = 5 | issue = 1| pages = 66‚Äì86 | doi = 10.12927/hcpol.2009.21005 | doi-access = free }}
</nowiki></code>

You would get the same result as if {{para|url|https://doi.org/10.12927/hcpol.2009.21005}} was set:

* {{cite journal |author1= Hoffman S.J. |author2=Lavis J.N. |author3=Bennett S. | year = 2009 | title = The Use of Research Evidence in Two International Organizations' Recommendations about Health Systems | journal = Healthcare Policy | volume = 5 | issue = 1| pages = 66‚Äì86 | doi = 10.12927/hcpol.2009.21005 | doi-access = free | url = https://doi.org/10.12927/hcpol.2009.21005 |ref=none}}

‚àí [[User:Pintoch|Pintoch]] ([[User talk:Pintoch|talk]]) 19:02, 23 April 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Football#rfc_FDB2227|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Football]] expired 2020-05-23 03:01 ===
* Id: FDB2227
* User: SportingFlyer
* Date: 2020-05-08 22:49:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|955639444|SOC 955639444}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|958313577|SOC 958313577}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This affects multiple pages, so I thought this would be the best place for a discussion.

We have always used a stadium's actual location instead of the official FIFA host city in the venue tables, for example, [[Pontiac, Michigan]] instead of [[Detroit]] for the [[Pontiac Silverdome]]. On [[1994 FIFA World Cup]], [[1999 FIFA Women's World Cup]], and [[2026 FIFA World Cup]], the tables have recently been edited to the names of the official FIFA host cities, so "Detroit" instead of "Pontiac" is displayed more prominently in the table. Both of these are factually true: Detroit was the host city, but games were played in Pontiac. Since this may impact other World Cup articles (for instance, the 2002 world cup shows Miyagi, but the FIFA web site shows Rifu).

Should the table of venues be changed to display the host city, where the host city differs from the stadium location? [[User:SportingFlyer|SportingFlyer]] ''<span style="font-size:small; vertical-align:top;">[[User talk:SportingFlyer|T]]</span>''¬∑''<span style="font-size:small; vertical-align:bottom;">[[Special:Contributions/SportingFlyer|C]]</span>'' 22:49, 8 May 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Layout#rfc_002B742|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Layout]] expired 2020-05-23 19:01 ===
* Id: 002B742
* User: Paradoctor
* Date: 2020-05-23 15:16:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|958401612|POLICY 958401612}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|958426407|POLICY 958426407}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I have encountered [[Talk:Chicken or the egg#Disputed see also entry|the claim]] that adding a link {{tquote|doesn't require a citation}}, even when [[WP:CHALLENGE]]d. (To be clear: I did not ask for an ''inline'' citation, merely that one be provided on the talk page.) Another editor subsequently claimed that [[MOS:SEEALSO]]'s criterion of "editorial judgment and common sense" is among the {{tquote|things that go [...] beyond the verifiabilty principle}}.

My reasoning is that, since See also links have to be relevant, adding a link comes with the implicit claim that the linked topic is relevant to the one at hand. In this particular instance, the stronger claim was made that the linked topic is an instance of the topic linked from. Since [[WP:PROVEIT|all content must be verifiable]], I don't see how See also should escape one of our pillars. That needs to be clarified here, regardless of the outcome of this RfC. [[User:Paradoctor|Paradoctor]] ([[User talk:Paradoctor|talk]]) 15:16, 23 May 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#rfc_DA52CC8|Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)]] expired 2020-05-23 21:01 ===
* Id: DA52CC8
* User: TonyBallioni
* Date: 2020-04-24 21:25:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|952944342|POLICY 952944342}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|958514856|POLICY 958514856}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Since there's a thread at BN about bureaucrat activity, and I've told people the way to solve the problem is by creating an RfC, I'll go ahead and start one. I'm proposing the activity policy for bureaucrats be updated to the following:
{{talkquote|Bureaucrats who do not have qualifying bureaucrat activity within the last two years before will have the bureaucrat permissions removed for inactivity, and may only have the bureaucrat permission restored by a new successful request for bureaucratship. Users will be notified one month prior to removal of their permissions. Qualifying bureaucrat activity shall consist of the following:
*Granting or removing permissions that can only be done by a bureaucrat
*Closing of discussions that are restricted by policy to bureaucrats
*Participation in bureaucrat discussions either as a part for requests for adminship or bureacratship or as a part of ordinary discussions at the bureaucrats' noticeboard.
Simply expressing willingness to participate as a bureaucrat without activity is not considered activity for the purposes of maintaining permissions. Bureaucrats who have their administrator permissions procedurally removed for inactivity will also have the bureaucrat permissions removed, but may request them back if they return to activity and would otherwise qualify as an active bureaucrat.}}
[[User:TonyBallioni|TonyBallioni]] ([[User talk:TonyBallioni|talk]]) 21:25, 24 April 2020 (UTC)}}


=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#rfc_4D6E272|Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)]] expired 2020-05-23 21:01 ===
* Id: 4D6E272
* Date: 2020-04-23 20:26:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|952738321|POLICY 952738321}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|952738323|PROP 952738323}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|958444585|POLICY 958444585}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|958444588|PROP 958444588}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This is a proposal to create a new usergroup, main page editor, as documented at [[Wikipedia:Main page editor]]. In brief, members of the new usergroup will be given the <code>editprotected</code> and <code>protect</code> user rights, which allows editors to edit pages transcluded onto the [[WP:MP|main page]] through [[WP:FULL|full]] and [[WP:CASCADE|cascading protection]]. This will allow editors with this permission to update content on the main page, and to fix errors on it. Details of the proposed mechanisms to grant and remove the right, and restrictions on its use, are at [[Wikipedia:Main page editor]]. If this request is successful, a phabricator request will be initiated, and once completed, [[Wikipedia:Main page editor]] will be changed from a proposal to a policy page and appropriately updated. 

*'''Note''': if [[phab:T71607]] is ever actioned, the <code>protect</code> userright would be replaced with <code>editcascadeprotected</code>. 
<span style="font-family:Papyrus">[[User:Vanamonde93|Vanamonde]] ([[User Talk:Vanamonde93|Talk]])</span> 20:26, 23 April 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:2020 Nova Scotia attacks#rfc_BF8C46B|Talk:2020 Nova Scotia attacks]] expired 2020-05-24 18:02 ===
* Id: BF8C46B
* User: Headbomb
* Date: 2020-04-24 17:29:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|958313580|STYLE 958313580}}

{{rfcquote|text=
Basically, should the first sentence begin with something like [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Nova_Scotia_killings&oldid=952883881 this], with the topic first, then the dates (What, Where, When, By Who)
:A) {{xt|<u>Multiple shootings</u> occurred in <u>Nova Scotia</u> <u>during 18‚àí19 April 2020</u>, when <u>Gabriel Wortman</u> engaged in a killing spree throughout various locations.}}
or with something like this [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Nova_Scotia_killings&oldid=952902599 this], with the dates first, then the event (When, By Who, What, Where)
:B) {{xt|<u>On April 18 and 19, 2020, Gabriel Wortman</u> committed <u>multiple shootings</u> and set fires throughout the Canadian province of <u>Nova Scotia</u>.}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Naming conventions (sportspeople)#rfc_06766A5|Wikipedia talk:Naming conventions (sportspeople)]] expired 2020-05-25 16:01 ===
* Id: 06766A5
* User: King of Hearts
* Date: 2020-04-25 15:41:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|953074504|SOC 953074504}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|953074506|STYLE 953074506}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|958762314|SOC 958762314}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|958762319|STYLE 958762319}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The question is quite simple:
# Suppose there are two people called "John Smith" who are notable for playing the sport known officially as [[Association football]]. One of them is an American soccer player and the other is a British footballer. Is "John Smith (soccer)" and "John Smith (footballer)" adequate parenthetical disambiguation, or do more disambiguators such as nationality or year of birth need to be used?
# Now suppose there are multiple British footballers called "John Smith" who are already disambiguated by their year of birth, but still only one American soccer player. What is the correct parenthetical disambiguation for the American?
Reading the current guideline does not make it clear whether football and soccer are intended to be treated as different sports or the same sport for the purposes of disambiguation. [[User:King of Hearts|King of]] [[User:King of Hearts|<font color="red">&hearts;</font>]] [[User talk:King of Hearts|<font color="red">&diams;</font>]] [[Special:Contributions/King of Hearts|<font color="black">&clubs;</font>]] &spades; 15:41, 25 April 2020 (UTC)}}
