=== [[Talk:Portraits of presidents of the United States#rfc_83A7786|Talk:Portraits of presidents of the United States]] expired 2020-05-25 22:01 ===
* Id: 83A7786
* User: MyPreferredUsernameWasTaken
* Date: 2020-05-09 17:49:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|957552200|MEDIA 957552200}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|957552202|POL 957552202}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|958823745|MEDIA 958823745}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|958823748|POL 958823748}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There are two organizations who raise private funds to commission a presidential portrait. As explained by TIME here, [https://time.com/5140261/official-presidential-portraits-history/ "In more recent history, the money has come from private donations, usually raised by the National Portrait Gallery. (The White House Historical Association has also raised private funds for portraits, but that‚Äôs a separate operation.)"]. Such presidents as Bush 41, Clinton, Bush 43, and Obama have had separate portraits painted by both entities, with Clinton's and Obama's explained within the article.

Should we have a separate list of National Portrait Gallery portraits in this article, with such examples as John Quincy Adams's (above) and James Buchanan's (below). [[User:MyPreferredUsernameWasTaken|MyPreferredUsernameWasTaken]] ([[User talk:MyPreferredUsernameWasTaken|talk]]) 17:49, 9 May 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_8F58BAD|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2020-05-26 04:01 ===
* Id: 8F58BAD
* User: Slugger O&#39;Toole
* Date: 2020-05-16 00:44:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|956916813|RELI 956916813}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|958878865|RELI 958878865}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The [[Catholic News Service]] was established in 1920 by the [[United States Conference of Catholic Bishops]]. It remains sponsored by the bishops. However, they are [https://www.catholicnews.com/services/englishnews/2010/usccb-communications-department-to-undergo-reorganization.cfm "editorially independent and a financially self-sustaining"] department of the bishops' conference (link is to their website but Google seems to think this is true). Their mission is to be "a leading agency for religious news. Our mission is to report fully, fairly and freely on the involvement of the church in the world today. CNS staff members and stringers are professional journalists who adhere to ethical practices and standards of the trade." [https://www.nzcatholic.org.nz/about-us/news-services/ They are] "used by about 240 newspapers, broadcasters and other news outlets in over 35 countries." 

They are established, editorially independent, financially self-sustaining, and trusted around the world. They are also an arm of the United States bishops. So, is CNS a reliable source on Catholic/religious topics? On other topics? --[[User:Slugger O&#39;Toole|Slugger O&#39;Toole]] ([[User talk:Slugger O&#39;Toole|talk]]) 00:44, 16 May 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Racial views of Donald Trump#rfc_99F57A2|Talk:Racial views of Donald Trump]] expired 2020-05-28 01:01 ===
* Id: 99F57A2
* User: Rambo Apocalypse
* Date: 2020-05-26 22:55:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|959052857|BIO 959052857}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|959052861|POL 959052861}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|959284214|BIO 959284214}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
A number of editors have repeatedly removed Donald Trump's directly stated views on racism on the basis that the statements are not credible, or that any racist would say they are not racist or condemn racism.  Others have argued that Trump's directly stated views are highly relevant to a page on Donald Trump's views, and should be featured at least as prominently as his critics' views.

A related issue concerns NPOV, while several of us have argued there are serious POV issues on the page, when the tag is added it is simply removed.

I'm not overly familiar with Wikipedia's rules and policies, so I apologise if this too lengthy or is otherwise inappropriate, but I think this discussion needs some external input.  Attempting to build consensus with the regular editors of this page has got absolutely nowhere.  [[User:Rambo Apocalypse|Rambo Apocalypse]] ([[User talk:Rambo Apocalypse|talk]]) 22:55, 26 May 2020 (UTC)}}

{{rfcquote|text=
'''Question:''' Should [[Dark Phoenix (film)|Dark Phoenix]] contain a statement regarding its box office failure in lede and box office section?

'''Option 1:''' "The film is widely described as a [[box office bomb]] including by USAToday, Hollywood Reporter, Deadline Hollywood, and Variety."<br />

=== [[Talk:Limp Bizkit#rfc_A970809|Talk:Limp Bizkit]] expired 2020-05-30 02:02 ===
* Id: A970809
* User: Xanarki
* Date: 2020-04-30 01:54:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|953981949|MEDIA 953981949}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|959683666|MEDIA 959683666}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Under the ''Discography'' section of the article, Limp Bizkit's major releases are listed; however, their 2005 EP ''The Unquestionable Truth (Part 1)'' is not listed. This is because many editors quickly undo the edits as they think it is against Wikipedia's guidelines. It is true, that Wikipedia says not to include EPs and other non full-length albums; however, the exact quote is: ''"Live and compilation albums, EPs, singles, etc. should generally not be included."'' GENERALLY is the key word here. Another quote from the WikiProject Discographies Style's page: ''"In an ideal situation however, any deviations from the guidelines should be with a clear purpose that is unique to the particular artist and situation in question."'' This supports the fact that the guidelines of not including EPs is NOT set in stone, and that it should be treated on a case-by-case basis. Do you think ''The Unquestionable Truth (Part 1)'' should be listed among the other albums? [[User:Xanarki|Xanarki]] ([[User talk:Xanarki|talk]]) 01:54, 30 April 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:List of ice hockey line nicknames#rfc_6CD3776|Talk:List of ice hockey line nicknames]] expired 2020-05-31 00:02 ===
* Id: 6CD3776
* User: JimKaatFan
* Date: 2020-04-30 23:52:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|954157767|SOC 954157767}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|959862911|SOC 959862911}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
What should the minimum requirement be for listing an ice hockey line in this article?
(these are in order, from most restrictive requirements to least restrictive)

*Option '''A''': Ice hockey line should have its own article in Wikipedia, such as [[Punch line (ice hockey)]] or [[The French Connection (ice hockey)]]
*Option '''B''': Line should be detailed in at least 2 reliable sources, with at least one written '''after''' the era that the line existed (ie, not a contemporaneous account)
*Option '''C''': Line needs only a mention in 1 reliable source
*Option '''D''': No formal requirements.
[[User:JimKaatFan|JimKaatFan]] ([[User talk:JimKaatFan|talk]]) 23:52, 30 April 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Reparative Therapy of Male Homosexuality#rfc_888176A|Talk:Reparative Therapy of Male Homosexuality]] expired 2020-05-31 04:01 ===
* Id: 888176A
* User: Markworthen
* Date: 2020-05-01 05:35:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|954204605|SCI 954204605}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|954204610|POL 954204610}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|959899737|SCI 959899737}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|959899739|POL 959899739}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
'''To what extent should this article discuss the scientific consensus on reparative/conversion therapy's potential harms and benefits?'''

Participants on both sides of this debate believe the other side's preferences would constitute [[WP:UNDUE|undue weight]].{{efn|I hesitate using the word "sides" because it might inaccurately imply a clear demarcation between the beliefs of two diametrically opposed camps, which is not the case. Please read the discussions above. (The entire talk page constitutes the debate.)}} 

One side believes that devoting substantial discussion of the aforementioned scientific consensus to an article about a book constitutes undue weight. 

The other side believes that failure to adequately discuss the medical and psychological consensus constitutes an dereliction of duty (so to speak) to ensure that readers understand that "reparative therapy" is a [[WP:FRINGE|fringe theory]] that harms patients. 

[[User:Markworthen|<span style="color:#539;">&nbsp; - Mark D Worthen PsyD</span>]] [[User talk:Markworthen|<span style="color:#64B;">(talk)</span>]] <small><small>(I'm a man‚Äîtraditional male pronouns are fine.)</small></small> 05:35, 1 May 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Record charts#rfc_1958B62|Wikipedia talk:Record charts]] expired 2020-05-31 10:01 ===
* Id: 1958B62
* User: Coolmarc
* Date: 2020-05-01 09:54:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|954230977|MEDIA 954230977}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|959940432|MEDIA 959940432}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 New rule for Czech Republic and Slovakia charts. As per the [[IFPI]] who publish the Radio Top 100 (airplay) and Single Top 100 (streaming and download sales) for these regions, the Single Top 100 is these regions singles charts. See the [https://www.ifpi.org/downloads/GMR2016.pdf IFPI music report] and [https://themusicnetwork.com/ifpi-global-music-report-digital-is-king/ article in ''[[The Music Network]]''] 

Therefore I am suggesting a rule in line with most other regions charts on [[WP:CHARTS]] that if a song by a foreign artist has charted on the Single Top 100 chart, the Radio Top 100 chart should be omitted. Please be so kind to comment below and advise if you support this suggestion thank you. <b>[[User:Coolmarc|<span style="font-family:tahoma; color:#000000">Cool</span>]][[User talk:Coolmarc|<span style="font-family:tahoma; color:#00BFFF">Marc</span>]]</b> 09:54, 1 May 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Virtue signalling#rfc_798C00F|Talk:Virtue signalling]] expired 2020-05-31 20:02 ===
* Id: 798C00F
* User: Bacondrum
* Date: 2020-05-30 22:48:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|959899745|UNSORTED 959899745}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|960033289|UNSORTED 960033289}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I think the fact that the common use of the term is derogatory or pejorative needs to be included in the lede, it's like leaving "During daylight, the sky appears to be blue" out of the Sky article's lede. Based on this peer reviewed academic source I think we should describe the contemporary, common use as derogatory https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6795490/ quote: "a phenomenon commonly referred to as ‚Äúvirtue signaling‚Äù [51]. Although somewhat neglected in psychological or social-science literature, ‚Äúvirtue signaling‚Äù seems most often to be used as a derogatory term" 
It is used commonly in a derogatory manner, this blatant fact being absent makes the lede read like a victim of Americas culture wars. [[User:Bacondrum|Bacondrum]] ([[User talk:Bacondrum|talk]]) 22:48, 30 May 2020 (UTC)}}

{{rfcquote|text=
Regarding suggestion that Biden sexual assault allegation article needs to include more material concerning accuser's back story. Currently the article contains only material concerning her educational background (see [[Joe Biden sexual assault allegation#Controversy over Reade's educational background]]). But much more has been found of revelance; see for example: 
#[https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/31/us/politics/tara-reade-joe-biden.html nytimes] feature on Reade's background: ''".. Ms. Reade‚Äôs own back story has been caught up in the churn of #MeToo-era politics, as rising questions about her credibility add fuel to the social-media combat between Mr. Biden‚Äôs defenders and detractors. .. Ms. Reade, through her own pluck and smarts and powers of persuasion, overcame an unsettled and abusive childhood to find opportunities on the big stages of acting, politics and law. She won praise for what friends took as a sincere commitment to helping other abuse victims and to animal rescue. .. The Times‚Äôs findings comport with the autobiography Ms. Reade, now 56, has rendered in cinematic detail across blog posts, online essays and court statements. But in the dramatic retelling of her life story she has also shown a tendency to embellish ‚Äî a role as a movie extra is presented as a break; her title of ‚Äústaff assistant‚Äù with clerical responsibilities in Mr. Biden‚Äôs office becomes ‚Äúlegislative assistant‚Äù when his shepherding of the Violence Against Women Act is an asset for her expert-witness testimony in court. .."''
#[[Draft_talk:Tara_Reade#Misc.]] (other material from Associated Press & local papers in CA & WI) <br>--[[User:Hodgdon&#39;s secret garden|Hodgdon&#39;s secret garden]] ([[User talk:Hodgdon&#39;s secret garden|talk]]) 18:08, 1 June 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_ED9E04B|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2020-06-06 09:01 ===
* Id: ED9E04B
* User: Hemiauchenia
* Date: 2020-05-29 15:31:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|959599481|MEDIA 959599481}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|959599486|PROP 959599486}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|959683670|POL 959683670}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|961039674|MEDIA 961039674}}

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|961039681|PROP 961039681}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Which of the following best describes the [[WP:RS|reliability]] of [[Sputnik (news agency)]]? {{duses|Sputniknews.com}} has been cited over 2,000 times on Wikipedia.
*'''Option 1:''' Generally [[WP:RS|reliable]] for factual reporting
*'''Option 2:''' Unclear or additional considerations apply
*'''Option 3:''' Generally [[WP:QUESTIONABLE|unreliable]] for factual reporting
*'''Option 4:''' Publishes false or fabricated information, and should be [[WP:DEPS|deprecated]] as in the [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard/Archive 220#Daily Mail RfC|2017 RfC]] of the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' [[User:Hemiauchenia|Hemiauchenia]] ([[User talk:Hemiauchenia|talk]]) 15:31, 29 May 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_49200B1|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2020-06-06 11:01 ===
* Id: 49200B1
* Date: 2020-05-12 23:12:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|956367658|MEDIA 956367658}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|956367702|PROP 956367702}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|962076810|MEDIA 962076810}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|962076825|PROP 962076825}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Given that references to ''[[Apple Daily]]'' are used in a lot of [[Hong Kong]]-related articles, editors are requested to comment on its reliability.

Please choose from the following options:
*''Option 1'': Generally reliable
*''Option 2'': Reliable, but may require further investigation
*''Option 3'': Unreliable for certain topics (such as those which may be considered controversial)
*''Option 4'': Generally unreliable for factual reporting
*''Option 5'': Publishes incorrect or fake information and should be deprecated.

Thanks. 23:12, 12 May 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_548402A|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2020-06-09 05:01 ===
* Id: 548402A
* User: Graywalls
* Date: 2020-05-29 14:59:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|960371303|SCI 960371303}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|960371306|MEDIA 960371306}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|961351822|PROP 961351822}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|961558833|SCI 961558833}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|961558835|MEDIA 961558835}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|961558838|PROP 961558838}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Hackaday is currently listed in the [[WP:SOURCEGUIDE]] as "no consensus" per the [[Wikipedia:Reliable_sources/Noticeboard/Archive_281#Hackaday|previous discussion]]. In the previous discussion, the editorial policies was not discussed. These policies are posted on their website at https://hackaday.com/policies/

<blockquote>When you contribute content to Hackaday, you retain ownership of the copyright, and you also grant permission to us to display and distribute it. In addition, you are responsible for the content of that material.
Hackaday has no responsibility for the content of any messages or information posted by readers. We, in our sole discretion, may or may not review, edit, or delete from the service any material which we deem to be illegal, offensive or otherwise inappropriate.
The tenor of the projects we feature on the service regularly use items in ways they were not originally intended (hack) and readers must understand the implications of this. Hackaday makes no guarantees or warranties as to the accuracy or completeness of content or the result of accessing and using information on our site. We shall not be liable to anyone for any damages resulting from information found on the service, even if damages are the result of inaccuracy, error, omission, or any other cause.
The opinions expressed by our editors and contributors are their own and not those of Hackaday.
We reserve the right to unpublish or refuse to unpublish anything for any reason or for no reason whatsoever.</blockquote>

With this new information taken in to account, I'd like to reconvene discussion on use of Hackaday as sources. Essentially, the only editorial oversight seems to be that they only choose to host or not host submitted contents. I argue that this source should be considered unreliable for factual accuracy, fair due weight presentation and notability building purposes just like HuffPost and Forbes contributor articles are treated in [[WP:RSP]].  [[User:Graywalls|Graywalls]] ([[User talk:Graywalls|talk]]) 14:59, 29 May 2020 (UTC)}}

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the [[MOS:NOTUSA]] clause: {{tqb|When the United States is mentioned with one or more other countries in the same sentence, {{xt|U.S.}} or {{xt|US}} may be too informal, especially at the first mention or as a noun instead of an adjective ({{xt|France and the United States}}, not {{!xt|France and the U.S.}}).}} be applied to the article? In other words, should instances of {{tq|U.S.}} and {{tq|US}} be replaced with {{tq|United States}} or {{tq|American}} where another country's full name (e.g. {{tq|South Vietnam}} or {{tq|South Vietnamese}}) is mentioned in the same sentence?

Please respond with '''Yes''' or '''No''', with justifications. Thanks. 07:34, 10 May 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:COVID-19 pandemic in Alabama#rfc_3D07061|Talk:COVID-19 pandemic in Alabama]] expired 2020-06-09 16:01 ===
* Id: 3D07061
* User: Raven9nine
* Date: 2020-05-10 15:57:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|956736793|POLICY 956736793}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|961635719|POLICY 961635719}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Specific instance - the Alabama Covid-19 page. [[2020_coronavirus_pandemic_in_Alabama]]

In recent weeks, with the push from business to reopen the economy, the actual daily increase in the number of infected and the daily increase in the number of fatalities have become highly relevent statistics because federal guidelines called for a consistant decrease in those numbers before economies should relax their stay at home directives. These daily statistics had been presented in charts on the wikipedia page as per this older version of the page.
 https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2020_coronavirus_pandemic_in_Alabama&amp;oldid=952992317

I had noticed the stats in those tables had been updated consistantly since the beginning of March but the daily updates suddenly stopped about two weeks ago. I tried to update them myself but I found the edits I made did not show up on the charts. I assume this means the charts are locked to prevent editing? Shortly after that those two charts were removed completely, the edit comment claims the reason is because the data those charts presented was already contained in the main chart which it clearly is not.

Although it is possible to calculate the daily numbers by using the data from the main chart, the actual daily number of new infections and the actual number of new fatalities is not presented by the main chart. I reversed the aformentioned edit to put back the charts that had been removed but they were subsequently removed again the next day. 

You can see, the only other way to source the actual number of fatalities each day is to manually calculate them from the main chart. Even the Alabama Dept of Health website is only presenting cumulative numbers. It seems to me, the political motivation for obscuring the actual daily numbers of new infections and new fatalities is obvious when the federal guidlines for reopening economies assumes access to those daily numbers. So what do we do about this? [[User:Raven9nine|Raven9nine]] ([[User talk:Raven9nine|talk]]) 15:57, 10 May 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Verifiability#rfc_2DF5E9C|Wikipedia talk:Verifiability]] expired 2020-06-10 12:01 ===
* Id: 2DF5E9C
* User: Onceinawhile
* Date: 2020-05-11 11:04:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|956080364|POLICY 956080364}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|961787585|POLICY 961787585}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the words "of new information" be added into WP:ONUS?

This would change it from: {{green|While information must be verifiable to be included in an article, all verifiable information need not be included in an article. Consensus may determine that certain information does not improve an article, and that it should be omitted or presented instead in a different article. The onus to achieve consensus for inclusion is upon those seeking to include disputed content.}}

...to {{green|While information must be verifiable to be included in an article, all verifiable information need not be included in an article. Consensus may determine that certain information does not improve an article, and that it should be omitted or presented instead in a different article. The onus to achieve consensus for inclusion <u>of new information</u> is upon those seeking to include disputed content.}}

This is an attempt to move closer to our common practice, per the community discussions in the archives most recently at [[#/Archive 68#WP:ONUS vs. WP:QUO]], without being overly precise.

[[User:Onceinawhile|Onceinawhile]] ([[User talk:Onceinawhile|talk]]) 11:04, 11 May 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:2020 Democratic Party presidential primaries#rfc_5758D19|Talk:2020 Democratic Party presidential primaries]] expired 2020-06-10 19:01 ===
* Id: 5758D19
* User: Smith0124
* Date: 2020-06-07 00:31:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|961208307|POL 961208307}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|962700204|POL 962700204}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
'''Question''': For the individual primary pages, should ''withdrawn'' candidates who got >5% of the vote or >5% of delegates be removed from the infobox?<br>

Here are the options:<br>

'''A.''' Withdrawn candidates should '''only''' be removed from the infobox if they did '''not''' receive >5% of delegates or received less than 5% of the vote.<br>
'''B.''' '''All''' withdrawn candidates should be removed from the infobox unless we need a second place finisher in the infobox (due to the 2017 Rfc).

Thanks all! [[User:Smith0124|Smith0124]] ([[User talk:Smith0124|talk]]) 00:31, 7 June 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:COVID-19 pandemic in mainland China#rfc_E0D94C0|Talk:COVID-19 pandemic in mainland China]] expired 2020-06-10 22:01 ===
* Id: E0D94C0
* Date: 2020-05-11 21:03:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:

#To the same extent as the text below
#:2a. The text below, without modification
#:2b. The text below, without the direct quotes
#:2c. The text below with other modification / completely different text
#To a lesser extent than the text below
#To no extent

Suggestions are welcome. Feel free to participate with other options. 21:03, 11 May 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_675C7BF|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2020-06-11 04:01 ===
* Id: 675C7BF
* User: ZiaLater
* Date: 2020-05-20 04:54:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|957709209|ECON 957709209}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|957709211|MEDIA 957709211}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|961924521|ECON 961924521}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|961924523|MEDIA 961924523}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Hello! Another source that has raised questions: [[PanAm Post]]. I noticed that PanAm Post was describing a member of their staff as having a Harvard University "degree". They say that Emmanuel Rinc√≥n, a self-published author {{small|([[WP:QUESTIONABLE]]/[[WP:RSSELF]])}} who writes for the site, has "[https://panampost.com/author/emmanuel-rincon/ a degree in Modern Masterpieces of World Literature from Harvard University]". That "degree" is a free [[edX]] course provided by Harvard ([https://www.edx.org/course/modern-masterpieces-of-world-literature see here, where 40,000 people are already enrolled!]). This raises concerns about their reliability and if the site exaggerates the credentials of their staff (or their reporting).

So I am asking the community to decide the following evaluations about PanAm Post:

*'''Option 1:''' Generally [[WP:RS|reliable]] for factual reporting	
*'''Option 2:''' Unclear or additional considerations apply	
*'''Option 3:''' Generally [[WP:QUESTIONABLE|unreliable]] for factual reporting
*'''Option 4:''' Publishes false or fabricated information, and should be [[WP:DEPS|deprecated]]

Not sure if these type of RSN RfCs are still permitted since changes were proposed when I was last active, but a few opinions on this source would be appreciated!----[[User:ZiaLater|<i style="text-shadow:#C0C0C0 0.2em 0.2em 0.2em; color: ForestGreen">ZiaLater</i>]] ([[User talk:ZiaLater|<span style="color: ForestGreen">talk</span>]]) 04:54, 20 May 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Aleister Crowley#rfc_9F44590|Talk:Aleister Crowley]] expired 2020-06-11 20:01 ===
* Id: 9F44590
* User: Midnightblueowl
* Date: 2020-05-12 19:44:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|956336814|BIO 956336814}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|956336817|HIST 956336817}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|962044175|BIO 962044175}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|962044179|HIST 962044179}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
'''Question:''' In a 2008 book, Richard Spence argued that Crowley worked for British intelligence from the 1890s on and that this was the reason behind several of his foreign travels. This claim was further promoted in a 2011 biography by [[Tobias Churton]]. It remains unproven. How should we best present this argument to the reader?

*'''Option A:''' (the status quo); by mentioning the argument at those points of the article which chronologically describe events which Spence and Churton interpret in light of their theory.
*'''Option B:''' (new proposal); mentioning the argument in a separate section later in the article. [[User:Midnightblueowl|Midnightblueowl]] ([[User talk:Midnightblueowl|talk]]) 19:44, 12 May 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Gretchen Whitmer#rfc_4324F4A|Talk:Gretchen Whitmer]] expired 2020-06-12 08:01 ===
* Id: 4324F4A
* User: MyPreferredUsernameWasTaken
* Date: 2020-05-14 20:10:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|956707208|POL 956707208}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|962129654|POL 962129654}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Briefly summarizing, a disagreement has arose regarding content within the COVID-19 subheading of Whitmer's article. Most of my points have already been established regarding why it needs major revision above, but I'll quickly restate myself starting with the subheading itself:

*COVID-19, not Covid-19.
*It hasn't been an epidemic in several weeks, even the "main article" link acknowledges this.
*"leadership" is clearly implying praise on her part, we don't do this for [[Donald Trump]], [[Mike Pence]], [[Gavin Newsom]], [[Andrew Cuomo]], for instance. In fact, this article can take example from Cuomo's, who has undoubtedly received greater media coverage regarding this pandemic than Whitmer ever has.

Now, [[User:NorthBySouthBaranof|NorthBySouthBaranof]] has argued against the inclusion of the protestors, claiming they are a "small minority viewpoint". Despite this, he agrees to include the judge's decision, which is inherently linked to the protests, and aren't even in favor of the protests as it is. When I brought it back for the shake of context, NorthBySouth decided to bring back the emotional appeal of a dead child's mother's testimony. Not only does this affect the NPOV of this article, it contradicts NorthBySouth regarding what constitutes a "small minority viewpoint".

I propose we revert back to [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Gretchen_Whitmer&type=revision&diff=956689094&oldid=956565251 my edit here] excluding the SNL and rap group fluff, which we both agreed is irrelevant already. [[User:MyPreferredUsernameWasTaken|MyPreferredUsernameWasTaken]] ([[User talk:MyPreferredUsernameWasTaken|talk]]) 20:10, 14 May 2020 (UTC)}}

.  The result of that RfC was ''There was strong consensus for A, "If only one candidate meets the threshold, then the second-place contender should be included.'' Since that RfC there has been discussion of this point at [[Talk:2012_Democratic_Party_presidential_primaries]] and

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Template index/User talk namespace#rfc_0150109|Wikipedia talk:Template index/User talk namespace]] expired 2020-06-15 00:03 ===

=== [[Talk:White supremacy#rfc_023AC8B|Talk:White supremacy]] expired 2020-06-17 21:01 ===
* Id: 023AC8B
* User: GamerKiller2347
* Date: 2020-06-15 19:21:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|962818528|POL 962818528}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|963103397|POL 963103397}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
In the previous RfC, I made several comments that were interpreted as being off topic. My comments were not intended to be off topic. Anyway, I still believe that black and white supremacy need to be described as the same thing. I have mentioned that even if there is an almost universal opinion on an issue, there will still be those that disagree. I have also mentioned this quote from [[Martin Luther King, Jr.]]:
*‚ÄúA doctrine of black supremacy is as dangerous as a doctrine of white supremacy. God is not interested in the freedom of black men or brown men or yellow men. God is interested in the freedom of the whole human race, the creation of a society where every man will respect the dignity and worth of personality.‚Äù
:Source: [https://prospect.org/civil-rights/martin-luther-king-jr.-50-years/]
This quote says that all types of racial supremacies are dangerous. I believe that this quote should be used to make the decision on how to describe both supremacies. I have also mentioned that we could support our descriptions of supremacies if we add polls based on [[Political ideologies in the United States|political ideologies]] and [[List of political parties in the United States|political parties]]. I would like to know everyone's opinions on everything that I just mentioned. [[User:GamerKiller2347|GamerKiller2347]] ([[User talk:GamerKiller2347|talk]]) 19:21, 15 June 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Rupert Sheldrake#rfc_27CBDC1|Talk:Rupert Sheldrake]] expired 2020-06-19 02:01 ===
* Id: 27CBDC1
* User: HappyWanderer15
* Date: 2020-05-20 01:38:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|957685090|BIO 957685090}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|962840260|SCI 962840260}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|962840262|RELI 962840262}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|963305172|BIO 963305172}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|963305177|SCI 963305177}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|963305183|RELI 963305183}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Since it is already clearly stated from the outset of the article that Sheldrake's work is regarded as pseudoscience, should we make the following edits to the lede to reduce repetition?:

* ''Current version:'' Morphic resonance is not accepted by the [[scientific community]] and Sheldrake's proposals relating to it have been widely criticised. Critics cite a lack of evidence for morphic resonance and inconsistencies between its tenets and data from genetics, embryology, neuroscience, and biochemistry. They also express concern that popular attention paid to Sheldrake's books and public appearances undermines the public's understanding of science.
* ''Proposed edit:'' Scientists have widely criticised Sheldrake's proposals relating to morphic resonance, citing lack of evidence and inconsistencies between its tenets and data from genetics, embryology, neuroscience, and biochemistry. They also express concern that popular attention paid to Sheldrake's books and public appearances undermines the public's understanding of science.

*''Current version:'' Sheldrake's ideas, while lacking scientific acceptance, have found support in the [[New Age]] movement from individuals such as [[Deepak Chopra]].
*''Proposed edit:'' His ideas have found support in [[New Age]] circles, notably from [[Deepak Chopra]].

[[User:HappyWanderer15|HappyWanderer15]] ([[User talk:HappyWanderer15|talk]]) 01:38, 20 May 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Graeco-Latin square#rfc_23A4962|Talk:Graeco-Latin square]] expired 2020-06-20 00:01 ===
* Id: 23A4962
* User: Wcherowi
* Date: 2020-06-19 18:33:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|963426558|SCI 963426558}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|963473777|SCI 963473777}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This section is in woefully bad condition and I will be rewriting it, but there are two issues that I'd like to bring up for discussion. First of all, the page title. The main subject here (although you can't tell by looking at the page at this point) is mutually orthogonal Latin squares (MOLS) and Graeco-Latin squares are just a special case. This special case does have an interesting history, but the name is rather pass√© except possibly in some application areas. When I'm finished revising the page, I'll ask for a title change if other editors agree. The second point (and more ticklish one) has to do with the big bright example of a compounded MOLS 5 that has been on the page in one form or another since March 2009. I like the example, it is correct and well crafted ... but it is also completely [[WP:OR]]. Other editors must have felt the same as I do, it is just too good to toss. I will be rewriting the section so that this example is not as prominent (it makes for a poor introduction to the topic) and I can explain what it is in more traditional terms. I would like to see some consensus to keep the diagram even though it is OR.--[[User:Wcherowi|Bill Cherowitzo ]] ([[User talk:Wcherowi|talk]]) 18:33, 19 June 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Criteria for speedy deletion#rfc_7EDAA07|Wikipedia talk:Criteria for speedy deletion]] expired 2020-06-20 02:01 ===
* Id: 7EDAA07
* User: Dli00105
* Date: 2020-06-18 19:10:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|963258662|POLICY 963258662}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|963489580|POLICY 963489580}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I'm quite surprised that I haven't seen any discussions relating to these three criteria. It appears (at least to me) that U1, U2, and U5 can be merged into G7, G8, and G11, respectively.
:U1 - User pages are only supposed to be edited by their respective users, so if the user requests the deletion of their user page in good faith, then it fits under G7 because they are the only contributor. G7 and U1 proposals are even merged into [[:Category:Candidates for speedy deletion by user]].
:U2 - User pages of nonexistent users can easily be superseded by G8 with the addition of a single bullet point.
:U5 - This one may be slightly controversial, but blatantly misusing user pages as web hosts can easily fit under G11 (pure advertising). However, I am at a loss for exactly how to fit such a criterion. Consensus anyone?
[[User:Dli00105|Dli00105]] ([[User talk:Dli00105|talk]]) 19:10, 18 June 2020 (UTC)}}

* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|961020435|HIST 961020435}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|961020444|POL 961020444}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|961020445|RELI 961020445}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|961020447|SOC 961020447}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|966281172|HIST 966281172}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|966281177|POL 966281177}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|966281186|RELI 966281186}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|966281190|SOC 966281190}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Shall we summarize the following allegations from former MEK members:

* {{tq|"an incident which Masoud Banisadr described as changing into "ant-like human beings", i.e. following orders by their instinct."}} 
* {{tq|"Allegations of cult-like characteristics in the MEK have been made by former members who have [[Defection|defected]] from the organization, including Massoud Khodabandeh and Masoud Banisadr among others."}} 
*{{tq|"In 2019, more defectors related their experiences. These included a ban on romantic relationships and marriages after a major military defeat. The leadership attributed that to the members being distracted by spouses and children. Members said they had to write in a notebook any sexual moments, such as 'today in the morning, I had an erection'. They had to write in the notebook feelings such as wishing to have a child after seeing children on TV. These notebooks had to be read aloud in front of the leaders and comrades."}} 
[[User:Stefka Bulgaria|Stefka Bulgaria]] ([[User talk:Stefka Bulgaria|talk]]) 05:36, 6 June 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Zamzam Well#rfc_17247FC|Talk:Zamzam Well]] expired 2020-06-20 09:01 ===
* Id: 17247FC
* User: Moughera
* Date: 2020-05-21 08:49:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|960513739|HIST 960513739}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|960513745|POLICY 960513745}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|963530835|HIST 963530835}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|963530847|POLICY 963530847}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 BC "Before Christ" is a dating term with predominantly "Christian" connotations, while the article is strictly about another, entirely different religious interest, i.e. Islam. I suggest that the dating across not only this but all the Islamic articles are to be Hijri (Hj.) or Before Hijra (BH.) and then BCE/CE added in braces like; '''Umayyad Mosque was constructed circa 86-96 Hj. (705‚Äì715 CE)'''.

I am aware that is going to be quite a tedious and time consuming task and may also be somewhat confusing for someone reading the article for the first time, but in the longer run it will add a new aspect to the relevant articles and content which will not only present a non-christian and neutral tone of the content but also add a the "academic touch" as well, as the BCE and CE have become more academically adopted. Please see following for a more detailed explanation; these sources can be found here ([[Anno_Domini#CE_and_BCE]]) as well

# Robinson, B.A. (20 April 2009). "Justification of the use of "CE" & "BCE" to identify dates. Trends". ReligiousTolerance.org.
# Safire, William (17 August 1997). "On Language: B.C./A.D. or B.C.E./C.E.?". The New York Times Magazine.
# Cunningham, Philip A., ed. (2004). Pondering the Passion : what's at stake for Christians and Jews?. Lanham, Md. [u.a.]: Rowman & Littlefield. p. 193. ISBN 978-0742532182.
[[User:Moughera|Moughera]] ([[User talk:Moughera|talk]]) 08:49, 21 May 2020 (UTC)}}

{{rfcquote|text=
Should [[Facebook]] be subject to a warn edit filter, and/or added to [[User:XLinkBot/RevertReferencesList]], which reverts the use of a source in {{tag|ref}} tags (Note: Does not include external links) for unregistered and new users under 7 days old  ([[Wikipedia:Reliable_sources/Noticeboard/Archive_267#RfC:_IMDb|Per the IMDb discussion on this noticeboard]]) to discourage misuse? Facebook is currently cited over 60,000 times on Wikipedia per {{duses|facebook.com}}. Facebook is currently described at RS/P as "Facebook is considered generally unreliable because it is a self-published source with no editorial oversight." 15 specific Facebook pages are currently on the [[MediaWiki:Spam-blacklist]]. Facebook is also specifically cited at [[Wikipedia:Reliable Sources]] as an example of "unacceptable user-generated sites" [[User:Hemiauchenia|Hemiauchenia]] ([[User talk:Hemiauchenia|talk]]) 16:31, 3 June 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_FB54C17|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2020-06-23 15:01 ===

* Id: D37638D
* User: JohnJohnson707
* Date: 2020-06-25 15:19:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|964454025|HIST 964454025}}

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|964454046|TECH 964454046}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|964672755|HIST 964672755}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|964672762|RELI 964672762}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|964672763|SOC 964672763}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|964672767|TECH 964672767}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I don't how there hasn't been an RfC on this before, perhaps the talk page was difficult to find for some. I think using the dagger icon (which resembles the [[Christian cross]]) for KIA is a bit confusing when representing KIA (Killed in action) for non-western editors, such as Chinese,  Hindu's and Muslims who comprise about 3/4 of worlds population. I propose changing the dagger icon to skull, which is the universal symbol of death. The skull icon is currently used on [[Template:Executed]] so if this passes I think that should be changed with abbreviation (EXE) for executed. [[User:JohnJohnson707|JohnJohnson707]] ([[User talk:JohnJohnson707|talk]]) 15:19, 25 June 2020 (UTC)}}

* Id: 42322F7
* Date: 2020-06-17 01:52:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|962975481|POLICY 962975481}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style#rfc_8C76E25|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style]] expired 2020-06-27 11:01 ===
* Id: 8C76E25
* User: Mike_Christie
* Date: 2020-05-28 10:43:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|959353305|POLICY 959353305}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|964752649|POLICY 964752649}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
When describing periodical works such as newspapers, magazines, journals, comic books, radio programs, televisions shows, podcasts, and web series that are no longer published, should we use "is" or "was"?

For example:
* "''Gourmet'' is a magazine that was published from 1941 to 2009" vs. "''Gourmet'' was a magazine published from 1941 to 2009"
* "''I Love Lucy'' is a TV show that ran from 1951 to 1957" vs. "''I Love Lucy'' was a TV show that ran from 1951 to 1957".

Note that the MoS guideline that covers this question is [[WP:WAS]], which says {{tq|By default, write articles in the present tense, including those covering works of fiction...and products or works that have been discontinued. Generally, do not use past tense except for past events and subjects that are dead or no longer meaningfully exist.}}  However, attempts to resolve the question this RfC is asking by referring to this have not agreed on whether defunct periodicals should be considered to be "dead...and no longer meaningfully exist" -- see [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style#WP:WAS and defunct magazines]].

If you believe some types of periodical should use "was" and the others should use "is", please make that clear in your response. [[User:Mike Christie|Mike Christie]] ([[User_talk:Mike Christie|talk]] - [[Special:Contributions/Mike_Christie|contribs]] -  [[User:Mike Christie/Reference library|library]]) 10:43, 28 May 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Virtue signalling#rfc_C80842B|Talk:Virtue signalling]] expired 2020-06-29 23:01 ===
* Id: C80842B
* User: Bacondrum
* Date: 2020-05-30 22:48:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|960033286|SOC 960033286}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|965193801|SOC 965193801}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I think the fact that the common use of the term is derogatory or pejorative needs to be included in the lede, it's like leaving "During daylight, the sky appears to be blue" out of the Sky article's lede. Based on this peer reviewed academic source I think we should describe the contemporary, common use as derogatory https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6795490/ quote: "a phenomenon commonly referred to as ‚Äúvirtue signaling‚Äù [51]. Although somewhat neglected in psychological or social-science literature, ‚Äúvirtue signaling‚Äù seems most often to be used as a derogatory term" 
It is used commonly in a derogatory manner, this blatant fact being absent makes the lede read like a victim of Americas culture wars. [[User:Bacondrum|Bacondrum]] ([[User talk:Bacondrum|talk]]) 22:48, 30 May 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_EAACA2B|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2020-06-30 04:01 ===
* Id: EAACA2B
* Date: 2020-06-21 13:28:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|963733873|MEDIA 963733873}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|963733874|SOC 963733874}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|965228484|MEDIA 965228484}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|965228485|SOC 965228485}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There was [[Talk:ContraPoints#"Controversies"|a discussion back in January]] on the talk page of the article for [[ContraPoints]], in which the reliability of [https://www.pride.com/ Pride.com] was briefly discussed. In the discussion, I asserted that the reliability of the website should probably be taken on a case-by-case basis. The site is said to [https://web.archive.org/web/20180130204433/http://www.magazine.org/industry-news/press-releases/member-press-releases/here-media-introduces-pridecom prominently feature user-submitted content], but it also has an editorial director, and features content by established figures. For example, [https://twitter.com/jessiegender Jessie Earl], who has also written for ''[[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]]'', has written articles for Pride.com. Fellow editor [[User:Bilorv|Bilorv]] agreed that the Pride.com article used on the ContraPoints page was an acceptable source in that case. However, I'd like more editors to weigh in, so perhaps a consensus regarding the site's status as generally reliable, generally unreliable, or marginally reliable could be listed at [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Perennial sources|WP:RSP]]. This is my first time starting a discussion on this noticeboard, so I hope I'm doing this correctly. ‚Äî'''''[[User:MatthewHoobin|<span style="color:#0640e0; text-shadow:#66ff66 0.2em 0.2em 0.4em;">Matthew</span>]]''''' - <span style="font-size:80%">([[User_talk:MatthewHoobin|talk]])</span> 13:28, 21 June 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Naming conventions (use English)#rfc_5A1A3B9|Wikipedia talk:Naming conventions (use English)]] expired 2020-06-30 06:01 ===
* Id: 5A1A3B9
* User: King of Hearts
* Date: 2020-05-31 05:08:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|959912495|STYLE 959912495}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|959912498|POLICY 959912498}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|965239042|STYLE 965239042}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|965239044|POLICY 965239044}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
[[WP:USEENGLISH]] says that we should use the name which is mostly commonly found in English-language sources. Sometimes, as with the [[Technical University of Berlin|Technical University of Berlin / Technische Universit√§t Berlin]], both the native name and a translation are widely used in English sources and it is impossible to tell which one is more common. In these cases, what should the tiebreaker be?
# Give the edge to the [[WP:OFFICIALNAME]], i.e. what the subject would prefer to be known as in English, which could be the native name or the translation.
# Give the edge to the English translation. Note that [[WP:USEENGLISH]] does not currently say that we prefer names in English, but rather names which are most commonly used in English sources.
# Keep the long-standing title, per [[WP:TITLECHANGES]]. This is the general default option when there is no specific guidance to do something different.
[[User:King of Hearts|<b style="color:red">King of ‚ô•</b>]][[User talk:King of Hearts|<b style="color:red"> ‚ô¶</b>]][[Special:Contributions/King of Hearts|<b style="color:black"> ‚ô£</b>]][[Special:EmailUser/King of Hearts|<b style="color:black"> ‚ô†</b>]] 05:08, 31 May 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Square One: Michael Jackson#rfc_DDD1546|Talk:Square One: Michael Jackson]] expired 2020-06-30 10:01 ===
* Id: DDD1546
* User: Israell
* Date: 2020-05-31 09:17:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|960408257|BIO 960408257}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|960408270|MEDIA 960408270}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|965263751|BIO 965263751}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|965263753|MEDIA 965263753}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I am now initiating a vote since there is an escalating dispute as to who did formally accuse Michael Jackson of child sexual abuse: Evan Chandler, his son Jordan Chandler or the two of them. [[User:Bananasasas|Bananasasas]] insists Jordan Chandler was the sole accuser, while several other editors (me included) agree that the two of them did formally accuse Jackson.

'''I ask that''' Banananasas' edit[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Square_One:_Michael_Jackson&diff=959690452&oldid=959659753] that reads: "''Square One'' is an independent investigative documentary that examines the original child sexual abuse allegations by Jordan Chandler, a 13 year old boy, against Michael Jackson." be changed back to "''Square One'' is an independent investigative documentary that examines the original child sexual abuse allegations brought against Jackson first by Evan Chandler and then by his son Jordan Chandler."

{{ping|Popcornfud|SNUGGUMS|Drmies|*Treker|SNUGGUMS|JG66|Deboleena.ghy|Hammelsmith|TruthGuardians|Akhiljaxxn|Orientls|QEDK|Jimcastor}} I am now pinging you for consensus. Other editors are invited to vote as well.

My statement is the following: "Evan Chandler did accuse Michael Jackson of sexually abusing his son Jordan Chandler." [[User:Israell|Israell]] ([[User talk:Israell|talk]]) 09:17, 31 May 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Militarization of police#rfc_7DF15E9|Talk:Militarization of police]] expired 2020-06-30 19:01 ===
* Id: 7DF15E9
* User: Snooganssnoogans
* Date: 2020-05-31 18:19:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|960022053|HIST 960022053}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|960022064|POL 960022064}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|965337841|HIST 965337841}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|965337847|POL 965337847}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the lead briefly summarize that (i) the U.S. is a prominent example of militarization of police in democracies, (ii) U.S. police departments were non-militaristic prior to the 20th century, and (iii) that influential police reformers (such as [[August Vollmer]]) introduced reforms in the early 20th century whereby US police departments adopted military tactics, techniques, and organizational templates? [[User:Snooganssnoogans|Snooganssnoogans]] ([[User talk:Snooganssnoogans|talk]]) 18:19, 31 May 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Soomro#rfc_FFA7092|Talk:Soomro]] expired 2020-07-02 04:01 ===
* Id: FFA7092
* Date: 2020-06-02 03:10:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|960289967|HIST 960289967}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|965573207|HIST 965573207}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The page underwent major changes with the addition of self-published sources. 

Prior to these changes, the article was [[Special:Permalink/950753453|this]], and specifically cited several sources which discussed the various proposed origins of the Soomro tribe, including native Sindhi, Rajput, Arab, and mixed-Arab heritage. Following the edits of a rather zealous editor, any discussion of the various theorized origins was completely obliterated, and the page presented one-sided information that made it seem that their potential Rajput origins were an open-and-shut case. He goes on to introduce a random story about their origins that was self-published by Harjani. There was a discussion about this author and his work at [[WP:Reliable_sources/Noticeboard/Archive 294#Notion_Press_publications]], and when it was removed, he re-introduced it with the crazy edit summary that [[Special:Diff/960271226|he was the one removing self-published source]], even though he clearly reinserted it. 

He also changed several terms to introduce POV - such as that "some members of the tribe converted to Islam," even though this is an almost entirely Muslim tribe now - downplaying the current religion. In the infobox he tries to change this fact by including Hinduism as a current religion of the tribe, though if you actually read his citation, the only claim is that the tribe converted from Hinduism, not that they are currently Hindus. He also introduces subtle terms to emphasize this suggestion, like that this is not a tribe, but instead a "caste." 

His edits are reintroduced on this and other pages with {{u|Srijanx22}}, whose infopage says he enjoys "trolling leftists."

Please add your perspective on whether this is disruptive. The two together are difficult to counter, since it doesnt seem like theyre interested in fact, and are much more interested in promoting POV. 03:10, 2 June 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Non-free content#rfc_78A7034|Wikipedia talk:Non-free content]] expired 2020-07-02 05:01 ===
* Id: 78A7034
* User: NCLI
* Date: 2020-06-12 14:49:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|962178115|POLICY 962178115}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|965578714|POLICY 965578714}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Criterium #1 states that "Non-free content is used only where no free equivalent is available, or could be created, that would serve the same encyclopedic purpose."

How is this to be interpreted? Is non-free content '''(A)''' allowed ''only'' when no adequate replacement can '''ever''' reasonably be expected to emerge, or '''(B)''' is it ok to use until it can be if it is just not possible to create at the moment? See discussion [[Wikipedia talk:Non-free content/Archive 70#Interpretation of criterium #1|above]] for context. [[User:NCLI|NCLI]] ([[User talk:NCLI|talk]]) 14:49, 12 June 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Naming conventions (royalty and nobility)#rfc_79E02E7|Wikipedia talk:Naming conventions (royalty and nobility)]] expired 2020-07-02 15:01 ===
* Id: 79E02E7
* User: Interstellarity
* Date: 2020-06-02 14:17:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|960363012|STYLE 960363012}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|965642899|STYLE 965642899}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The requested move on [[Elizabeth I]], [[Talk:Elizabeth_I#Requested_move_25_May_2020|here]], has passed that shortened the title. There are a few things I would like to address in this RFC. Firstly, I would like to know how far we can go in shortening the titles to omit the country. [[Henry VIII of England]] is not titled [[Henry VIII]], and [[Juan Carlos I of Spain]] is not titled [[Juan Carlos I]]. Other examples we have that omit the country are [[Elizabeth II]] and [[James VI and I]]. The second thing I would like to address is when there has been one holder of the name of a monarch, should we title it like this [[John of England]] or [[Anne of Great Britain]]? [[Queen Victoria]] is not called [[Victoria of the United Kingdom]] or [[Victoria, Queen of the United Kingdom]]. [[User:Interstellarity|Interstellarity]] ([[User talk:Interstellarity|talk]]) 14:17, 2 June 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Occupational stress#rfc_B5272DE|Talk:Occupational stress]] expired 2020-07-02 21:01 ===
* Id: B5272DE
* Date: 2020-06-03 22:01:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|960607668|SCI 960607668}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|960607671|SOC 960607671}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|965869637|SCI 965869637}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|965869638|SOC 965869638}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the Occupations section be rewritten as specified below?

'''Occupations'''

Should the two paragraphs at the end, in the Occupations section, be replaced by:
 Professionals from several fields conduct research on the causes of occupational stress and interventions that prevent or treat occupational stress. Other professionals are practitioners who consult with organizations regarding how to make the work environment less stressful or to treat individual casualties of job stress. These professionals come from a number of fields including occupational health psychology, industrial and organizational psychology, sociology, human factors and ergonomics, clinical psychology, and occupational safety and health.

22:01, 3 June 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:The Haunting of Hill House (TV series)#rfc_8CCE4FB|Talk:The Haunting of Hill House (TV series)]] expired 2020-07-05 11:01 ===
* Id: 8CCE4FB
* User: Alex 21
* Date: 2020-06-05 10:25:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|960874286|MEDIA 960874286}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|966151280|MEDIA 966151280}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
How should this article and its subarticles be titled and structured?
* '''Option A''' This article is titled ''The Haunting of Hill House'' ([[Special:Permalink/960846706|layout]]), with no Season 1 article and only ''The Haunting of Bly Manor'' article as a subarticle ([[Special:Permalink/954716384|layout]]).
* '''Option B''' This article is titled ''The Haunting of Hill House'' ([[Special:Permalink/960846706|layout]]), with ''The Haunting of Hill House'' (season 1) ([[Special:Permalink/960293565|layout]]) and ''The Haunting of Bly Manor'' ([[Special:Permalink/954716384|layout]]) articles as subarticles.
* '''Option C''' This article is titled ''The Haunting of Hill House'' ([[Special:Permalink/960846706|layout]]), with ''The Haunting of Hill House'' (season 1) ([[Special:Permalink/960293565|layout]]) and ''The Haunting of Hill House'' (season 2) ([[Special:Permalink/960293568|layout]]) articles as subarticles.
* '''Option D''' This article is titled ''The Haunting'' ([[Special:Permalink/960293521|layout, but retitled]]), with ''The Haunting of Hill House'' ([[Special:Permalink/960293565|layout, but retitled]]) and ''The Haunting of Bly Manor'' ([[Special:Permalink/954716384|layout]]) articles as subarticles.
* '''Option E''' Some other title and structure.
-- <span style="text-shadow:0 0 1px #8dd">''/[[User:Alex 21|<span style="color:#008">Alex</span>]]/[[User talk:Alex 21|<sub style="color:#008">21</sub>]]''</span> 10:25, 5 June 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Naming conventions (geographic names)#rfc_DBD9D57|Wikipedia talk:Naming conventions (geographic names)]] expired 2020-07-06 18:01 ===
* Id: DBD9D57
* User: King of Hearts
* Date: 2020-06-06 17:30:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|961117976|STYLE 961117976}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|966364261|STYLE 966364261}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 
Currently there is no guideline on whether parenthetical disambiguators for place names (e.g. [[Georgia (U.S. state)]], [[Georgia (country)]], and [[New York (state)]]) should be maintained in subtopics of the location. Call our two entities A and B, and suppose that an article exists for a subtopic of A but not for B. There are several questions to answer here:
# Should we preemptively disambiguate when the topic can only reasonably exist for A, such as [[President of Georgia]]?
# Should we preemptively disambiguate when no article currently exists for B, but one could theoretically be created, such as [[Law of Georgia (U.S. state)]]?
# When B is geographically part of A, should we preemptively disambiguate when no article currently exists for B, but one could theoretically be created, such as [[List of beaches in New York]]? Does it matter if the subtopic is a list or a regular article? -- [[User:King of Hearts|<b style="color:red">King of ‚ô•</b>]][[User talk:King of Hearts|<b style="color:red"> ‚ô¶</b>]][[Special:Contributions/King of Hearts|<b style="color:black"> ‚ô£</b>]][[Special:EmailUser/King of Hearts|<b style="color:black"> ‚ô†</b>]] 17:30, 6 June 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_7CF8001|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2020-07-07 19:01 ===
* Id: 7CF8001
* User: Hemiauchenia
* Date: 2020-06-07 18:20:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|961311830|MEDIA 961311830}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|961311834|PROP 961311834}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|961345251|POL 961345251}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|966552502|MEDIA 966552502}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|966552506|POL 966552506}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|966552516|PROP 966552516}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Which of the following best describes the [[WP:RS|reliability]] of the reporting of [[Fox News]]? (as separate from their cable pundits) {{duses|foxnews.com}} has been cited over 15,000 times on Wikipedia.
*'''Option 1:''' Generally [[WP:RS|reliable]] for factual reporting
*'''Option 2:''' Unclear or additional considerations apply
*'''Option 3:''' Generally [[WP:QUESTIONABLE|unreliable]] for factual reporting
*'''Option 4:''' Publishes false or fabricated information, and should be [[WP:DEPS|deprecated]] as in the [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard/Archive 220#Daily Mail RfC|2017 RfC]] of the ''[[Daily Mail]]''
Additional questions:
*Does FOXNews.com have a separate reliability from their cable news reporting?
*Do local affiliate stations have a separate reliability to the main Fox News operation?
*Is Fox News reliable for US Politics?
The last RfC on Fox News [[Wikipedia:Reliable_sources/Noticeboard/Archive_73#Request_for_Comment_on_Fox_News_Channel|was in 2010]], Fox News is currently described [[WP:FOXNEWS|at the RS/P as]]: {{quote|text=FOX News was determined by consensus to be generally reliable per [[WP:NEWSORG]]. The network consists of 12 news bureaus worldwide, including their New York headquarters. Several shows in the channel's news lineup include America's Newsroom, The Daily Briefing, Bill Hemmer Reports (replaced Shepard Smith), Special Report with Bret Baier, The Story with Martha MacCallum, and Chris Wallace anchoring Fox News Sunday. Some editors perceive FOX News to be a biased source whereas others do not; neither affects reliability of the source. Editors should always exercise caution when choosing sources, and treat talk show content hosted by political pundits as opinion pieces, avoid stating opinions in Wikivoice and use intext attribution as applicable. The Fox News website maintains a form for requesting corrections.}} [[User:Hemiauchenia|Hemiauchenia]] ([[User talk:Hemiauchenia|talk]]) 18:20, 7 June 2020 (UTC)}}

{{rfcquote|text=

There are two issues concerning a sentence in the lead of the [[Abortion]] article: whether late termination of pregnancy should be defined in terms of fetus viability or in terms of gestational age, and whether ''late term abortion'' is neutral terminology. === [[Talk:Ronald Reagan#rfc_8520D62|Talk:Ronald Reagan]] expired 2020-07-10 00:01 ===
* Id: 8520D62
* User: Springee
* Date: 2020-06-09 23:38:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|961707815|HIST 961707815}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|961723884|BIO 961723884}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|961723889|POL 961723889}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|966914389|BIO 966914389}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|966914391|HIST 966914391}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|966914395|POL 966914395}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Last fall a RfC asked this question [[Talk:Ronald_Reagan#Newly_released_audio]].  A number of editors suggested a wait and see approach.  It has been 9 months and an editor recently added the following to the article [//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ronald_Reagan&diff=961679741&oldid=961375128]
::''{{tq|In July of 2019 a previously undisclosed tape recorded in the Nixon White House was released. In the audio recording, made in 1971 and documenting a phone conversation between then-President Nixon and then-Governor Reagan, Mr. Reagan can be heard saying, ‚ÄúTo see those, those monkeys from those African countries‚Äîdamn them, they‚Äôre still uncomfortable wearing shoes!‚Äú <ref> <iframe title="vimeo-player" src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/353811584" width="640" height="360" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe> </ref> This statement was made in reference to a United Nations delegation from Tanzania, which opposed the United States in a vote to officially recognize the People‚Äôs Republic of China. When the tape was initially released in 2000, the racist portion had been edited out. Subsequent to Reagan‚Äôs passing, the original recording was restored and released to the public.}}

Do editors feel this added text is DUE for inclusion? [[User:Springee|Springee]] ([[User talk:Springee|talk]]) 23:38, 9 June 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Liancourt Rocks#rfc_C0342AF|Talk:Liancourt Rocks]] expired 2020-07-10 12:01 ===
* Id: C0342AF
* User: Leemsj2075
* Date: 2020-06-25 06:57:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|964397284|HIST 964397284}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|966981487|HIST 966981487}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
'''Should the alternative name "(East Sea)" be added in parentheses after the first mention of "[[Sea of Japan]]" in the lead sentence of this article?'''

According to the [[WP:NC-SoJ]], Korean article should use Sea of Japan (East Sea), but this article only use Sea of Japan, Dokdo has controversy between Japan and S.Korea, but Dokdo is include in Korea. So I think this article should follow Japan/Korea and South Korea articles at [[WP:NC-SoJ#Sea of Japan (East Sea)]] this regulation. --[[user:Leemsj2075|Leemsj2075]] ([[User talk:Leemsj2075|Talk]] | [[Special:Contributions/Leemsj2075|Contributions]]) 06:57, 25 June 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Mr. Wrestling II#rfc_50279F9|Talk:Mr. Wrestling II]] expired 2020-07-11 09:01 ===
* Id: 50279F9
* User: Dibbydib
* Date: 2020-06-11 08:58:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|961956386|BIO 961956386}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|961956413|SOC 961956413}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|967127773|BIO 967127773}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|967127779|SOC 967127779}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
&#32;
* {{article|Mr. Wrestling II}}
Recently it has come to my attention of a bit of a content dispute, which focuses on whether Mr. Wrestling II was a registered sex offender. The editors involved are all IPv6 anonymous editors, and they've seemed to be getting into an edit war over this (see {{pagehistory|Mr. Wrestling II|history}}).

This is quite a controversial topic, and its sudden addition [[Mr. Wrestling II#Death|just after his death]] does raise some red flags. However, the content is sourced twice, both in a sex offender registry ([https://www.homefacts.com/offender-detail/HIA0031098/John-F-Walker.html]) and a clipping from the [[Honolulu Advertiser]] ([https://www.newspapers.com/clip/19212498/mr-wrestling-ii-johnny-walker-rape/]) clipped in 2018.

Is the content acceptable to include into the article? [[User:Dibbydib|<b style="color:#1dd400">dibbydib</b>]] <sup>[[User talk:Dibbydib|<i style="color:#117f00">boop</i>]]</sup><i style="color:#117f00"> or </i><sub>[[Special:Contributions/Dibbydib|<i style="color:#117f00">snoop</i>]]</sub> 08:58, 11 June 2020 (UTC)}}

{{rfcquote|text=
Are the following statements in the "ACORN videos (2009)" section properly supported by the reliable sources cited? Please answer which, if any, are supported. I have labeled in bold the parts whose support from reliable sources is disputed and supplied the relevant cited source for each instance.
#"O'Keefe's targeting of ACORN, coordinated with Andrew Breitbart, '''was due to conservative hatred for the organization significantly motivated by its voter registration drives'''." ([https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/09/17/AR2009091704805.html Cited source])
#"Mr. Vera lost his job '''and was falsely accused of being engaged in human trafficking'''." ([https://www.forbes.com/sites/rickungar/2013/03/08/james-okeefe-pays-100000-to-acorn-employee-he-smeared-conservative-media-yawns Cited source])
#"O'Keefe agreed to pay $100,000 to former California ACORN employee Juan Carlos Vera '''for deliberately misrepresenting Mr. Vera's actions'''." ([http://www.latimes.com/news/local/la-me-0308-acorn-20130308,0,5432316.story?track=rss Cited source])
#"The settlement contained the following '''apology'''..." ([http://www.latimes.com/news/local/la-me-0308-acorn-20130308,0,5432316.story?track=rss Cited source])
Disclosure: I work for Project Veritas. [[User:Sal at PV|Sal at PV]] ([[User talk:Sal at PV|talk]])(13:18, 11 June 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Racial bias on Wikipedia#rfc_5E35215|Talk:Racial bias on Wikipedia]] expired 2020-07-11 17:01 ===
* Id: 5E35215
* User: Juliette Han
* Date: 2020-06-11 16:38:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|962019919|SOC 962019919}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|962019923|STYLE 962019923}}

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
See [[Talk:Racial_bias_on_Wikipedia#Removed_templates]]. On behalf of [[User:NightHeron|NightHeron]]: how to handle a situation where, despite an article's title, its actual coverage relates only to English Wikipedia rather than to Wikipedia generally. Through a template, retitling, nothing, or something else? 
'''Note''' that English-centered nature of such articles may be inevitable due to Wikipedia being a language-divided project, where different divisions may be covered unequally. [[User:Juliette Han|Juliette Han]] ([[User talk:Juliette Han|talk]]) 16:38, 11 June 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Joel Fuhrman#rfc_BD57896|Talk:Joel Fuhrman]] expired 2020-07-11 22:01 ===
* Id: BD57896
* User: Danielinnov8
* Date: 2020-06-29 19:29:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|965170063|BIO 965170063}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|967217324|BIO 967217324}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Requesting a peer review and changes to the article. I do not believe it to be correct or objective. For example the first sentence "is an American celebrity doctor who advocates what he calls a micronutrient-rich diet" is a subjective statement and is mis-quoted from the original reference which states "...and his nutrient density program..." page 41. Regardless this subcategory idea is not appropriate for the introduction of the subject. I propose a more accurate and fair introduction: "...is a Board Certified physician and author based in New Jersey."

The entire Diet and health section is essentially controversial material from one perspective (against) the subject. I propose renaming this heading to "Diet Controversy..." where all of the controversial material can go instead of being scattered throughout the entire article. Thank you. [[User:Danielinnov8|Danielinnov8]] ([[User talk:Danielinnov8|talk]]) 19:29, 29 June 2020 (UTC)}}

{{rfcquote|text=
Given it is a claim that has the [[WP:BLP|potential to cause harm]] and is [[WP:BURDEN|likely to be challenged]], is the statement "widely criticized for its unreliability" [[WP:V|adequately sourced]] with [[WP:INCITE|inline citations]] placed at the end of the sentence, which either contain this literal claim, or [[WP:PLAGIARISM|words to that effect]], such that readers are not being improperly asked to [[WP:NOR|draw their own conclusions]] from said sources? If not, can this claim ever be sourced to these necessarily strict evidentiary standards? (i.e., if you think it can, please provide proof of such a source, quoting the relevant passage) [[User:BorkNein|BorkNein]] ([[User talk:BorkNein|talk]]) 13:49, 11 July 2020 (UTC)}}
