=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_7A7AB6A|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2020-10-07 05:01 ===
* Id: 7A7AB6A
* Date: 2020-09-20 16:38:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|979418349|PROP 979418349}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|981282138|MEDIA 981282138}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|982276240|MEDIA 982276240}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|982276247|PROP 982276247}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
What is the reliability of [[Entrepreneur (magazine)]] ({{duses|entrepreneur.com}})? Over 1000 Wikipedia articles cite this publication. The site, like Forbes, runs two types of articles:
*Articles by "Entrepreneur Staff" e.g. hxxps://www.entrepreneur.com/article/354030
*Articles tagged " Opinions expressed by Entrepreneur contributors are their own." e.g. hxxps://www.entrepreneur.com/article/356195, which make up most of the stuff on this website.

For both types, please indicate which of the following applies:

*'''Option 1:''' Generally [[WP:RS|reliable]] for factual reporting
*'''Option 2:''' Unclear or additional considerations apply
*'''Option 3:''' Generally [[WP:QUESTIONABLE|unreliable]] for factual reporting
*'''Option 4:''' Publishes false or fabricated information, and should be [[WP:DEPS|deprecated]] as in the [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard/Archive 220#Daily Mail RfC|2017 RfC]] of the ''[[Daily Mail]]''?

[[User:MER-C|MER-C]] 16:38, 20 September 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Naming conventions (people)#rfc_D9EF6B2|Wikipedia talk:Naming conventions (people)]] expired 2020-10-09 01:01 ===

* RFC Text:

@ [[wp:Middle initial]] I propose adding this text:<blockquote> "(Note: In cases where reliable sources include a subject's middle initial along with a subject's first and last names as often as they do not include the middle initial, since Wikipedia has no default preference, either form is acceptable.)"</blockquote>--[[User:Hodgdon&#39;s secret garden|Hodgdon&#39;s secret garden]] ([[User talk:Hodgdon&#39;s secret garden|talk]]) 12:55, 12 September 2020 (UTC)}}


=== [[Wikipedia talk:Naming conventions (people)#rfc_69835B9|Wikipedia talk:Naming conventions (people)]] expired 2020-10-09 01:01 ===
* Id: 69835B9
* User: Mdewman6
* Date: 2020-09-09 00:20:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|977563031|BIO 977563031}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|982578524|BIO 982578524}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
What is the policy for use of middle initials for disambiguation purposes? My understanding of this page is that parenthetical disambiguation should be used and middle initials should not be added solely for disambiguation. Nevertheless, this happens all the time, as individuals with common names have pages including their middle initials while most of them are not commonly known by version of their names containing their middle initials. I think this policy should be clarified. [[User:Mdewman6|Mdewman6]] ([[User talk:Mdewman6|talk]]) 00:20, 9 September 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Slate industry in Wales#rfc_CDA8F5E|Talk:Slate industry in Wales]] expired 2020-10-09 21:01 ===
* Id: CDA8F5E
* Date: 2020-09-09 20:45:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|977603940|HIST 977603940}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|977603959|STYLE 977603959}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|982710788|HIST 982710788}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|982710796|STYLE 982710796}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
A brief introduction:

After [[Talk:Bryn_Eglwys_quarry#Requested_move_4_January_2020|a move discussion in early January (2020)]] on [[Talk:Bryn Eglwys]], a mass-move of [[:Category:Slate mines in Wales|all slate quarries in Wales]] was performed, by {{u|The Mirror Cracked}}, who was a major editor of these pages [[User Talk:The Mirror Cracked#Don't Go|but has unfortunately recently gone missing]]. This move retitled the pages from assorted '...Quarry's, '...Slate Quarry's, and '...quarry's, to a standard '...quarry'.

However, this is controversial, given that most sources give the titles as '...Quarry'. The purpose of this RfC is to attempt to gain a [[WP:consencus|consencus]] on what title capitalisation should be used for quarries.

For further details please see [[#Quarry or quarry|above]]. [[User:WT79|WT79]] <sup class="plainlinks">([[User Talk:WT79|speak to me]] &#124; [//xtools.wmflabs.org/ec/en.wikipedia/WT79 editing patterns] &#124; [//xtools.wmflabs.org/globalcontribs/WT79 what I been doing])</sup> 20:45, 9 September 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:List of Joe Biden 2020 presidential campaign endorsements#rfc_4E18557|Talk:List of Joe Biden 2020 presidential campaign endorsements]] expired 2020-10-10 05:01 ===
* Id: 4E18557
* User: Lima Bean Farmer
* Date: 2020-10-09 00:04:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|982578531|POL 982578531}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|982578538|PROJ 982578538}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|982759713|POL 982759713}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|982759714|PROJ 982759714}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should independent groups of people be listed as an endorsement? I‚Äôll elaborate: As per section 2 of [[WP:ENDORSEMENTS]], ‚ÄúLists of endorsements should only include endorsements which have been covered by reliable independent sources.‚Äù On occasion, a website will pop up such as The Lincoln Project or national security officials for Biden which list people who have signed on as endorsements. These are not independent sources, but they are covered by independent sources. As a hypothetical example, the New York Times might report that a new group called we endorse Biden popped up announcing 120 new endorsements. The NYT doesn‚Äôt list all of the endorsees because the list is too long, they may name a few or none at all. In this case, should these names be added? Should they be referenced to the NYT article or the website of 120 new endorsements or both? As you can see, independent sources cover the endorsement, but they do not list all of the names. Just to clarify, I am not referring to anything referring to social media, so this rfc is not about ‚ÄúTwitter is reliable‚Äù or ‚ÄúYoutube is not reliable‚Äù, only official organizations or websites. [[User:Lima Bean Farmer|Lima Bean Farmer]] ([[User talk:Lima Bean Farmer|talk]]) 00:04, 9 October 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_840CCB5|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2020-10-12 09:01 ===
* Id: 840CCB5
* Date: 2020-10-09 13:34:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|982653274|POL 982653274}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|984629934|POL 984629934}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Fox is correctly considered dubious for politics, does this prevent use of Fox as a source for political endorsements? '''[[user:JzG|Guy]]''' <small>([[user talk:JzG|help!]] - [[User:JzG/Typos|typo?]])</small> 13:34, 9 October 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Lichess#rfc_673B8F6|Talk:Lichess]] expired 2020-10-14 23:01 ===
* Id: 673B8F6
* User: ThijsLaarhoven
* Date: 2020-09-14 22:35:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|978439933|SOC 978439933}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|983561552|SOC 983561552}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Over time various people (presumably mostly new users) have proposed to add a list of titled arena winners to this page, with experienced users rolling back and undoing these edits, marking them as promotional content and primary-source only. An RfC was then held in March 2020 and closed after two members added their opinions, voting against adding such a list.

As stated above, even if the consensus remains that such events are not suitable for Wikipedia, I believe it is inconsistent to then allow for pages such as [[2017 Speed Chess Championship]] and [[2018 Speed Chess Championship]] to exist, with the former having 24 references out of which 24 are to Chess.com, and the latter having 25 out of which 23 are to Chess.com. So I believe the discussion should be reopened, if only to address this inconsistency.

As for the point raised in the previous RfC that this table would double the page length, again this equivalently applies to e.g. [[2018 Speed Chess Championship]], which is significantly longer than [[Chess.com]].

Regarding external references, as mentioned in [[Lichess]] a.o. Forbes, Slate, and Der Spiegel have previously made note of the titled arenas and Carlsen's performance in these events, which suggests there is more interest in these results besides the Lichess community. [[User:ThijsLaarhoven|Thijs Laarhoven]] ([[User talk:ThijsLaarhoven|talk]]) 22:35, 14 September 2020 (UTC)}}

# At the bottom of the "'''Read''' or '''find''' an article" section: {{tq2|1=It is possible to '''[[Help:Mobile access|access Wikipedia on multiple platforms]]'''. The desktop version of English Wikipedia is located at '''https://en.wikipedia.org'''. The mobile version of English Wikipedia is located at '''https://en.m.wikipedia.org''' (also very useful on desktop and laptop computers, to display articles in large print across the entire width of the screen without the side menu, making them much easier to read).}}

=== [[Talk:Nicholas II of Russia#rfc_F663D98|Talk:Nicholas II of Russia]] expired 2020-10-16 23:01 ===
* Id: F663D98
* User: Emiya1980
* Date: 2020-09-16 22:47:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|978787034|BIO 978787034}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|978787036|HIST 978787036}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|978787043|POL 978787043}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|983902187|BIO 983902187}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|983902194|HIST 983902194}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|983902198|POL 983902198}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 Lately, I have been arguing with editors, {{u|Joker0002710}} and {{u|Mattia332}}, over whether Nicholas II should be characterized as a "good ruler" in the lead. In light of the sources I've cited as well as the overwhelming evidence set forth in the article, it is my position that such a description is a [[Wikipedia:Neutral_point_of_view#Due_and_undue_weight|minority viewpoint]] which should not be used to sum up assessments of his reign recently made after the Soviet Union's fall. If the consensus among Wikipedia's Community is that this view should be included, I'll yield the argument. However, it seems very inappropriate to do so given the existing consensus on Nicholas's reign. [[User:Emiya1980|Emiya1980]] ([[User talk:Emiya1980|talk]]) 22:47, 16 September 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:George Floyd protests#rfc_B5722D2|Talk:George Floyd protests]] expired 2020-10-17 08:01 ===
* Id: B5722D2
* User: Dilbaggg
* Date: 2020-10-10 18:53:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|982849215|HIST 982849215}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|983954791|HIST 983954791}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There have been no reported incident regarding George Floyd since August, absolutely no [[WP:RS]] says it is still ongoing, and nowhere other than Wikipedia based on opinions of certain editors the protests are still considered ongoing. This was stated before, it is an update after 2 months, there has not been any protest relating to George Floyd since August, no [[WP:V]] that is ongoing and people are mixing up the protests relating to the [[Killing of George Floyd]] with other [[Black Lives Matter]] protests which have been going on for decades and protests relating to the 2020 election. It is not an official war like the [[American Civil War]] that there has to be a declaration the protests are over, but like the [[1992 Los Angeles riots]] which was over when no further incidents of protests were reported. There are no reports or [[WP:RS]] that the George Floyd protests are still ongoing, thus it must be referred to as an event of the past. This was the last reported George Floyd protest incident on August 3rd [https://www.koin.com/news/protests/live-blog-night-65-of-protests-in-portland/]. While the George Floyd protests may not be ongoing anymore, protests relating to other issues of racism and police brutality may be included in other [[Black Lives Matter]] movement articles. Please [[WP:AGF]] [[User:Dilbaggg|Dilbaggg]] ([[User talk:Dilbaggg|talk]]) 18:53, 10 October 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Andy Ngo#rfc_CBEB9DC|Talk:Andy Ngo]] expired 2020-10-17 10:01 ===

* User: LokiTheLiar

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
We currently have the following text in the lede of this article:

{{tq|In August 2019, footage from May was published showing Ngo with armed Patriot Prayer members prior to an alleged attack on a bar frequented by antifa protesters. Ngo did not film the alleged planning of the attack, but did film parts of the attack itself. Ngo disputes that he was aware of the details of the plan. Following this incident, Ngo left Quillette.}}

We also have a more detailed description of the incident later in the article.

# Should this material be in the lede?
# How should we describe the incident? In particular, should we refer to it as "alleged planning" of an "alleged attack", or "planning" of an "attack", or something else entirely?

[[User:LokiTheLiar|Loki]] ([[User talk:LokiTheLiar|talk]]) 17:26, 8 October 2020 (UTC)}}

I'm not sure under what policy or authority this is being done, but these edits are disruptive and should stop. A couple of times, discussions have started, [[User_talk:Mike_Peel/Archive_56#Commons_templates_in_EL_are_"misplaced"?]] and [[User_talk:Mike_Peel#Vernon, Nevada]]. --[[User:evrik|evrik]]&nbsp;<sup>([[User talk:evrik|talk]])</sup> 03:40, 19 September 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Hungarian irredentism#rfc_24E1455|Talk:Hungarian irredentism]] expired 2020-10-21 01:01 ===
* Id: 24E1455
* User: KIENGIR
* Date: 2020-09-21 00:13:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|979477984|HIST 979477984}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|984602920|HIST 984602920}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The last stable consensused revision of the page is [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Hungarian_irredentism&diff=969855115&oldid=969855091 this]. As may be read on above talk, a few controversial edits has been introduced. Peer reviewed RS refer to the two official 1930 Romanian and 1941 Hungarian censuses and posit near equal the possible Romanian and Hungarian population in [[Northern Transylvania]], without taking sides. A user removed the ''significant Romanian population'' and took sides, claiming ''significant'' would not be neutral, at the same time added the Hitchins quote copied from the earlier mentioned article, which is exactly reflecting the neutral approach based on the two censuses,  not taking sides. Is really ''significant'' not an appropriate description? Or should be write instead ''near equal number of Romanians and Hungarians''? Or we should just refer it like in the Hungary in World War II article like ''a total population of 2,578,100 divided more or less evenly between Hungarians and Romanians (depending on the census, cf. [[Second Vienna Award#Statistics|Second Vienna Award]])''?([[User:KIENGIR|KIENGIR]] ([[User talk:KIENGIR|talk]]) 00:13, 21 September 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Historical policy of the Law and Justice party#rfc_40E9C40|Talk:Historical policy of the Law and Justice party]] expired 2020-10-24 10:01 ===
* Id: 40E9C40
* User: Kasha lover
* Date: 2020-10-24 05:38:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|985140384|HIST 985140384}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|985140390|POL 985140390}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|985140394|RELI 985140394}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|985140395|SOC 985140395}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|985162086|HIST 985162086}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|985162094|POL 985162094}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|985162099|RELI 985162099}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|985162104|SOC 985162104}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the following text, copied from [http://pis.org.pl/files/Program_PIS_2019.pdf the website of PiS], be inserted to the article as the first section? Text: "Since the end of 2015, Law and Justice has been implementing a conscious historical policy that encompasses many concrete tasks and programs. The policy must be systematically continued and developed in the following years. Its basic cornerstones include: the duty of real patronage of the state over culture and national heritage; care for the institutionalization of memory; protection of historical monuments and Polish heritage abroad, as well as the lost heritage; proper commemoration of anniversaries and persons important to Poland; an active audiovisual and media policy and an active educational policy in the field of cultural and historical identity." [[User:Kasha lover|Kasha lover]] ([[User talk:Kasha lover|talk]]) 05:38, 24 October 2020 (UTC)}}

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There are three questions:
#Should [[:Category:Communism]] be a subcategory of [[:Category:Totalitarianism]] or [[:Category:Authoritarianism]]?

#Should the article [[Authoritarianism]] be categorized in [[:Category:Communism]]?
RFC posted 03:03, 17 October 2020 (UTC)}}

There is a dispute about changes in origin section particularly related to derogatory words used here and also the origin image?
*The origin of the Rajputs has been a much-debated topic among the historians. Modern historians agree that Rajputs consisted of a mixing of various different social groups including Shudras and tribals.
*Thus, modern scholars summarise that Rajputs were a "group of open status" since the eighth century, mostly illiterate warriors who claimed to be reincarnates of ancient Indian Kshatriyas ‚Äì a claim that had no historical basis.

=== [[Talk:Committee for a Workers' International (1974)#rfc_F6DD6A8|Talk:Committee for a Workers' International (1974)]] expired 2020-10-27 19:01 ===

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the following paragraph added by [[User:Abu ali]] be included in the body of the article or should the site(s) mentioned be listed under "External links" instead?
::The  CWI have published their main documents of the debate leading up to the Split in the book "In Defence of Trotskyism". They have also made the most important documents from both sides available on the marxism.net website<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://marxist.net/in-defence-of-trotskyism-the-documents/|title=In Defence of Trotskyism ‚Äì the documents ‚Äì Marxist.net|language=en-GB|access-date=2020-03-28}}</ref>. The ISA produced over a hundred documents during the course of the debate, but have not published any of them online. <ref>{{cite web |title=Continuing the Fight for International Socialism |url=https://internationalsocialist.net/en/2019/10/cwi |website=International Socialist Alternative |accessdate=September 19, 2020}}</ref>

:Pinging all individuals who have commented in the talk page or the two related articles in the past year. {{u|Vahvistus}} {{u|Golightlys}} {{u|Yevgeni Preobrazhensky}} {{u|Cullen328}} {{u|FranciscoR}} {{u|SolTrek }} {{u|Abu ali}} {{u|Andysoh}} {{u|Primefac}} {{u|DuncanBCS}} [[User:Sowny|Sowny]] ([[User talk:Sowny|talk]]) 15:04, 2 October 2020 (UTC)}}


=== [[Talk:Committee for a Workers' International (1974)#rfc_AB93471|Talk:Committee for a Workers' International (1974)]] expired 2020-10-27 19:01 ===
* Id: AB93471
* User: Sowny
* Date: 2020-09-27 18:02:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|980660982|POL 980660982}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|985749904|POL 985749904}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the infobox of this article include a link to [http://www.internationalsocialist.net/en/ internationalsocialist.net] (one of the organizations that claims to be the successor of the original CWI - see [[International Socialist Alternative]]) [http://www.socialistworld.net/ socialistworld.net] (an organization which claims to have dissolved and refounded the CWI - see [[Committee for a Workers' International (2019)]]), neither organization, or both organizations. There is a second dispute - I hope to open an RFC for it once the current RFC is concluded. [[User:Sowny|Sowny]] ([[User talk:Sowny|talk]]) 18:02, 27 September 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Notability (organizations and companies)#rfc_7C29D4B|Wikipedia talk:Notability (organizations and companies)]] expired 2020-10-29 22:01 ===
* Id: 7C29D4B
* User: Ad Meliora
* Date: 2020-10-29 20:54:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|986108899|POLICY 986108899}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|986116387|POLICY 986116387}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I would like to start a discussion on the notability of publishers (including companies that publish books, newspapers and magazines, as well as production companies that create radio and television programs, or films, and perhaps other types I am missing here). The organization/company SNG says companies don't become notable by having notable products. I would like to invite a discussion on how strictly this would apply to publishers, considering that [[WP:COMMON|common sense]] dictates a film studio (for example) is notable based on the films it creates, not random coverage it might have gotten somewhere; it's a bit like [[WP:PROF]], in that the the company becomes notable by its work/output being "cited", so to say. ‚Äî '''[[User:Ad Meliora|Ad Meliora]]''' [[User talk:Ad Meliora|<sup>Talk</sup>]]‚àï[[Special:Contributions/Ad Meliora|<sub>Contribs</sub>]] 20:54, 29 October 2020 (UTC)}}


=== [[Wikipedia talk:Notability (people)#rfc_5880B21|Wikipedia talk:Notability (people)]] expired 2020-10-29 22:01 ===
* Id: 5880B21
* User: Ad Meliora
* Date: 2020-10-29 20:48:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|986108899|POLICY 986108899}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|986108905|PROP 986108905}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|986116387|POLICY 986116387}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|986116394|PROP 986116394}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Interviews are considered primary sources, and we don't rely on primary sources for our facts. That is clear. However, there seems to be a degree of confusion when it comes to use of interviews to establish notability. It is a bit surprising that interviews have not been adequately dealt with in WP policy. My own view is that the principle of [[WP:OR]] applies to factual information, not notability. [[WP:COMMON|Common sense]] dictates that the fact that a subject has an interview published in a major [[WP:RS]]/[[WP:IS]] makes them notable (i.e. counts towards [[WP:SIGCOV]] requirement), same as a profile would. But should we take every piece of information provided in the interview as fact? Of course not! I would like to invite a discussion on this issue. ‚Äî '''[[User:Ad Meliora|Ad Meliora]]''' [[User talk:Ad Meliora|<sup>Talk</sup>]]‚àï[[Special:Contributions/Ad Meliora|<sub>Contribs</sub>]] 20:48, 29 October 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Persecution of Christians#rfc_C61CCAE|Talk:Persecution of Christians]] expired 2020-10-31 04:01 ===
* Id: C61CCAE
* User: Jenhawk777
* Date: 2020-10-28 06:14:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|985836601|POL 985836601}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|985836602|RELI 985836602}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|986324987|POL 986324987}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|986324993|RELI 986324993}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I request input from other editors on this sentence in the lead: {{tqq|Christianity also enjoys dominant group privilege in the US and some other Western societies.}}  Although it's in the lead, it is not a summary of anything, as there is no discussion of it anywhere in the text. It claims one point of view, making a statement in Wikipedia's voice, without mentioning other viewpoints, and most importantly without defining what "dominant" or "group privilege" mean or refer to. And it is unattributed. 

Perhaps a discussion of what the sources say on this should be in the text somewhere, perhaps under current situation, but imo, it should most definitely include a discussion of what these terms mean with regard to religion, (not race or social class), in sociology, and psychology, and with some reference to how these terms are used on a practical basis in research by PEW and other sources like them.

Then there would need to be some explanation of what impact this has on persecution, since that is allegedly what this page is about. [[User:Jenhawk777|Jenhawk777]] ([[User talk:Jenhawk777|talk]]) 06:14, 28 October 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:People's Mujahedin of Iran#rfc_9023D3A|Talk:People's Mujahedin of Iran]] expired 2020-11-01 11:01 ===
* Id: 9023D3A
* User: Stefka Bulgaria
* Date: 2020-10-02 10:38:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|981447620|HIST 981447620}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|981447629|POL 981447629}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|981447631|SOC 981447631}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|986520129|HIST 986520129}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|986520133|POL 986520133}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|986520137|SOC 986520137}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This RfC takes into account the points made in the previous RfC [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:People%27s_Mujahedin_of_Iran#RfC_about_copy-editing_%22cult%22_claims_in_the_article "about copy-editing "cult" claims in the article"].

Shall we summarize the following:

{{tq|According to a BBC article, the US government described the MEK as a "Cult", with one US colonel saying "the organisation was a cult", and yet another retired US general saying "Cult? How about admirably focused group?". United States Department of State describes MEK in a 2008 report as "cult-like terrorist organisation". Iraq's ambassador to the U.S., Samir Sumaidaie, said in 2011 that the MEK was "nothing more than a cult". Some academics, including Ervand Abrahamian, Stephanie Cronin, Wilfried Buchta, Eli Clifton and others have also made similar claims. Former French Foreign Ministry spokesman Romain Nadal criticized the MEK for having a "cult nature"; while Former French Foreign Minister Bernard Kouchner said that he was "ashamed" by this statement.|}}

{{tq|A report commissioned by the US government, based on interviews within Camp Ashraf, concluded that the MEK had "many of the typical characteristics of a cult, such as authoritarian control, confiscation of assets, sexual control (including mandatory divorce and celibacy), emotional isolation, forced labour, sleep deprivation, physical abuse and limited exit options". In 2003 Elizabeth Rubin referred to the MEK as "Cult of Rajavi".|}} [[User:Stefka Bulgaria|Stefka Bulgaria]] ([[User talk:Stefka Bulgaria|talk]]) 10:38, 2 October 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Democratic Progressive Party#rfc_A842B7D|Talk:Democratic Progressive Party]] expired 2020-11-02 18:01 ===

=== [[Talk:Orgone#rfc_46A7D52|Talk:Orgone]] expired 2020-11-03 01:01 ===
* Id: 46A7D52
* User: Iss246
* Date: 2020-11-02 20:31:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|986758935|SCI 986758935}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|986790310|SCI 986790310}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 

What is the nature of the relationship to [[occupational burnout]] to [[depression]]?

Older research suggests that they are separate entities. Newer research suggests that there is substantial overlap. One key to this controversy is the problem of comparing scores on BO scales like exhaustion to the presence/absence of a depression diagnosis. That kind of comparison is problematic because any relation between a continuous factor like BO's exhaustion to a binary entity like depression present/absent will have a smaller correlation than the relation between two continuous factors.

Recent research on psychopathology (cited in the latest version of the occupational BO article) indicates that depression is better conceptualized as a dimension (on a continuum) than as a taxon. The latest, most methodologically advanced research (also cited in the article), which treats BO and depression as continuous entities, reveals very high correlations, r >= 0.80. In the social sciences, correlations that high suggest that the two measures involved reflect the same underlying entity. In addition, methodologically advanced research that relies on structural equation modeling bifactor analysis, which takes a granular look at the items in BO and depression scales, suggests the BO's exhaustion items and depression items reflect the same entity. [[User:Iss246|Iss246]] ([[User talk:Iss246|talk]]) 20:31, 2 November 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:TikTok#rfc_B4FCA09|Talk:TikTok]] expired 2020-11-03 13:01 ===

* RFC Text:

*'''Option 1:''' "'''TikTok''' is a viral video-sharing social networking service owned by Chinese company ByteDance."
*'''Option 2:''' "'''TikTok''' is a viral Chinese video-sharing social networking service owned by Chinese company ByteDance"

=== [[Talk:2020 Atlantic hurricane season#rfc_E9D1945|Talk:2020 Atlantic hurricane season]] expired 2020-11-03 22:02 ===
* Id: E9D1945
* User: Knowledgekid87
* Date: 2020-10-12 18:27:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|986942912|SCI 986942912}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Quicklink for reference: [[Tropical Storm Arthur (2020)]]

I am making this section in response to the suggestion above. I encourage editors to read my objections before making a quick judgement by looks or current article size alone.

*The entire "Meteorological history" section of the article uses a single primary source ([[WP:PRIMARY]]). The formation and events surrounding any given tropical system are considered to be routine unless something is unusual in the way they form or develop.
*Damage was limited in the Caribbean according to the sources used.
*"Although Arthur never directly impacted Florida as a tropical system, the precursor system to Arthur caused heavy rainfall and gusty winds in the Florida Keys and South Florida throughout May 13-14. Over 4 in (101.6 mm) of rain fell in many sections of the Middle Keys and a peak rainfall total of 5.35 in (135.8 mm) fell in Marathon on May 14, where it was the tenth highest rainfall amount for the city on record and second most for May." This is a bit of a stretch... if the sources are not directly blaming the rainfall on Arthur then it could be seen as [[WP:SYNTH]].
*The rest of the impacts section is full of [[WP:ROUTINE]] news reports about rainfall during a tropical system. When tropical systems hit, there is going to be rainfall and flooding. Nothing unusual or [[WP:LASTING]] about that unless it is noted otherwise. 
 
So in conclusion... I do not think Arthur needs an article. The information can be condensed into a summary that does not go into run of the mill detailed information. - [[User:Knowledgekid87|Knowledgekid87]] ([[User talk:Knowledgekid87|talk]]) 18:27, 12 October 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Captions#rfc_D1564E8|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Captions]] expired 2020-11-03 22:03 ===
* Id: D1564E8
* User: Sdkb
* Date: 2020-10-04 21:31:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|981868972|STYLE 981868972}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|986942918|STYLE 986942918}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
When I see videos in mainspace, they sometimes include a note of how long they are in the caption. I'd like to see what the community thinks of this practice, and how best to format the note if it is included. You may !vote from the list below with a combination of a number and a letter, and feel free to add additional options.

*'''Option 1''': Do not include a length note.
*'''Option 2''': Include a length note whenever desired, on a case-by-case basis.
*'''Option 3''': Generally include a length note in normal circumstances.

*'''Option A large''': Example caption. (4:07)
*'''Option A small''': Example caption. <small>(4:07)</small>
*'''Option B small''': Example caption. <small>(4:07&nbsp;min)</small>
*'''Option C small''': Example caption. <small>(4:07&nbsp;{{abbr|min|minutes}})</small>
*'''Option D small''': Example caption. <small>(4&nbsp;min&nbsp;7&nbsp;s)</small>
*'''Option E small''': Example caption. <small>(4&nbsp;{{abbr|min|minutes}}&nbsp;7&nbsp;{{abbr|s|seconds}})</small>
*'''Option F small''': Example caption. <small>(4&nbsp;minutes&nbsp;7&nbsp;seconds)</small>
*'''Option G small''': Example caption. <small>(4&nbsp;min&nbsp;7&nbsp;sec)</small>
*'''Option H small''': Example caption. <small>(4&nbsp;{{abbr|min|minutes}}&nbsp;7&nbsp;{{abbr|sec|seconds}})</small>
*'''Option I small''': Example caption. <small>(4&nbsp;m&nbsp;7&nbsp;s)</small>
*'''Option J small''': Example caption. <small>(4&nbsp;{{abbr|m|minutes}}&nbsp;7&nbsp;{{abbr|s|seconds}})</small>

I didn't list out all the large options to keep the list short, but if you want to !vote e.g. '''Option 2C large''', feel free to do so.
<span style="color:#AAA"><small>&#123;{u&#124;</small><span style="border-radius:9em;padding:0 5px;background:#088">[[User:Sdkb|<span style="color:#FFF">'''Sdkb'''</span>]]</span><small>}&#125;</small></span>‚ÄØ<sup>[[User talk:Sdkb|'''talk''']]</sup> 21:31, 4 October 2020 (UTC)}}

The whole statement removed by the IP is: {{talkquote|Islamic scholar [[Sayyid Mumtaz Ali]], while commenting on whether Adam was first or Eve, says that "the fact that Adam was created first is nothing but childish. To begin with, we are tempted to assert that this is so because it was not acceptable to God that a woman is left without a companion for even a second. Therefore, it is for her sake that He created Adam first. But as a matter of fact, the belief that Adam was created first and then came Eve is part of the Christian and Jewish faith. This is not at all part of the Islamic creed. There is no mention in the Quran about who was created first, Adam or Eve."<ref>{{cite book |last1=Deobandi |first1=Sayyid Mumtaz Ali |authorlink1=Sayyid Mumtaz Ali |title=Huquq-e-Niswan |publisher=Rifah-e-Aam Press |location=[[Lahore]] |pages=21‚Äì22 |edition=1898 |url=https://archive.org/details/HuqooqENiswan |accessdate=22 August 2020 |language=Urdu |quote=Adapted from [[Javed Anand]]'s translation to [https://www.sabrang.com/cc/archive/2009/oct09/cover1.html the piece]}}</ref>}} {{reftalk}} Should the statement be include per [[WP:RSOPINION]] or not? === [[Talk:Biden‚ÄìUkraine conspiracy theory#rfc_B2BF918|Talk:Biden‚ÄìUkraine conspiracy theory]] expired 2020-11-06 08:01 ===
* Id: B2BF918
* User: Elijahandskip
* Date: 2020-10-16 16:14:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|983879303|POL 983879303}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|987321049|POL 987321049}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
{Logic statement, ignoring WIKI policy and sorry for any people pinged}  
*Background
So let me drop a quick logic statement.  Wikipedia is supposed to remain unbiased in articles.  So in the opening statement, the article has "The Biden-Ukraine conspiracy theory is a series of false allegations".  I undid the word false as the FBI still has the computer.  {{u|Valjean}} undid my revision with the comment "Follow the RS in the body (IOW, pretty much NEVER revert content with such an editorial note without extensive discussion first). This article isn't just about the last New York Post matter."  So I read the body section.

Now let me give some logic.  About 90% (maybe 100%) of the sources in the Background section are liberal sources (In general, Go Biden, Boo Trump...Those sources).  Logically, they would all say "FALSE!" to any comments about a democrat/liberal, because those are the people they support.  For example, CNN just after the allegations (NY post talk) came out, immediately started saying they were false and then never reported it.  Fox News (Using Logic, ignoring WIKI RS policies) is running with the story.  HOWEVER, Fox News and the majority of non-liberal sources, are leaving the fact in that they might be true.  Knowing how Wikipedia is supposed to be unbiased, should the body have some conservative sources?  {LOGIC Statement:  If you want to know why Wikipedia is saying 'False' to the allegations, it is because the article only has liberal sources, which say 'false'.} (Current Event WikiProject Coordinator) [[User:Elijahandskip|Elijahandskip]] ([[User talk:Elijahandskip|talk]]) 16:14, 16 October 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:2020 Bangalore riots#rfc_F004494|Talk:2020 Bangalore riots]] expired 2020-11-08 21:01 ===
* Id: F004494
* User: Dilbaggg
* Date: 2020-10-09 20:26:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|982710788|HIST 982710788}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|987720678|HIST 987720678}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
[[WP:RS]] clearly states the riots occurred in the late hours of August 11 and early hours of August 12. [https://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/bangalore-riots-karnataka-to-approach-hc-for-help-on-recovery-of-cost-from-rioters/story-t0rrYkPv4Oyulrg6FHAWLK.html] and [https://indianexpress.com/article/cities/bangalore/bengaluru-violence-dj-halli-kg-halli-srinivas-murthy-derogatory-social-media-post-6551265/] among many. Also it is a Universal fact that past mind night, 12 AM is a new date but perhaps [[User:Slatersteven]] isn't aware of this fact, and is desperatley trying to push the end date as 11 August 2020, despite no [[WP:RS]] anywhere claiming that riots ended on August 11, incidents were reported on August 12 almost everywhere and major [[WP:RS]] including the two I showed specifically states the riots as a two day even on august 11 and August 12. Should we just include something based on individual user's opinion? No! We should include what [[WP:RS]] states! Wikipedia is about accuracy not personal opinions of certain users. [[User:Dilbaggg|Dilbaggg]] ([[User talk:Dilbaggg|talk]]) 20:26, 9 October 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Lists#rfc_D06AFDB|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Lists]] expired 2020-11-10 09:01 ===
* Id: D06AFDB
* User: Sdkb
* Date: 2020-10-11 08:10:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|982941683|STYLE 982941683}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|987969198|STYLE 987969198}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
It is common practice to abbreviate reference column titles to keep their width narrow. However, even among featured lists, I've noticed considerable variation in format, e.g. [[List_of_accolades_received_by_Her_(film)#Accolades|1]]{{nbsp}}[[List_of_World_Heritage_in_Danger#Currently listed sites|2]]{{nbsp}}[[List_of_Hot_C%26W_Sides_number_ones_of_1961#Chart history|3]]{{nbsp}}[[List_of_awards_and_nominations_received_by_Alicia_Vikander#Awards_and_nominations|4]]{{nbsp}}[[Hawthorn_Memorial_Trophy#List_of_winners|5]]. This RfC seeks to find agreement on the best format for these titles, which could then be added to this guideline or encoded in a template. Here are a bunch of options:
{{div col}}
#Ref
#Ref.
#Refs
#Refs.
#Ref(s)
#Ref(s).
#{{abbr|Ref|Reference}}{{pad}}[Tooltip: Reference]
#{{abbr|Ref|References}}{{pad}}[Tooltip: References]
#{{abbr|Ref|Reference(s)}}{{pad}}[Tooltip: Reference(s)]
#{{abbr|Ref.|Reference}}{{pad}}[Tooltip: Reference]
#{{abbr|Ref.|References}}{{pad}}[Tooltip: References]
#{{abbr|Ref.|Reference(s)}}{{pad}}[Tooltip: Reference(s)]
#{{abbr|Refs|References}}{{pad}}[Tooltip: References]
#{{abbr|Refs|Reference(s)}}{{pad}}[Tooltip: Reference(s)]
#{{abbr|Refs.|References}}{{pad}}[Tooltip: References]
#{{abbr|Refs.|Reference(s)}}{{pad}}[Tooltip: Reference(s)]
#{{abbr|Ref(s)|Reference(s)}}{{pad}}[Tooltip: Reference(s)]
#{{abbr|Ref(s).|Reference(s)}}{{pad}}[Tooltip: Reference(s)]
#Have no standard.
#Don't allow abbreviations; always use {{tq|Reference}}, {{tq|References}}, or {{tq|Reference(s)}}.
{{div col end}}
Cheers, <span style="color:#AAA"><small>&#123;{u&#124;</small><span style="border-radius:9em;padding:0 5px;background:#088">[[User:Sdkb|<span style="color:#FFF">'''Sdkb'''</span>]]</span><small>}&#125;</small></span>‚ÄØ<sup>[[User talk:Sdkb|'''talk''']]</sup> 08:10, 11 October 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Citing sources#rfc_8C4521E|Wikipedia talk:Citing sources]] expired 2020-11-12 16:01 ===
* Id: 8C4521E
* User: Guy Macon
* Date: 2020-11-11 22:01:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|988274709|STYLE 988274709}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|988341623|STYLE 988341623}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should citation tools be allowed?

Background:
* [[Wikipedia:Citing sources#Citation templates and tools]]
* [[Help:Citation tools]]
* [[:Category:Wikipedia citation/link tools]]
Currently, tools such as [[Wikipedia:AutoEd|AutoEd]], [[Wikipedia:AutoWikiBrowser|AutoWikiBrowser]] and [[User:Kaniivel/Reference Organizer|Reference Organizer]] may be used to make changes to citation styles on individual pages.

(This is about using such tools on single pages and carefully checking the results before publishing. Using such tools on many pages in an automated fashion is far more controversial and would require a separate discussion.)

{{userlinks|Lithopsian}} has decided that edits made with such tools should not be allowed[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=User_talk:Kaniivel/Reference_Organizer&diff=prev&oldid=988216459] and has started reverting them.[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Eta_Carinae&diff=prev&oldid=988211071][https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Eta_Carinae&diff=prev&oldid=988215534]

:'''Proposed: citation tools may be used on individual Wikipedia articles. The person using the tool should preview the page and carefully check the results before publishing. Such edits should not be reverted unless they introduce errors, and in particular should not be reverted simply because someone does not like the resulting citation style.''' 

--[[User:Guy Macon|Guy Macon]] ([[User talk:Guy Macon|talk]]) 22:01, 11 November 2020 (UTC)}}

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|988406634|BIO 988406634}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|988406647|SOC 988406647}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|988406651|POLICY 988406651}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
What is the reliability of ''Sherdog.com''?
*'''Option 1:''' Generally [[WP:RS|reliable]]
*'''Option 2:''' Reliable, in the absense of generally reliable sources
*'''Option 3:''' Unclear or additional considerations apply
*'''Option 4:''' Generally [[WP:QUESTIONABLE|unreliable]]
*'''Option 5:''' Publishes false or fabricated information, and should be [[WP:DEPS|deprecated]]
[[User:Lordpermaximum|Lordpermaximum]] ([[User talk:Lordpermaximum|talk]]) 23:20, 13 October 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[User:Davide King/sandbox#rfc_05EC36C|User:Davide King/sandbox]] expired 2020-11-13 00:01 ===
* Id: 05EC36C
* User: Davide King
* Date: 2020-11-10 21:01:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|988399435|POL 988399435}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|988406642|POL 988406642}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
What is, or should be, the main topic of this article?
# Communist genocide/mass killing
# Crimes against humanity/Mass killings under Joseph Stalin, Mao Zedong and Pol Pot
# Double genocide theory
# Excess deaths under Communist regimes
# Mass killings under Communist regimes
# Scholarly analysis of Communist regimes
# Victims of Communism

What is the status of the current article's main topic?
# The topic exist and it is mainstream
# The topic exist, but it is a minority view.
# The topic does not exist and the article should be deleted/merged, or a new, clear main topic established.

You are free to add more main topic possibilities. Below, I will summarise how each main topic could be structured. Please, do not just state your support for a main topic or that it does exist, without providing an analysis of sources; same thing for those who do not think the topic exists. [[User:Davide King|Davide King]] ([[User talk:Davide King|talk]]) 21:01, 10 November 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Template talk:Infobox album#rfc_DF9FE8B|Template talk:Infobox album]] expired 2020-11-13 04:02 ===
* Id: DF9FE8B
* User: 41matt14
* Date: 2020-10-14 03:02:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|988434208|MEDIA 988434208}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There have been some discussions and disagreements on K-Pop album pages whether a K-Pop album's repackage counts as a re-release and therefore its single should be omitted from the Infobox Album. The argument has been presented that the repackaged album has its own, separate promotional period, and that the Track Listing can circumvent potential confusion around the single not belonging to the original album.
[[User:41matt14|41matt14]] ([[User talk:41matt14|talk]]) 03:02, 14 October 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Abortion law#rfc_B784A3A|Talk:Abortion law]] expired 2020-11-15 20:01 ===
* Id: B784A3A
* User: Heitordp
* Date: 2020-11-09 01:13:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|987758312|POL 987758312}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|987758314|RELI 987758314}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|988877250|POL 988877250}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|988877252|RELI 988877252}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The official interpretation of canon law of the Catholic Church regarding abortion is to allow only indirect abortion in case it's necessary to save the woman's life.[https://www.ewtn.com/catholicism/library/abortion-and-the-catholic-church-9580][http://natcath.org/NCR_Online/archives/011703/011703d.htm] Canon law is the primary source of law of Vatican City,[https://www.vaticanstate.va/it/norm-general.html?download=10:legge-sulle-fonti-del-diritto-1-ottobre-2008-n-lxxi] but it's unclear whether any abortion has been performed there, perhaps due to lack of cases or medical facilities. What colors should be used for Vatican City in the column for "save life" in the table and in the maps? [[User:Heitordp|Heitordp]] ([[User talk:Heitordp|talk]]) 01:13, 9 November 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Catholic Church sexual abuse cases#rfc_BE5FFAB|Talk:Catholic Church sexual abuse cases]] expired 2020-11-17 06:01 ===
* Id: BE5FFAB
* User: Elizium23
* Date: 2020-10-18 05:49:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|984103953|RELI 984103953}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|989130735|RELI 989130735}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the article [[Catholic Church abuse cases]] be merged into this article ([[Catholic Church sexual abuse cases]])?
:It is time to reopen discussion in order to achieve consensus to merge these two articles covering one singular topic. But first I would like to address an elephant in the room. There are '''far too many''' Catholic sex abuse articles to manage right now. There is a ton of overlap, just peruse [[:Category:Catholic Church sexual abuse scandals]] and try to visualize the proliferation of articles that all cover topics in a large, crowded, Venn diagram. Here's what happens. There are several IPs who are quite reliable and diligent at adding information to articles like this. When they add a case, it goes in 2-3 disparate articles, identical text. Then someone else like me comes in to edit it. Why should I be forced to edit 3 articles which contain identical information? We invented transclusion for a specific reason. These articles need to be overhauled so that (a) the topics do not overlap so much and (b) duplicated prose is maintained in one and only one central location.
:Now, back to the merge. There is no reason to retain the moribund article [[Catholic Church abuse cases]]. Let's take what's useful and bring it to the aforementioned central location, and then toss the rest overboard. What say you? (Would it be appropriate to start an RFC for wider participation?) [[User:Elizium23|Elizium23]] ([[User talk:Elizium23|talk]]) 05:49, 18 October 2020 (UTC)}}

# List of Communist mass killings

=== [[Talk:Crusades#rfc_95F79B6|Talk:Crusades]] expired 2020-11-18 10:01 ===
* Id: 95F79B6
* User: Norfolkbigfish
* Date: 2020-10-19 09:24:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|984296095|HIST 984296095}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|989325215|HIST 989325215}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
{{ping |Gog the Mild|Johnbod|Onceinawhile|Srnec|Borsoka}}

Ok, right. In association with the debate on splitting [[Crusades]] there is a related question on what the article or articles should be called and related to that what the content of each should be. Academics working in the crusades constantly argue between themselves over this and sometimes even argue against their own positions. This has issues of both depth and width of content. This article cannot cover the subject at an appropriate depth while also covering the bredth. A summary article has the challenge of inappropriate emphasis being given to topics only included in order to cover the bredth of the subject. It is unlikely that these issues could be resolved in a major tome let alone a single article on WP.

This requires a pragmatic solution. There is no summary article for the Crusades in the Levant/Near East. Although there are summary articles that have been in turn summarised here e.g. the C-Class [[Northern Crusades]] and [[Reconquista]]. This is in effect that article. But in being that article, some peoples' view of what the full bredth of the subject is cannot be covered here, the wider geographies and periods, the theories, politics, historiograhies, criticisms & ideologies. Neither would the average anglophone lay reader expect them to be covered. They would expect Muslims v Christians, Medieval warriors fighting in the Holy Land. Once they found it, they might feel inclined to make the academic journey and end up with Riley-Smith's near millenia of crusading through to the 19th{{nbsp}}century.

Comment is welcome on two questions:

'''* 1) What should this article be called?'''

'''* 2) What should any split articles be called?'''

To answer these two questions feedback on the scope of 1) and any other split articles would also be helpful.[[User:Norfolkbigfish|Norfolkbigfish]] ([[User talk:Norfolkbigfish|talk]]) 09:24, 19 October 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Mass killings under communist regimes#rfc_8A40473|Talk:Mass killings under communist regimes]] expired 2020-11-19 21:01 ===
* Id: 8A40473
* User: Davide King
* Date: 2020-11-18 06:46:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|989466623|HIST 989466623}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|989473003|POL 989473003}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|989584717|HIST 989584717}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|989584723|POL 989584723}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
What is, or should be, the main topic of this article?
# Communist genocide/mass killing
# Crimes against humanity/Mass killings under Joseph Stalin, Mao Zedong and Pol Pot
# Double genocide theory
# Excess deaths under Communist regimes
# List of Communist mass killings
# Mass killings under Communist regimes
# Scholarly analysis of Communist regimes
# Victims of Communism

What is the status of the current article's main topic?
# The topic does exist and it is mainstream
# The topic does exist, but it is a minority or [[Wikipedia:Fringe theory|fringe]] view.
# The topic does not exist and the article should be deleted/merged, or a new, clearer main topic established.

You are free to add more main topic possibilities. Below, I will summarise how each main topic could be structured. Please, do not just state your support for a main topic or that it does exist, without providing an analysis of sources; same thing for those who do not think the topic exists. [[User:Davide King|Davide King]] ([[User talk:Davide King|talk]]) 06:46, 18 November 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_4A7CE69|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2020-11-19 23:01 ===
* Id: 4A7CE69
* User: 2402:3a80:a87:34bd:1dd8:9588:6b:8c73#top
* Date: 2020-11-19 12:16:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|989518169|PROP 989518169}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|989601269|PROP 989601269}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
== CounterPunch, Other98, and People's Democracy [by CPI(M)] on Left, and The Daily Wire, Blaze Media and Rebel News on the Right '''

These sources have consistently faulted on political news. While doing any academic writing, I had to cross check them with at least one more independent publication. My bottom line is based on the Daily Mail and The Sun. As to source progressive or conservative views, the mainstream outlets give ample voice to both sides on that note. I move the request to deprecate these sources for at least political news. {{small|1=<span class="autosigned">‚Äî&nbsp;Preceding [[Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[User:2402:3a80:a87:34bd:1dd8:9588:6b:8c73|2402:3a80:a87:34bd:1dd8:9588:6b:8c73]] ([[User talk:2402:3a80:a87:34bd:1dd8:9588:6b:8c73#top|talk]] ‚Ä¢ [[Special:Contributions/2402:3a80:a87:34bd:1dd8:9588:6b:8c73|contribs]]) </span>}}
: As far as I can tell, ''Other98'' and ''People's Democracy'' have never been discussed on RSN, and so are not eligible for an RfC. The other sources have already been discussed a fair bit, and deprecation never came up. In any case, deprecation for only one domain seems rather odd. If a source needs to be deprecated, it probably needs to be generally deprecated. 
: This suggestion seems overly broad and doesn't engage at all with past discussions/policy. For these reasons, I do not think engaging with this would yield useful results. Perhaps you could focus on a specific source and bring up specific reasons for changed status or discussion? [[User:Jlevi|Jlevi]] ([[User talk:Jlevi|talk]]) 12:16, 19 November 2020 (UTC)}}

Which option best describes the reliability of ''[[Newsmax]]''?

*'''Option 2:''' Unclear or additional considerations apply
*'''Option 3:''' Generally [[WP:QUESTIONABLE|unreliable]]
*'''Option 4:''' Publishes false or fabricated information, and should be [[WP:DEPS|deprecated]]

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Tropical cyclones#rfc_76A7B11|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Tropical cyclones]] expired 2020-11-23 14:01 ===
* Id: 76A7B11
* User: Hurricane Noah
* Date: 2020-10-24 13:59:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|985196065|SCI 985196065}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|990220604|SCI 990220604}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I hate to say this, but I believe us calculating ACE is a violation of [[WP:OR]]. This isn't simple mathematics by any means. It involves squaring, dividing, and adding together numbers hundreds of times. If you take a look at some of the published sources such as [http://tropical.atmos.colostate.edu/Realtime/index.php?arch&loc=northatlantic Colorado State], there are differences in multiple years. Some differences are as small as 0.1 units and others as large as 2-3 units. We should be using established sources for calculations like this rather than performing our own. Our numbers for the current seasons are actually off from what is listed for their real-time stats. I just don't think we should be using our own calcs when professionals say something else. Is it OR to perform such calculations? Should we use these calculations when professionals have other values listed? [[User:Hurricane Noah|<span style="white-space:nowrap;text-shadow:#009200 0.3em 0.4em 1.0em,#009200 -0.2em -0.2em 1.0em;color:#009200"><b>Noah</b></span>]]<sup>[[User talk:Hurricane Noah|<span style="color:#ff0000"><b>Talk</b></span>]]</sup> 13:59, 24 October 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_5F679EC|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2020-11-24 05:01 ===
* Id: 5F679EC
* User: TheSandDoctor
* Date: 2020-11-06 06:41:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|989911618|MEDIA 989911618}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|989911630|SOC 989911630}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|989911637|PROP 989911637}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|990385280|MEDIA 990385280}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|990385283|SOC 990385283}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|990385287|PROP 990385287}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
[https://www.metalreviews.com/ MetalReviews.com] was used in part [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Torn (Evergrey album)|to defend]] the notability of [[Torn (Evergrey album)]]. I would like to know if others consider it a reliable source.

Please choose one of the below:
*'''Option 1''' - MetalReviews is a generally reliable source.
*'''Option 2''' - MetalReviews is a questionable source, or should be used with considerations.
*'''Option 3''' - MetalReviews is a generally unreliable source.
*'''Option 4''' - MetalReviews needs to be deprecated due to providing false or fabricated information.


--[[User:TheSandDoctor|<span style="color:#FF9933; font-weight:bold; font-family:monotype;">The</span><span style="color:#009933; font-weight:bold;">SandDoctor</span>]] <sup>[[User talk:TheSandDoctor|<span style="color:#009933;">Talk</span>]]</sup> 06:41, 6 November 2020 (UTC)}}

* Id: 96FF40D
* User: Factfox
* Date: 2020-10-25 10:29:00

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
A discussion on whether illicit trade and black market are duplicate or distinct topics was started a few weeks ago after an editor replaced the article on illicit trade with a redirect to black market. The latest version of the illicit trade article before it was set to a redirect can be found at: {{oldid|Illicit_trade|974366109|permalink}}. I asked for help at two relevant wikiprojects (WP:crime and WP:Organized_Crime). After a few weeks without new input, the discussion appears stalled.

Earlier discussions related to this merge can be found at [[User_talk:MrOllie/Archive_11#Redirecting_illicit_trade_to_black_market]] and [[Talk:Black_market#Recent redirect from duplicate topic]]

Note that  I am the initiator of the illicit trade article and I have a close connexion with the topic. [[User:Factfox|Factfox]] ([[User talk:Factfox|talk]]) 10:29, 25 October 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Bah√°?√≠ Faith on life after death#rfc_2ED6D19|Talk:Bah√°?√≠ Faith on life after death]] expired 2020-11-26 15:01 ===
* Id: 2ED6D19
* User: Dereck Camacho
* Date: 2020-10-27 14:07:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|985715881|RELI 985715881}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|990791995|RELI 990791995}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I would like to see more input about the lenghty presence of the Near Death Experiences section. I think it might be breaking the Neutral Point of View as, at least on its current phrasing seems to endorse that NDE are evidence that the Bahai believes in the after life are true. NDE experiences are a very subjective and controversial topic; practically all religions see them as "evidence" of their belief system and people of different religions generally have NDE that coincidentally correspond to their respective belief (Christians report angels and Jesus or hell with fire and devils, for example). Thus its presence on an article about one particular religion might be over-reaching, but I would like to see other people's opinions. --[[User:Dereck Camacho|Dereck Camacho]] ([[User talk:Dereck Camacho|talk]]) 14:07, 27 October 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Lead section#rfc_C8FDC0C|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Lead section]] expired 2020-11-26 16:01 ===
* Id: C8FDC0C
* User: Onceinawhile
* Date: 2020-10-27 15:19:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|985724493|HIST 985724493}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|985724500|STYLE 985724500}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|990801290|HIST 990801290}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|990801291|STYLE 990801291}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
What does the ideal first sentence of "History of X" articles look like? 

MOS:LEADSENTENCE requires a statement of "what, or who, the subject is", which is not easy to apply to these articles. Across the project it is interpreted in different ways, such as:

# Stating how broad the history is (e.g. [[History of Slavery]], [[History of saffron]])
# Stating when the history started (e.g. [[History of the United States]], [[History of Baltimore City College]])
# Stating what X is (e.g. [[History of Gillingham F.C.]] or [[History of the British farthing]])
# Stating X's notability (e.g. [[History of the Wales national football team (1876‚Äì1976)]] or [[History of Israel]])

[[User:Onceinawhile|Onceinawhile]] ([[User talk:Onceinawhile|talk]]) 15:19, 27 October 2020 (UTC)}}

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Is including information regarding the topic of Saint Sava's sermons in the article relevant or not? Per WP:RELEVANCE. [[User:Edion Petriti|Edion Petriti]] ([[User talk:Edion Petriti|talk]]) 16:42, 27 October 2020 (UTC)}}

What sources should be used for calling states? Below are three of the (consensus) options from the section [[Talk:2020 United States presidential election#Election night prep|above]].

* '''Don't call anything'''

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (WMF)#rfc_96C0BD7|Wikipedia:Village pump (WMF)]] expired 2020-11-27 19:01 ===
* Id: 96C0BD7
* User: Alsee
* Date: 2020-10-28 18:43:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|985921282|PROP 985921282}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|990905464|TECH 990905464}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|991000986|TECH 991000986}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|991000993|PROP 991000993}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
As a result of the [[mw:Talk pages consultation 2019|Talk pages consultation 2019]], the Foundation ended their strategy to eliminate&replace Talk pages with [[mw:Flow|Flow]]. It also resulted in a decision to keep existing Talk pages, to keep existing Talk page editing, and to build new tools on top of the existing Talk system. The current project is called [[mw:Help:DiscussionTools|Discussion Tools]]. Discussion Tools is, in general, a promising product. It aims to add a Reply link after comments, and help automatically insert the comment into the page wikitext at the right spot with appropriate indentation. I hope to see it ultimately improved and deployed. However the RFC below describes a design problem with the product, and the project manager doesn't want to fix it. The proposal below seeks consensus that the product not be deployed until the design flaw is fixed. [[User:Alsee|Alsee]] ([[User talk:Alsee|talk]]) 18:43, 28 October 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Naomi Osaka#rfc_2ECED54|Talk:Naomi Osaka]] expired 2020-11-27 22:01 ===
* Id: 2ECED54
* User: Sportsfan77777
* Date: 2020-10-28 22:00:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|991029177|SOC 991029177}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the lead opening sentence state
#"''Naomi Osaka is a Japanese professional [[tennis]] player.''", or
#"''Naomi Osaka is a professional [[tennis]] player who represents Japan.''"
The previous RfC on this topic back in 2018 chose the second option, but a lot has changed since then. [[User:Sportsfan77777|Sportsfan77777]] ([[User talk:Sportsfan77777|talk]]) 22:00, 28 October 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Hamas#rfc_868D24C|Talk:Hamas]] expired 2020-11-28 19:01 ===
* Id: 868D24C
* User: Nishidani
* Date: 2020-10-29 18:10:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|986091949|HIST 986091949}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|987025720|POL 987025720}}

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
In the Hamas article, the lead mentions 3 nations and one supranational block (the [[EU]] consisting of 27 nations) designating the organization as 'terrorist'. It mentions 4 nations holding the opposite view. It also notes the UN Assembly (193 nations) failed to pass a motion designating Hamas as 'terrorist'. Should this paragraph (a) allow mention of countries that are neutral, such as Norway, Switzerland and Brazil (a third position) (b) retain mention of the UN Assembly vote?[[User:Nishidani|Nishidani]] ([[User talk:Nishidani|talk]]) 18:10, 29 October 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Rules for Fools#rfc_5089653|Wikipedia talk:Rules for Fools]] expired 2020-11-29 01:01 ===
* Id: 5089653
* User: 73.168.5.183
* Date: 2020-10-30 00:44:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The rules currently say that April Fools pranks are banned on mainspace and help talk pages, but do not mention anything about other talk pages, like userspace talk, wikipedia talk, template talk, category talk, file talk pages, and so on. I propose that the April Fools pranks ban be extended to all talk pages, for the same reason as was given in [[Wikipedia:Requests for comment/April Fools' 3#No pranks on mainspace talk and help talk pages or Wikiproject pages|the discussion to ban pranks on mainspace and help talk pages]]. [[Special:Contributions/73.168.5.183|73.168.5.183]] ([[User talk:73.168.5.183|talk]]) 00:44, 30 October 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:TERF#rfc_FB361D8|Talk:TERF]] expired 2020-11-29 09:01 ===
* Id: FB361D8
* User: LokiTheLiar
* Date: 2020-10-30 08:12:00

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|986183662|LANG 986183662}}

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|991293603|LANG 991293603}}

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The page [[TERF]], about the word "TERF" and not the people to whom the term is applied, currently contains three sections after the lede: "Coinage and usage", "Opposition to the word", and "Slur debate", which are each roughly the same length. "Opposition to the word" and "Slur debate" contain many quotes attributed to individuals, mostly opposing the word that the page is about.

Some of the editors on this talk page believe that there are several problems with these two sections (described below for the sake of keeping the RFC description as neutral as possible). Is there a problem with these sections, and if so, what should we do about it? [[User:LokiTheLiar|Loki]] ([[User talk:LokiTheLiar|talk]]) 08:12, 30 October 2020 (UTC)}}

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|991468879|BIO 991468879}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|991468882|POL 991468882}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|991468884|SOC 991468884}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should Kornacki's khaki pants he wore during his election night coverage be mentioned in this article?

'''Survey'''

*'''Yes'''. Kornacki's khaki pants have been reported in reliable sources, such as [https://www.latimes.com/entertainment-arts/story/2020-11-12/steve-kornacki-gap-khaki-sales-chartthrob LA Times] {{RSP entry|Los Angeles Times}} and [https://ew.com/tv/msnbc-steve-kornacki-reacts-thirsty-tweets/ Entertainment Weekly] {{RSP entry|Entertainment Weekly}}. His khaki pants [https://www.huffpost.com/entry/steve-kornacki-sexiest-men-alive_n_5fb59640c5b695be82ff9651 helped] him land on ''People'' magazine's 'Sexiest Men Alive' list in 2020, and Gap Inc. CEO Sonia Syngal [https://www.marketwatch.com/story/gaps-old-navy-and-athleta-brands-are-leading-the-companys-turnaround-2020-11-25 attributed] Kornacki to increased sales of khakis at the retailer. Clearly, this is widely reported content. feminist [[User talk:Feminist|(talk)]] &#124; free Hong Kong 04:15, 30 November 2020 (UTC)}}

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Currently, there is no image in this section. On the right is the image suggested. 
[[File:Cook et al. (2016) Studies consensus-en.svg|thumb|upright=1.5]]

It comes from this peer-reviewed secondary source [https://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/1748-9326/11/4/048002], which NASA also uses on their Climate Change facts pages [https://climate.nasa.gov/scientific-consensus/]. The image does not contain the 3 lower percentages in the study, for agreement among "Sub-sample of publishing climatologists" (see table 1): 83.5% (2008), 88.5% (2005), 89% (2012).

Should we use this image, or another image, or edit this image (only contain cited studies newer than 2010 or all studies), or use no image? [[User:Bogazicili|Bogazicili]] ([[User talk:Bogazicili|talk]]) 19:02, 15 November 2020 (UTC)}}

Syrian Kurdistan is a term used to refer to Kurdish inhabited areas of Syria. This designation is contested, so I would like interested editors to weigh in on the wording of the lead:

*'''A''': Syrian Kurdistan or Western Kurdistan (Kurdish: Rojavay√™ Kurdistan√™‚Äé), often shortened to Rojava, is regarded by many Kurds and some regional experts as the part of Kurdistan in Syria.
*'''B''': Syrian Kurdistan or Western Kurdistan (Kurdish: Rojavay√™ Kurdistan√™‚Äé), often shortened to Rojava, is the Syrian part of Kurdistan
*'''C''': Syrian Kurdistan  (Kurdish: Rojavay√™ Kurdistan√™‚Äé) is the Syrian part of Kurdistan

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Tropical cyclones#rfc_5462E2F|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Tropical cyclones]] expired 2020-12-03 21:01 ===
* Id: 5462E2F
* User: HurricaneTracker495
* Date: 2020-12-01 21:20:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|991801033|SCI 991801033}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|992164130|SCI 992164130}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
So, I noticed something. When we go to landfalls of any category(lets just take [[List of Category 4 Atlantic hurricanes]]), we don't see Chesapeake bay landfalls. Just like we count [[Long Island Sound]] landfalls, I believe we should count storms that make a landfall in the Chesepeake Bay. 

Now, some people may be opposed to this, because what if reliable sources don't say it's a direct landfall. Hmm. Then I am personally a bit more neutral. Still, if we count tiny bodies of water as landfalls, we should definitely count this big of a bay. --[[User:HurricaneTracker495|HurricaneTracker495]] ([[User talk:HurricaneTracker495|talk]]) 21:20, 1 December 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Images#rfc_9AD241B|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Images]] expired 2020-12-03 22:01 ===
* Id: 9AD241B
* User: Sdkb
* Date: 2020-12-02 02:56:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|991845828|BIO 991845828}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|991845830|POLICY 991845830}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|992173850|BIO 992173850}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|992173864|POLICY 992173864}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Which of the following best represents how we should select lead images for biographies of living people?
#'''Option 1''': All else being equal, images from the period in which the subject was most notable are preferred.
#'''Option 2''': All else being equal, more recent images are preferred.
#'''Option 3''': Use Option 1 for subjects most famous for public activities during a certain time period (e.g. most actors, politicians) and Option 2 for other subjects (e.g. most scientists, authors, and businesspeople).
#'''Option 4''': Have no standard, and determine preference on a case-by-case basis.
<span style="color:#AAA"><small>&#123;{u&#124;</small><span style="border-radius:9em;padding:0 5px;background:#088">[[User:Sdkb|<span style="color:#FFF">'''Sdkb'''</span>]]</span><small>}&#125;</small></span>‚ÄØ<sup>[[User talk:Sdkb|'''talk''']]</sup> 02:56, 2 December 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Introduction to entropy#rfc_2A2E105|Talk:Introduction to entropy]] expired 2020-12-03 23:01 ===
* Id: 2A2E105
* User: PAR
* Date: 2020-11-03 22:10:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|986949747|SCI 986949747}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|992182676|SCI 992182676}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
How should the introductory article on (thermodynamic) entropy begin? Order/disorder? Macro/Microstates? Irreversibility? etc.?  

There are two introductions upon which we cannot agree. The present introduction is one, the second is the version of 24 January, 2020. Arguments are presented in the above sections, especially the previous section. [[User:PAR|PAR]] ([[User talk:PAR|talk]]) 22:10, 3 November 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Juno (film)#rfc_3CDA32E|Talk:Juno (film)]] expired 2020-12-04 20:01 ===
* Id: 3CDA32E
* User: Trillfendi
* Date: 2020-12-04 14:17:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|992293179|MEDIA 992293179}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|992347239|MEDIA 992347239}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
It‚Äôs such a shame it has to come to a now formal process but {{xt|reasonable people can disagree with [me].}} It‚Äôs absolute revisionism to say that a identity that did not publicly exist until 13 years later supercedes what is on the official poster and who was nominated for all those awards.  It‚Äôs revisionism to say Juno, a pregnant teenage girl, was then played by a transgender actor. It would‚Äôve been an astronimically bigger controversy than even the alleged, so-called ‚Äúanti-choice‚Äù-ness of the film and the lackadaisical attitude toward teenage pregnancy. Page wasn‚Äôt even publicly gay in 2007. Publicly, Page was a cisgender woman. That‚Äôs as important to the film as it was to her own biographical background. Elliot Page did not portray Juno MacGuff just as the [[Prince_(musician)#1991‚Äì1996:_Name_change,_Diamonds_and_Pearls,_and_Chaos_and_Disorder|Love Symbol #2]] didn‚Äôt create ''[[Purple Rain (album)|Purple Rain]]'' and John ''Ono'' Lennon didn‚Äôt co-write ''[[A Hard Day's Night]]''. My edit wasn‚Äôt even that egregious. There was no so-called ‚Äúconsensus‚Äù for making all links Elliot Page or addressing the pronouns, as the talk page above me shows a sea of questions. Too many news reports, including by CNN and the ''New York Times'', about Page‚Äôs transition preface with the context of Juno. [[User:Trillfendi|Trillfendi]] ([[User talk:Trillfendi|talk]]) 14:17, 4 December 2020 (UTC)}}

On determining if a stub type is useful, [[Wikipedia:Stub]] currently reads:
{{tqb|4. Will there be a significant number of existing stubs in this category? (Ideally, a newly created stub type has 100‚Äì300 articles. In general, any new stub category should have a ''minimum'' of 60 articles. This threshold is modified in the case of the ''main'' stub category used by a [[Wikipedia:WikiProject|WikiProject]].)}}
# Should the recommended minimum of 60 articles be lowered to 25? (This number may be subject to further revision.)
# Should an exception be added for standard subdivisions of large stub types, e.g. dividing [[:Category:Aircraft stubs]] into decades?
